story:
The Play; One Flea Spare by Naomi Wallace:

Are we tricking ourselves into believing we are more tolerant and accepting than we actually are? Do we compartmentalize our lives with imaginary walls between our true selves and our public image?  What does it take to wake us up and shatter these glass walls?

A rich, older couple, a ragged sailor, a desensitized servant girl, and a corrupt guard; these are the characters of Naomi Wallace’s stirring play - One Flea Spare.  Forced to interact very closely over 28 days of quarantine, how will they fare?   

We see these characters in our every day lives: the 1%, the middle-class working man, the fatherless child, and foul authorities.  How do we treat each other when not even forced to be in close quarters every day?

It’s a little easier to take a look at ourselves when we back up and see our reflections in the pool of a past time.  Naomi Wallace asks us to do just that with this play.  

The following statement is one I constructed to help this production team stem from one thematic spot and to maintain the universal qualities of this piece:

"To connect in order to belong by means of deception and revelation in a time of separation."

The Separation is the emotional (and physical) setting in which the characters are found. Separated by the quarantine, separated by class, separated by ideas.

To Connect is the action that the characters are all attempting; physically, emotionally, even just the exchange of words.  Why?

They need to feel as though they Belong somewhere - even though the world around them is full of opposition, we all need to feel like we fit in somewhere.  

Through Deception we see a few of the characters connecting with each other - false pretenses, misleading gestures, flat-out lies, etc.

We also see them connect using Revelation of the truth.  That moment of discovery together forces them to interact in unexpected ways.

These are all ideas that we can all relate to - and I feel as though putting them all in one piece has made this play a powerful entity.

Please feel free to visit the Pinterest page I've created to share image inspiration with the team:

Initial Image Research

Sarah Jo White, our awesome costume designer, also has a pinterest for some of her research:

Costume Research

As more work is done on this (ie. sketches, models, etc.), we will post updates so you can all stay in the know!!

The Team and The Goal:

We have put together a FANTASTIC production team of younger designers/minds.  The main reason for going with younger Chicago artists is to make this an experience from which we can all gain exposure and an unified appreciation for collaboration.  While I have either worked with each member of this team, prior to now, or we have become friends through the community - we all have the same desire to do a show "on our own" and "just for the art."  

We are looking to reach out to the theatre community and present a work that is independent of a season and separated from an already established company.  

Design Team: Jeff-Award-Winning Designer Amanda Rozmiarek (Set Design), Soon-to-be DePaul Graduate Megan Turner (Costume Design), Interrobang Theatre Project's Claire Chrzan (Lighting Design), Professional-Prior-to-Graduation David Samba (Sound Design), and Moscow Art Theatre Alum Vivian Knouse (Props Design)

The cast has been constructed!!!

Morse - Caroline Phillips; Bunce - Sean Jaskiewicz; Snelgrave - Scott Stockwell; Darcy - Dori Erwin Collins; Kabe - David Guy

Rehearsals through June and the first week of July.

8 Performances at The Den Theatre at 1333 N Milwaukee Ave Chicago, IL 60622:

Opening  Sunday, July 13 at 3PM; Thursday, July 17 - Saturday, July 19 at 7:30 PM; Sunday, July 20 at 3PM; Wednesday, July 23 - Friday, July 24 (Closing) at 7:30 PM

The Director: Jeffrey Clark Stokes

I have been working, actively, in the Chicago theatre scene for the 3.5 years since I relocated (Performed in 3 productions, costumed one, and stage managed six).  Prior to Chicago, I got my B.A. in Theatre (minor in Speech Communications) from Ouachita Baptist Univeristy.  There I discovered and developed my passion for directing.  Soon after finishing school - I put up a production of two one acts with related themes; "Plays in the Park," I called it.  After feeling that that was a success, I went on to direct a sideshow staged reading of 4.48 Psychosis by Sarah Kane at the summer theatre company where I worked for two summers.  

My feelings thus far have been that I can use whatever experience I gain to my advantage, as a director.  Here I am, having worked with 8 directors in the Chicago area - and being friends with a few more - ready to put all of my recent experience into a work of my own.  

The Funds

While we realize that $14,250 sounds pretty steep - we intend to use it very wisely; HOWEVER, after a recent meeting with the team - we have determined we can put this production together for as little as $4000!!! This is exciting because if we reach this goal, we will have a production.  Anything more than that will just enhance our project!!!

No one is expecting to walk away from this production with deep pockets.  However, with the time and artistic commitment we want all involved in this production to be rewarded for their hard work and their creative endeavors; each person involved will be getting a couple hundred dollars as a modest stipend.  (Stipends for All Involved; Actors, Designers, Marketing, PR - $5500).

They will, of course, also need a budget to work with - having discussed this with each of my team - we have constructed a strict budget to work from.  (Budgets for All Creative Departments; Set, Lights, Costumes, Sound, Props - $3100).

Rehearsal and Performance Space Rentals - $3050.

Marketing/PR - $1200.

Rights to The Production/Running Costs/Processing Fees/Etc. - $1400.

How Else To Help!

If nothing else, please SPREAD THE WORD!  

Word-of-Mouth is still the best form of publicity!

story:
Trolley Dances Riverside is an iconic event produced by P.L.A.C.E. Performance and the Riverside City College Dance program in partnership with Riverside Transit Agency. In this, it's third year, the project will be in collaboration with La Sierra High School dancers who as interns will learn the "ins and outs" of the project, research the history of the various sites for dances, and also perform at the event. Any and all support is greatly appreciated. It is our hope that those in attendance will have an opportunity to see dance in all forms. Usually confined to a stage or theater, in this instance dances are performed in the open air amongst various landmarks, here in the heart of our beautiful, innovative, up and coming arts community of Riverside California. Please join us on October 18, 2014 for this captivating and awe inspiring event. Trolley Dances is a trademark of Jean Isaacs San Diego Dance Theater.

Your contribution will ensure that Trolley Dances Riverside continues to bring quality performances every year and opens the possibility of expanding to new communities in the near future. Contributions of $5 and up are appreciated and celebrated! Thank you for reading our story...

story:
About The Play

Diner of Eden is about an old man named Art, who is having a difficult time getting over the death of his wife of 47 years. Everyday he returnes to their favorite diner and relives the night they first met. 

Meet The Cast And Crew



Nicholas McGovern (Art) became a resident of Harlem NY this past November and is thrilled to make is NYC debut at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre.  Born into an athletic family in Springfield VA, his early interests were in athletics-a passion he followed to the University of Mary Washington where he played baseball for two years before finding his love for acting.  After studying at the Atlantic Acting School and graduating from UMW this past May with a BA in Theatre, he signed on to make his television debut in ABC/Amazon Studios pilot, Point of Honor-directed by Randall Wallace (Braveheart), and made the move to NY a month later.  He would like to thank his parents Michael and Julie for their unwavering love and support in his journey. 



Meghan Leathers (Joyce) is a recent graduate of Middlebury College, where she studied Theatre and Art History. Off-Broadway: Gertrude - The Cry (Ragusa), Serious Money (Gleason), Middlebury Credits include Boston Marriage (Anna), Vinegar Tom (Margery), The Castle(Ann), US Drag (Angela), Big Love (Lydia) and Victory (Gwynn, Cropper). Meghan was also a finalist in the 2012 Kennedy Center for the Arts American College Theatre Festival Irene Ryan competition, Region 1.



Diane Sykes is thrilled to be part of the cast of 'Diner of Eden,' as the kindly waitress, Jill.  Most recently, Diane played a therapist held captive by her homicidal patient in the original work, "Unsolvable Riddle" at The Barrow Group.  But her favorite role to date has been Vivian Bearing in 'Wit' at the Generic Theater in Norfolk, Virginia.  During the day, Diane is a news producer, and a very good tipper to wait staff.



Jessica Lehman (Director) is thrilled to be back at Manhattan Rep directing Diner of Eden. She most recently directedThe Lives We Lead as part of Manhattan Repertory Theatre's Fall One Act Competition. She is a recent graduate of Quinnipiac University with degrees in Theater and Film, Video, and Interactive Media. She is also an actor, currently appearing as Kitty in Casey -- 30 Years Later at Broadway Comedy Club.


Why We Need You

Manhattan Repertory Theatre provides the performance space, lights, sound, and set pieces for the production. Everything else, we're on our own. Funding this production is a large expense. Your donations will go toward:

  • Renting out Rehearsal Spaces - $1320
  • Printing Programs - $100
  • Participating Fee - $150
  • Props, Costumes, Food Prop Items - $200
  • Reward Shipping Fee - $50
  •  Indiegogo Cost - $80 - $180

Right now we are funding this project out of our own pockets. Any generous donations would greatly be appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please share our campaign!

And if you're in the NYC area come out and see our show! 

January 13, 14,15,and 16th at 9PM. Tickets are $20 and can be reserved by emailing mrtreserve@gmail.com.

story:
In history, there's always been movements that sounded crazy in the beginning but eventually became game changers. The Civil Rights Movement, the Stonewall riots and then came hip hop making history with a slab of linoleum, a spray can, two turntables and a microphone.

Welcome to the future of The Human Project. An Urban Arts Collective.

I'm Anton and for 10 years my dance company produced countless workshops, battles and concerts for the purpose of elevating the urban arts. Our goal was to always honor the history of the culture but at the same time push it forward artistically in unexpected ways.

My new vision is to take that same respect and creativity to the next level by creating a show where all the songs, beats, dancing and visuals are written, produced, and choreographed in house. And to top it of, I also want to tour this show.

So, I need your help. I have the talent and the ideas but your donation will help me pay for studio time to make songs, choreography rehearsals, music publishing, costumes, travel expenses and so much more. Sounds crazy but I'm optimistic that we can do it. And you're not just helping me, you're helping all of my friends and collaborators who sacrifice to bring quality art to their communities.

Thank you for your time and contribution in advance. Big hugs! Anton

story:
Chekhov in The Lower East Side. Smoke Machines. Soap Opera Stars. Taxidermy?

David Bucci has written a visceral play that is an homage, but not a literal adaptation, of that most theater-y of plays, Chekhov's "The Seagull." It asks the big questions we as artists contemplate on the daily: What is the true nature of art? What does it mean to be an artist? Who should be 'allowed' to call themselves an artist? Is art a hobby or a calling? And of course, what is the true nature of love?

There is also taxidermy.

We are literally freaking out, we are so psyched to bring this amazing play to life, BUT WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!!

We have a theatre space, thank goodness, but we still need….

  •     A Fog Machine & Fog Machine Juice: $100
  •    An old-school video camcorder that is still usable: $200
  •    A typewriter, preferably one that works: $150
  •    A taxidermied possum, one without a bad attitude: $600-ish
  •    A portable record player and vinyl copy of "House Of The Rising Sun" : $100
  •    Wood, Wood, and more WOOD:  Around $1500
  •    Approximately 44 hours of off site rehearsal space at $15/hour: $660
  •    Assorted Props and Fancy-Type Duds for Actors: $500-ish
  •    Actor, Director, Stage Manager and Designer Stipends: $3800

You get it.  We need to raise about $10,000.00 to mount the production we think this script deserves.  We are hoping to raise at least $7,500.00 of that with this campaign. 

All gifts are tax deductible, as Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)3. So any contribution you make helps you come tax time! Let Uncle Sam know you've been supporting the arts!

Seriously though, THANK YOU for Helping Bring This Script to Life

Hopefully some of our perks will excite you.  But even more importantly, we hope supporting great theatre and this exceptional script will inspire you.  We will be grateful for any donation, no matter how small.  And, if you have no funds to give,that's cool too, you can still show your support by: 

TAKE THE WORD OF THE POSSUM TO THE STREETS!!! (and the tweets)

  • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vine, or by carrier pigeons, smoke signals and skywriting.
  • Follow our progress by following and re-tweeting us on Twitter. (@ThePossumPlay, @TheatreOfNOTE.)
  • Hashtag us with #NOTEPossum
  • Follow the play visually on Instragram @TheatreOfNOTE.
  • "Like" Theatre of NOTE on Facebook and get our news in your feed!
  • Come out to our Halloween, Punk Rock Karaoke event in late October!
  • Get a possum stencil and some graffiti and do it up Punk Rock DIY style! (Theatre of NOTE does not condone vandalism, but possums do.)
  • And most importantly, honey child, don’t forget to come experience “Possum Carcass," opening December 4th at Theatre of NOTE!!!


IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PLAY AND OUR TEAM, READ THIS…

Theatre Of NOTE has been an LA Theater institution for over 30 years, and in that time has developed a reputation as a place where original, edgy, world premiere plays are brought to vibrant, visceral, non-compromised life. We are proud to now add David Bucci's play Possum Carcass to the mix. He has had plays performed in NYC, Seattle, Providence, Washington D.C., Austin, and now LA. Possum Carcass represents his triumphant and long overdue return to playwriting.

The show opens in our theatre at 1517 N. Cahuenga Boulevard (on Sunset, across from Amoeba Records!) in Hollywood, on December 4th, 2014. We want you beautiful babies there!


THANKS SO MUCH FOR ALL YOUR HELP!

Sincerely,

The Possum Carcass Crew

story:
Once upon a time ...

... long ago on an island far far away (to anyone living in Boise, Idaho), Paul Gregg was walking down the Avenues of Manhattan singing along to his iPod. "Oh, I love this song!" he said. "Too bad I'll never get to sing it for an audience. I'm not right for the role." Dejected, he did his best impression of an upset Dennis the Menace - hands in imaginary overalls, kickin a pebble. Well, that pebble bounced off a fire hydrant and flew up to hit Paul square in the head, knocking him into an Alternate Side Street Cleaning sign, and throwing him into a hazy confusion of musical theatre and a strange need to cross the street every Tuesday/Thursday morning. And that's when Paul saw it: HIS OWN CABARET! "Of course - it's so clear now. I can sing whatever the heck I want in my own show!" And he ran home with this golden ticket of an idea, to write out his own Willy Wonka whacky style of show.

Really?? ...

Ok … so that might not be exactly how it started, but this dream of a show did in fact begin it’s life as a vessel to sing all the songs I’ve always wanted to perform. But through the writing process, it’s morphed into the hilarious and heartwarming tale of my time here in New York City, pursuing the elusive Musical Theatre Career, complete with song, dance, sass, true awkward confessions, and not a toaster in sight!


    Why use IndieGoGo then?

    Well, as much you can’t turn around without seeing someone else’s Off-Off-Off Broadway show opening, or yet another mime troop roaming free down 10th avenue, don’t be misled – polished and ready theatre doesn’t fall from the sky. Your donations will help fund:

    • Rehearsal studios and equipment
    • Copies of all the music and scripts for rehearsals
    • Payment for the actors, dancers, and musicians -- who are all very hungry (especially the dancers)
    • Rental of the theatre and lighting/sound equipment for performance (and if we make our fundraising goal, they promise to include the seat cushions!)
    • Coffee and donuts so all staff members remain awake and functional (I told you they were hungry!)

    But that’s not all your donations accomplish:

    • By clicking "donate" you have the chance to take home some awesome prizes! Just check out the right side of your screen for the goodies each donation level receives. Isn't online shopping fun?!
    • I'm a huge believer that theatre should be accessible and affordable to all, so any amount above the fundraising goal we raise will be used to reduce the ticket prices for all. This will also be true should we receive any sort of corporate sponsorship (I'm looking at YOU Dunkin' Donuts!)

     

    Ok Paul, I'm pretty convinced and I'm ready to donate. I just have a few more questions ...

    Don’t worry, I’m way ahead of you and ready with those answers:

    1.  Will I know any of the other stars also performing in your show? Well, let me put it this way – you’ll get to say “I saw them when they weren’t famous yet!”… and that’s priceless. In my years in NYC, I’ve met some unbelievably talented people on the fast-track to stardom, and I’ve got many of them in line for this show (i.e. tricked into agreeing to perform with promises of donuts and laughter)

    2.  What’s with the toaster theme? Come to the show and find out! (Diabolical answer, I know, but totally worth it!)

    3.  Do you have any clips to show me? Yes! But you have to check back in for those. I’ll be posting rehearsal videos and song clips throughout the campaign, so donate now and keep checking back in for more!

    4.  When is the show? The show will be on Sat November 15th at 7:30pm at LittleField (622 Degraw St, Brooklyn NY 11217). Tickets are $15 cash at the door (doors open at 7:00pm), or available for online purchase at http://www.ticketfly.com/purchase/event/708671

    5.  Do you ever stop talking? No.
story_txt:
Once upon a time ... ... long ago on an island far far away (to anyone living in Boise, Idaho), Paul Gregg was walking down the Avenues of Manhattan singing along to his iPod. "Oh, I love this song!" he said. "Too bad I'll never get to sing it for an audience. I'm not right for the role." Dejected, he did his best impression of an upset Dennis the Menace - hands in imaginary overalls, kickin a pebble. Well, that pebble bounced off a fire hydrant and flew up to hit Paul square in the head, knocking him into an Alternate Side Street Cleaning sign, and throwing him into a hazy confusion of musical theatre and a strange need to cross the street every Tuesday/Thursday morning. And that's when Paul saw it: HIS OWN CABARET! "Of course - it's so clear now. I can sing whatever the heck I want in my own show!" And he ran home with this golden ticket of an idea, to write out his own Willy Wonka whacky style of show.



Really?? ... 


Ok … so that might not be exactly
how it started, but this dream of a show did in fact begin it’s life as a
vessel to sing all the songs I’ve always wanted to perform. But through the
writing process, it’s morphed into the hilarious and heartwarming tale of my
time here in New York City, pursuing the elusive Musical Theatre Career,
complete with song, dance, sass, true awkward confessions, and not a toaster in
sight!

worry, I’m way ahead of you and ready with those answers:

I’ve got many of them in line for this show (i.e. tricked into agreeing to

2.

3.

No.

story:
You've heard from Fran Tarr, the director/founder of breaking walls, and four of our amazing Cape Town artists . . .  building our diverse, yet unified artistic ensemble is one gigantic step towards ending what so many youth suffer with -- voice poverty. Through critical reflection, creative writing and live theater performance our artists become conscious of our world and through consciousness – through knowing and sharing – breaking walls artists and ambassadors have the power to transform our world. 

This is YOUR chance right now to empower the voices of international youth building an empathetic, peaceful world for themselves and their peers.  PICK A PERK TO YOUR RIGHT . . .

WANT TO LEARN MORE ABOUT BREAKING WALLS?

I’m Fran Tarr, an educator by profession with a passion for writing and children. My first teaching assignment is in an elementary school on the South Side of Chicago in the 1970s. I’m the teacher but I learn so much from the children. I learn that I don’t like the assumptions placed on the kids and if I’m teaching correctly, using the incredible vehicle of art, perhaps, I can guide them to discover their ever-evolving possibilities.

This is a lesson that stays with me until today, and inspires me in 2011 to create breaking walls, an international creative writing and performance initiative, that empowers youth, ages 13 – 22, to discover their voice, and offers them a platform on which to use it.

At breaking walls our artists are our writer-performers, and our ambassadors are youth facilitators who were once artists themselves. Each breaking walls artist and ambassador is a part of a forum where young voices are creatively represented and nurtured on the path to leadership.

Our first initiative is breaking walls  2012 Berlin that brings together youth from Brooklyn, Berlin and Bethlehem write, perform and share life experiences. We learn much from our Berlin experience, all good with one exception. Our Berlin artists wish to stay at the youth hostel with their Bethlehem and Brooklyn friends. As we approach breaking walls  2014 we have the extraordinary opportunity to install a new level of commitment and community

breaking walls is raising funds for all four delegations from Bethlehem, Berlin, Brooklyn and Cape Town to stay as a creative community at the Rotary Camp in Gelncairn, Cape Town for the nine-day initiative. Staying as one community our 20 artists and 6 ambassadors can build a deep trust with each other as they reach into their most protected places to write, share and build a beautiful ensemble creating theater together.

Mohammad (Bethlehem), Lucie (Berlin), Mahmoud (Bethlehem), Merve (Berlin), Kofo (Brooklyn) and Corinna (Berlin) happy to be together at our Berlin youth hostel.

Right this minute is your chance to add our 12 Cape Town artists to this picture. PICK A PERK TO YOUR RIGHT . . . BE A PART OF OUR OPENING NIGHT FESTIVITIES . . . GET A PEEK AT OUR REHEARSAL PROCESS . . .

WANT TO LEARN MORE ABOUT BREAKING WALLS AND WHY IT MATTERS TO OUR YOUTH NOW?

When asked to assess the overall success breaking walls  2012 Berlin initiative, 16 of the 16 of the artists felt they had built a community that then allowed them to consider individual leadership roles as an ambassador. Among the artists, 16 wished to continue in 2014 and, 16 were eager to apply to become ambassadors.

In the words of Canaan of Bethlehem, “I enjoyed the writing very much, I believe that my writing has become stronger. I also started thinking more about the ideas that mean something valuable to me. I am excited for our performance today. I made many friends . . . we became like a family . . . brothers, sisters, mom and dad. I will be sad to leave Berlin.”

Our breaking walls impact and empowerment resonates long after an initiative ends, and our artists and ambassadors return to their home communities. Our youth actively participate in international grassroots conferences and workshops; igniting a movement to create a youth sports program in the West Bank Refugee Camps; as well as, addressing the International Day of Peace at the United Nations in New York.

Even more empowering are the words I often hear. “It’s nice to see the Brooklyn and Bethlehem kids, who are usually seen as the ones in need of an intervention, guiding others to success.”

So, please support breaking walls 2014 Cape Town. YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE IN ENDING VOICE POVERTY, STEREOTYPING, MISUNDERSTANDINGS AND MISCONCEPTIONS THAT STAND BETWEEN OUR YOUTH AND THE OPEN EMPATHIC, PEACEFUL THEY ARE SEEKING.

I always want to say “yes” when I see a truly inspirational cause, yet I am keenly aware that many times there are options to using my credit card. breaking walls understands this, too; so we ask you to spread, spread the word about these amazing artists and ambassadors.

story:
Contemplating is...

Award-winning composer, performer and visual artist Robert Szymanek makes his directorial debut with Contemplating, a concert spectacular for the ears, eyes and mind. The world premiere takes place at 7:30pm on Friday 18th July at the Jerwood Hall at LSO St Luke's.*

Presented in conjunction with London Symphony Orchestra's Soundhub Scheme for emerging composers, and under the guidance of opera Director Keith Warner, this is a concert like no other: a suite of Robert's new songs and instrumental pieces dramatised for the stage. Artists Kira Zhigalina and Anna Salmane provide the visual backdrop, together with origami from Rebecca Ephgrave and innovative lighting design from Willow Bleasdale.

Here is Robert on the project:

"This is my most ambitious work to date. I've brought together a team of wonderful musicians and artists. Keith has been just an amazing mentor, and he's raving about it as much as us."

And the subject? Contemplating! Or more importantly, the discoveries we all make through the act of contemplation. About ourselves, each other, the world around us.

"We're putting everything we've got into it to make it the remarkable event we all feel it should be. There is already interest from other venues for future performances. More importantly, however, I think we've got something that audiences will really enjoy and gain a lot from. We've already had a couple of previews of various pieces with excellent feedback."

More information about all the artists and musicians involved in the project can be found at the bottom of this page.

*The concert is free entry. To reserve your seats, please write to robert@robertszymanek.com.

What We Need

The project has been made possible through the LSO's Soundhub Scheme for emerging composers. They have granted five 3-hour sessions in the Jerwood Hall for rehearsals together with technical support for the concert.

Other funding has come through a generous award from the Hinrichsen Foundation. This has been used to pay all the musicians and artists properly for their involvement. As Director, Robert has been responsible for hiring the other artists. He is not taking any money for himself or looking to make financial gain.

The concert has incurred an additional £2,515 in technical fees from LSO St Luke's, which need to be paid by the end of August 2014. These comprise of:

- £1,800 for additional technical support. This comes in the form of three hired technicians who will operate the lighting rigs, screen projector and PA system in the hall during rehearsals. Each technician bares a cost of £200 per session in the hall. They are each required for three sessions, bringing the total cost to £1,800.

- £495 for additional hall hire. Because of the scale of the event, it has been necessary to hire the Jerwood Hall for an extra 3-hour session in addition to the sessions provided by the LSO Soundhub Scheme. The usual cost of the hall for 3 hours is close to £1,500, but we have been able to secure a discounted rate.

- £150 for concert stewards. Three LSO stewards need to be hired for the concert, with a cost of £50 each for their work over the whole day and through the event.

- £70 for piano tuning. The Steinway Grand piano in the Jerwood Hall is a remarkable instrument that requires regular maintenance. With all the moving required for rehearsals and the concert, the piano needs to be tuned on the day of the performance. £70 is the standard rate for LSO St Luke's piano tuners.

There is a '4% of the target' fee from Indiegogo.com. This comes to just over £100. And finally there is an approximate 3.5% PayPal fee for all transactions. This is £88, taking the total we are looking to raise to to £2700.

Donations and Perks

All donations will be gratefully received. A variety of perks have been created, including a CD of music from the concert and copies of Robert Szymanek's previous releases. These can either be collected on the night of the concert if you are attending, or they can be posted to you to arrive in early August.

What Happens If the Target is Not Reached

This fund-raising scheme is based on Indiegogo's Flexible Funding package. That means that whether or not we reach our target, all funds will be kept and go towards the LSO fees.

However, if we do not reach our target, Indiegogo.com will increase their fee to 9% of the target. This will be paid from the funds raised.

The concert will go ahead in July as planned no matter what. If the target is not reached, the remainder of the fees will be sourced from Robert's own finances.

People, People, People

Robert Szymanek's music has been performed around the world by some of the world's leading ensembles and soloists (BBC Singers, Vasko Vassilev, Barbican Mainstage, Southbank Centre; Youth Orchestra of the Middle East in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, Peter Davoran at the Kyoto Music Festival). In 2009 he was shortlisted for a British Composers Award and in 2012 he received his PhD in Composition from the Royal Academy of Music, working with Brian Elias. 

Kira Zhigalina (Ki Ra) is a multimedia artist graduated from Central St. Martins. She created installations and visual projections for Secret Cinema, London Contemporary Orchestra, London Zoo, Musion Holographic Systems, Tate Modern, onedotzero, Vivienne Westwood Show, The Leaf Label, Fruit for the Apocalypse, Unfashion Show, and the Rambert Dance Company. Kira won Kinetica Award in 2012 at Kinetica Artfair, and in 2010 she won an award for performance at MAMAs 2010.

Anna Salmane is a visual artist working with installation, photography andvideo. She received her Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree from Goldsmiths College, University of London and Master of Philosophy from University of Latvia. She has been participating in group exhibitions since 2001 and has had solo shows in London, Nottingham and Riga. In 2013, her public art work 'For Reasons Unknown' was shortlisted for Latvian Contemporary Art Prize nomination.

Willow Bleasdale creates lighting designs for theatre, dance and opera; and lighting effects and soft circuits for homewares, hand-held properties and wearable tech.Willow attends the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama in London and is currently in her final year of the Theatre Practice Lighting Design course. She recently designed and built a light installation for the Vivid Festival of Lighting, Music and Ideas in Sydney.

Musicians: Percussion: Sarah Mason (LPO, Glyndebourne), Barnaby Archer (ENO, Les Miserables), Harp: Mali Llywelyn (Race Horses); Piano: Kate Halsall (Piano Circus); Flute: Joshua Batty (LSO, Britten Sinfonia); Violin: Alice Barron (WOMAD), Sarah Hill (Sautinne Quartet), Eugene Feygelson (iequalsu Festival); Viola: Jenny Wilkinson (RPCO). Soprano Ruth Hopkins (K'antu Ensemble); Mezzo Soprano Lucie Lourvrier (Sorbonne Schola Cantorum). The concert also features the Wave Theremin, invented by Horst Gruhle.

story:
Short Summary

Roaring was birthed out of my desire to see authentic and holistic representations of Trans characters on a Broadway stage. Being a Trans woman of color I rarely saw characters that reflected my artistic and realistic sensibilities, I still rarely see characters that look like me. 

 Andrew and I did a reading of this incredible work in 2013 at Takoma Station in DC. Our ultimate goal is Broadway;  so we wish to do a reading of Roaring in NYC at  the historic Don't Tell Mama to get to hear what New York has to say about this amazing work.

Never before has their been a musical that deals with the Trans experience in the context of a family of color within the 1920s. Roaring is  a new, exciting,  and one of a kind. Also, both creators are apart of the LGBTQ community.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this fundraiser is 4,000. Being performance artist and writers, we understand the need and responsibility of being able to compensate performers for their amazing work. 

Andrew and I desire to be able to pay for the travel of our cast to New York, their food for the evening, a small stipend as well as pay for the use of historical Don't Tell Mamas. 

The Impact

Roaring is the first musical to date written by a trans woman of color about a trans woman of color in the 1920s.  By supporting this amazing work you are helping to give birth to a piece of history that reflects back. By supporting this work you are helping the success of trans women of color voices within theater. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out about this amazing work that deals with a silent part of LGBTQ history. 

Share on your face book

Tweet #FundRoaring

Share our campaign

Thank you for your love and continued support. xoxox

Being performance artist and writers, we understand the need and responsibility of being able to compensate performers for their amazing work. Andrew and I desire to be able to pay for the travel of our cast to New York, their food for the evening, a small stipend as well as pay for the use of historical Don't Tell Mamas. The ImpactRoaring is the first musical to date written by a trans woman of color about a trans woman of color in the 1920s.  By supporting this amazing work you are helping to give birth to a piece of history that reflects back. By supporting this work you are helping the success of trans women of color voices within theater. Other Ways You Can HelpPlease get the word out about this amazing work that deals with a silent part of LGBTQ history. Share on your face bookTweet #FundRoaringShare our campaignThank you for your love and continued support. xoxox

story:
video compiled & edited by Tatiana Shannon/ Choreography by Claire Maurey

Hello!

My name is Uma Shannon, I am 18 and I am a dancer from Amherst, MA. I began dancing four and a half years ago shortly before my 14th birthday.  

I am currently a student at East Street Ballet, in Hadley Ma. I am also a member of The Movery, a contemporary dance company founded by dancer/choreographer Claire Maurey, also based in Hadley MA. I dance over 30 hours weekly between classes, rehearsals and performances.

Dancing is my passion, and I currently train in ballet, contemporary and modern. I have also studied character and flamenco. I have the good fortune to study with Carlos Molina, Claire Maurey and Tekla Kostek.  My former teachers include Irina Vakhromeeva, Andre Reyes, Taj Jimenez, and Ines Arrubla among others.

My performance experience is varied and includes classical variations and original contemporary pieces created for East Street Ballet, and performing with The Movery. Over the past four and a half years I have performed at venues across the Pioneer Valley appearing in pieces performed at the Massachusetts Dance Festival, Northampton's First Night 2013, and East Street Studio Theater, among others.

My first two summer intensives were through a small program at the Bolshoi Ballet Academy in Moscow, Russia. Last summer I attended Gelsey Kirkland Academy of Classical Ballet in New York City.  It was a very successful intensive as I received invitations to return both for the 2013-2014 school year, and for this coming summer.  I chose to remain at East Street Ballet because of the high caliber of the instructors, the intimate environment, the range of classes, and the financial aid offered.

This winter I also auditioned and was accepted at Joffrey Ballet for both their summer and trainee programs, and Hartt Community Division for their "From Studio to Stage" summer ballet intensive with Artistic Director Angel Corrella, and Urbanity Dance. I received a number of partial merit scholarships, but I chose Hartt because of what they offer in terms of training (4 weeks, six days a week training in classical & contemporary technique, pointe, partnering, variations, composition and body conditioning) and financial assistance. 

In order to progress and reach my goals, I am continuously looking to expand my knowledge and experiences as a dancer. I need to pursue a varied dance curriculum, and grow my dance vocabulary. In order to do so, I need to train throughout the year.

The money I raise through this campaign will help me cover the cost of tuition and room and board that come with my acceptance to " From Studio to Stage" summer ballet intensive at Hartt in Hartford CT. Any moneys raised above what I have requested will be applied towards 5 pairs of pointe shoes, 2 pairs of ballet slippers, tights, and leotards. Even with the merit scholarship I received from Hartt I will need to raise $3675 to cover the costs of tuition and housing at this month long program.

I live to dance, and I really appreciate all the support you can provide. My parents’ contributions are especially limited this year, as my father was laid off last summer and I am one of five children. All my work savings are dedicated to my dancing pursuits, and my sisters are assisting me in this fundraising campaign. If you can't contribute financially there are also other ways to help. 

A campaign like this is only as good as it's sharing- If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support the campaign that can be a really big help. Indiegogo uses its "GoGo Factor" to determine who gets to be on the home page, and at the top of the searches for different categories.

story:
Aiutaci a liberare la nostra passione!

Abbiamo ancora tante idee da sperimentare e tante storie da raccontare, con la ricerca di fondi dal basso potremo continuare a mettere in scena i nostri spettacoli.
Non facciamo morire le cose belle, se ogni amico ci sostiene e Passaparola il nostro progetto potrà sopravvivere.
E' facile, basta un click e in cambio riceverete dei doni.. danzanti!
#aiutadanzainscena


Chi siamo

DANZA IN SCENA è un progetto sotto la direzione artistica di Alessandra Costa, dedicato ad allievi di tutte le età che abbiano un livello di studio intermedio - avanzato e per danzatori che abbiano un buon livello di esperienza.
Si tratta di un'occasione unica per approfondire lo studio della danza contemporanea e del teatro-danza attraverso un percorso fatto di lezioni tecniche -laboratori - prove -performance ma soprattutto spettacolo e sperimentazione di un processo creativo in tutte le varie declinazioni.

Il progetto è dedicato a tutti coloro che vogliono approfondire lo studio della danza praticandolo e sperimentandolo nell'esperienza di scena.

La particolarità del Progetto DANZA IN SCENA sta proprio in questo: formare, perfezionare il danzatore mettendolo in gioco direttamente su quello che sarà il suo campo d'azione, ovvero la performance e il suo inevitabile dialogo con lo spettatore da una parte e con lo staff tecnico dall'altra. Dunque si studia e si va in scena e andando in scena si accelerano determinati processi di comprensione e maturazione.

Audizioni

Vuoi far parte anche tu di questo progetto? Iscriviti alle nostre audizioni:

- Sabato 28 Giugno ore 10:00

o

- Sabato 06 Settembre ore 10:00

Per accedere all'AUDIZIONE: inviare a info@arcobalenodanza.it
CV con descrizione del percorso di studi e lettera di motivazione  specificando la data scelta
Per saperne di più http://danzainscena.weebly.com/
Se non ti è possibile presentarti alle date dedicate puoi venire alle lezioni settimanali, mandaci una mail per definire giorni e orari.


Le nostre produzioni

TRE STANZE di Alessandra Costa

DEL MIO CORPO FACCIO SPADARegia di Alessandra Costa e  coreografie di Alessandra Costa e Davide Manico

TUTTI SULLA STESSA BARCAdi Alessandra Costa e con la partecipazione di Nicola Caruso (attore e pianista)

POETA MEdi Alessandra Costa

MA QUANTE STORIE ! di Alessandra Costa

WONDERLAND EXPRESS di Davide Manico

LIVIDO di davide Manico

"IO E LA SAGRA... Santa sagra della primavera"
Regia e coreografia di Alessandra Costa
Al pianoforte Monica Dreossi e Chiara Sarchini

"SELF-PROMOTION... il lato crudele della normalità"
Regia e coreografia di Davide Manico

"SCORES... tra composizione e improvvisazione"
Regia e coreografia di Simone Magnani
Musica dal vivo di Alex Stangoni

"CONCERTO PER PRINCIPESSE SINGLE"
Regia e coreografia di Alessandra Costa
Musica dal vivo dei MaiPiùSenza di Alex Stangoni e Serena Rose Zerri

story:
Featuring an ensemble of eight women and original music, this new, devised clown show will draw from historical as well as contemporary resources in devising a world where sad clowns explore deep longing, desire and loss. In looking closely at Brassaï's photographs from Le Monocle in Paris during the 1930s, this project will work to excavate queer history and connect it with our own political moment.

But we can't do any of that connecting without your help. Your support not only helps us to build our set, construct costumes, share small stipends, turn on lights and piece together props, it also helps to energize the innovative and classic world of the clown. In a theatre scene stifled by reality, we are looking for your help to explore a theatrical world of our own that is mashed up in secret histories and famous funny, and sad, acts.

Your gift will be used to help us:

  • Support our generous theatre and rehearsal space
  • Build original costumes, set pieces, art and props from found materials
  • Offer small stipends to our talented performers and collaborators 

With performances around the corner, April 16 - 27, 2014 at The Secret Theatre, we are jumping at the challenge to make this project happen. Surrounded by texts, photographs, scores, music, and a talented ensemble, we are looking for you to help complete our ensemble of support and energy. Inspired by the rich history of feminist skill shares, we are offering our own skills to you in exchange for your support. Check them out. Pick one, or two, or just send us a check for $2500. Please.

Starring: Johana Barral, Corrie Blissit, Marjorie Conn, Lauren Durdach, Jamie Law, Jessica Ranville, Dana Scurlock and Kamaria Williams

Directed by Clare Hammoor

Co-produced by The Secret Theatre & Clare Hammoor

This production features original, live percussion by Abby Fisher. Costume design is done by Amalya Meira Goldberg. Scenic design by Bradley Wehrle. Lighting design by Jake DeGroot. Charlene Deen is the production stage manager. This production is co-produced by The Secret Theatre (Richard Mazda, Artistic Director) and Clare Hammoor.

THE SECRET PARIS PROJECT plays the following regular schedule April 17-26: Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sunday at 8p at The Secret Theatre (4402 23rd Street, Long Island City, NY 11101). 

In connection with THE SECRET PARIS PROJECT there will be a post-show conversation with Circus Amok founder and performer, Jennifer Miller on April 19th, a post-show performance by internationally acclaimed, French singer-songwriter Marine Futin on April 25th and a post-show workshop discussion of devised theatre making with the ensemble of THE SECRET PARIS PROJECT and director Clare Hammoor on April 24th.

Photo by Ashley Lauren Hamilton.

story:
Who We Are: 

             The Humanist Project

Incorporating the full Human experience into our Work, Play, Life and Art

We are all born capable of having and expressing the full range of human experience. In order to fit in, we begin to manage and limit the scope of who we are. Because of this the Humanist Project believes artists and their communities have become disempowered. We bring only particular parts of our humanity to our work, play and expression. And so the “great debate” of who we are and what we should do is happening among a few individuals instead of the entire community. 


Using performance as a vehicle, The Humanist Project is a theater company that is asking the artist to bring all the elements of their spirit to their work and to integrate those elements more fully. We are creating new customs in and out of the studio to unify our voice, play, movement, and thought. 
We are using these new customs in creating original work and in staging existing works with humanist themes for public performance. The Humanist Project is interested in a performance style that provokes our audience to ask same questions we are asking of ourselves, without lecturing or providing answers.
We believe that by making the audience a necessary part of performance we awaken that which is already within them. The desire to engage more fully in their Lives, Work and Play.

Francis Goes to War:

The Humanist Project is currently workshopping a new play written by Michael Toomey called:

"Francis Goes to War" This ain’t the Boy Scouts Francis

It asks the questions: "What happens when a young man who has never spend a night away from home suddenly finds himself in the middle of a World War? What happens when destiny takes hold in a Clown’s world?" “Francis goes to War” takes a comedic look at what is means to be at War in today’s Global Community. Where every War is a Civil War. It is a evening of  Big laughs, Big questions, a little bit of slapstick and maybe some tears.

A Matching Grant:

We have found a private donor who has agreed to provide us with a Matching Grant. This means for every $1 we raise this donor will give us $2. Up to $5,000. This means that if we can reach our Indiegogo goal of $5,000 this private donor will give us another $10,000 for a total of 15,000! This would get us even closer to our budget for the show. But only with your support can we make this happens. Donate today!

What We Need & What You Get:

We have been workshopping this play throughout the fall and plan to have a proper rehearsal of four weeks starting in February 2014 with performances starting at the end of March. In order to do this we need to pay for rehearsal space, performance space, designers fees, costumes, sets and props and the performers. 

It is only with the support of Friends, Family and Comrades like you that great Art can be created. 

If we found 

200 people to donate $25 we would reach our goal

100 people to donate $50 we would reach our goal

50 people to donate $100 we would reach our goal

10 people to donate $500 we would reach our goal

And just look to right to see all these great perks like free tickets to the show and invites to the opening night.

There are many ways to support this campaign. Not only can you donate to the campaign but you can 

Spread the word about The Humanist Project and 'Francis Goes to War' 

Like us on Facebook

Visit our website The Humanist Project

Tell all your friends and family about this new exciting company.

story:
be [human] with me

will premiere June 5 & 6th 8pm at Center for Performance Research
and be released as a dance film directed by Anthony McGowan late 2013.

Under the direction of Ariel Asch, the show will feature amazing dancers from all walks of life with the live music of Sashka, Silas Fermoy, the Glenn Asch Quartet, and more.  It will also feature the projection design and cinematography of Anthony McGowan, and set design by Rich Hahn.

The indie-ballet collaborative is a project based company where a new inclusive performance-experience is created by our commitment to fostering a synergetic relationship between dance and other art forms.  We have assembled a team of artists; dancers, musicians, photographers, film-makers, and actors to collaboratively create an evening length work based on our own human experience- fond memories, finer (and not so “fine”) moments, struggles, celebrations, and sense of humor.  The work is named as a directive for our audience to be human with us!

Movement lives and breathes in every visual media form. However, what we strive to do at ibc is emphasize the craft, the composition & the process. The human experience relies on dialogues (often spoken) to coexist, but by using motion as the primary expressive tool for a nonverbal dialogue we the audience, as well as the participants engage our perspective in a way of unparalleled beauty. Its graceful, its elegant, and simply a whole lot of fun to film.

Our approach to creating this work:

Anne Bogart wrote; “You cannot expect other people to create meaning for you. You cannot wait for someone else to define your life. You make meaning by forging it with your hands. It requires sweat and commitment. Working toward the creation of meaning is the point. it is action that forges the meaning and the significance of a life.”

This is something that guides us in our process and gives us the courage as young artists to take action towards this project.  The rehearsal process is an investigative series of workshops dealing heavily in character development and improvisational exercises- this allows each artist to be personally invested in the final product and lets it grow organically allowing room for significant synergies.

We need your support!

The process is underway, and choreographing and conceptualizing this show collaboratively is very exciting for all of us, and we need a little “collaboration” from you in order to produce this dance for film as well as for the premiere June 5 and 6th at Center for Performance Research. So please help us reach our financial goal, everything counts, and all your donations are tax-deductible!

Your money will go towards

-Renting the performance venue and rehearsal space

-Renting additional sound film equipment

-Costume and set design

-Event insurance

-Marketing our show

-Paying our technical staff

   

                     and last but not least

              -Making meaningful art!

If you are unable to donate you can still help by:

    -Sharing our campaign with people you know
    -Recommend indieballet collaborative to your friends on facebook! (www.facebook.com/indieballetcollaborative)
    -Coming to see the show!!!

You cannot wait for someone else to define your life. You make meaning by forging it with your hands. It requires sweat and commitment. Working toward the creation of meaning is the point. it is action that forges the meaning and the significance of a life.”This is something that guides us in our process and gives us the courage as young artists to take action towards this project.  The rehearsal process is an investigative series of workshops dealing heavily in character development and improvisational exercises- this allows each artist to be personally invested in the final product and lets it grow organically allowing room for significant synergies.We need your support!The process is underway, and choreographing and conceptualizing this show collaboratively is very exciting for all of us, and we need a little “collaboration” from you in order to produce this dance for film as well as for the premiere June 5 and 6th at Center for Performance Research. So please help us reach our financial goal, everything counts, and all your donations are tax-deductible!Your money will go towards

-Renting the performance venue and rehearsal space
-Renting additional sound film equipment
-Costume and set design
-Event insurance
-Marketing our show
-Paying our technical staff
    
                     and last but not least
              -Making meaningful art!
If you are unable to donate you can still help by:    -Sharing our campaign with people you know    -Recommend indieballet collaborative to your friends on facebook! (www.facebook.com/indieballetcollaborative)    -Coming to see the show!!!

story:
The Company:

Rocha Dance Theater is a Brooklyn-based dance company led by artistic director, Jenny Rocha.  RDT's work ranges from contemporary dance to  vaudeville inspired dance. Rocha has created over 50 works and 10 evening-length productions for her company since 2001.  Her choreography has been presented by numerous venues in New York City such as Danspace Project, Joyce Soho, LaMama ETC, Galapagos Art Space, 92nd Street Y and more. Currently, Jenny is a resident artist at Galapagos Art Space in DUMBO Brooklyn where her vaudeville dance group "Jenny Rocha & Her Painted Ladies" performs weekly as part of their "Floating Kabarette".  As an artist, she is dedicated to creating provocative dance that is both artistic and entertaining, with a wide appeal to general audiences. 

New York Times:

"a beauty in her clear bold way, her face nakedly revealing fierce self-confidence and vulnerability"

"authoritative work...evokes strong emotion physically". 

The NEW Production:

The company is currently working on a new multi-media production, "Mandorla", which will debut in May of 2011 at LaMama ETC's Ellen Stewart Theater in NYC.  Rocha is choreographing/ directing and designing costumes for 5 principal dancers and a chorus of nine.  Collaborations involved in this production include live music by a 5 piece band and video design by Joseph Rivas.  Principal dancers include: Jillian Hollis, Lesley Garrison, Molly Merkler and Jamie Graham.  Chorus dancers include: Stephanie Franck, Karesia Batan, Andrea Mathias, Karina Mudd, Sarah Walkowicz, Alisa Fendley, Amy Hessler, Katherine Moore, Stephanie Lane & Darlisa G. Wajid-Ali.

"Mandorla" is a symbolic production that speaks boldly of a society of performers looking for work.  Using dance, satire, character development, video design and live music, Mandorla will give audiences a vicarious experience of these performers vulnerable, competitive world.  How far will these performers go to survive?   What are they willing to give up, barter, manipulate, sell?   What is self value?  How much are they themselves worth?  Using wit as a weapon, this show will entertain and simultaneously serve as a thought provoking commentary on the present time.


What this campaign will FUND:

This fund-raising campaign is dedicated solely to paying the principal performers in the production.  The funds will go towards paying them a performance fee and a rehearsal stipend for 25 weeks of rehearsal.  Please help the dancers receive the minimum compensation they truly deserve. 

This will be a truly amazing experience!  I hope you will be part of it.

story:
Hi there, 

Thanks for looking at my page! 

Im Tom, and this is my campaign; 

I’ve been lucky enough to be asked to join the National Youth Theatre REP Scheme. I will be 1 of just 15 training for the next 9 months in collaboration with the National Theatre, BBC, Royal Shakespeare Company and Wildworks. 

The NYT REP is an epic, vocational, industry based program. 

The National Youth Theatre currently consists of more than 3000 members; over 200 members were selected to be auditioned for the REP, 40 were then recalled, and Tom has been accepted. 

While my commitment to my career is total, I am relocating to London from the West-Country and my self sufficient financial circumstances cannot support me through this incredible opportunity. 

Any questions please ask, or send to tomcprior@gmail.com 

“The NYT REP is amazing, it could completely turn acting training on its head.” 

- Michael Grandage -

 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

What I Need

I begin working with the REP from 2nd April 2013 and I will be training up to 50 hours a week and I am now seeking sponsorship to help me fund my time with the REP. 

You can donate any amount you wish, you dont have to stick to the suggestions on the side! There's a few perks to the side > to get you going.

I've budgeted a target of £5,000. I have a part time job to work at the weekends to contribute to my outgoings. I have opened a specific account “Tom Prior NYT REP 2013”, so rest assured this money will be used solely to cover my time with the REP. If you would consider sponsoring me I would be utterly grateful.

“The NT are really delighted to be involved with the NYT REP.  The NYT have put together a terrific program of work, giving the Rep brilliant exposure to some of the best creative companies and individuals in the UK.” 

- Wendy Spon, Head of Casting at the National Theatre -

 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Biography 

Tom having gained 4 A-levels, 2 As Levels and 13 GCSEs at the Thomas Hardye School and Sixth Form, Dorset, where he directed and performed an original by Judith Johnson for the National Theatre Connections with performances in the Thomas Hardye Theatre and The Nuffield, Southampton. 

Tom was an actor for the Dorchester Youth Theatre, which he later went on to lead. 

He the joined Tenth Opinion theatre company in Dorset performing Bums on Seats (Michael Snelgrove) and Our Country's Good (Timberlake Wertenbaker).

He was then asked to join the National Youth Film Academy (NYFA) - Pilot Course, 2 Weeks of training, master classes and film making given at the BFI, Southbank in collaboration with Gareth Edwards [Monsters, Godzilla] , Iain Canning [The Kings Speech].

Short Films include; 

   -Alex was a Friend of Mine (Alex), Luckytown Productions; directed by Steven James

   -Royal and Sun Alliance; directed by Jake Warren. 

Tom assisted actor Chris New on his directorial debut short film, Ticking. 

Tom is a member of the National Youth Theatre (NYT) and a graduate of the

Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA) Foundation Course 2011-2012;

Performances include: Welcome to Thebes (Moira Buffini), Cymbeline, playing Posthumus, directed by Nick Hutchinson and Everyone's Doing It directed by Trilby James 

 Tom wrote his debut short "Breaking the Circle" earlier this year. 

 -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  

Tom is totally financially self reliant, and has always worked as hard as he can to make his dreams become a reality. He is so very grateful to his kind sponsors and benefactors to helped him attend the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, and got him to where he is today.  

 With your support you will be allowing Tom to complete this incredible opportunity, and allow him to follow his chosen career, which without financial assistance he will struggle fulfill.  

 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Perks 

If you fancy a little tipple, and would be so kind as to invest into Tom’s opportunity there are a few perks which may get you going.

 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

What People say about Tom

Tom's first acting teacher Richard Wheal said: 

“Tom is a very talented and very watchable performer... He is precise, disciplined and funny – when you watch him you can see him thinking his way through a performance.”

“In the big school shows...he absolutely shone.”

“He was always destined to succeed.”

“People liked watching him and being with him, he is a charismatic kind of person. The school was really pleased for him as RADA is probably the hardest acting school to get into.”

Hilary Over, said;

“a highly creative and talented...sensitive and supportive...Tom’s commitment is exemplary. He is utterly determined and ...with an affable and winning manner.”

“Tom directed...the school’s production of Jesus Christ Superstar which was recognised as by far the best school production we have staged.”

“Tom was very happy to share his expertise and has run, in a voluntary capacity, Dorchester Youth Theatre...with a range of ages and challenging students.” 

 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Other Ways You Can Help

I need YOU. 

Please share this page through Facebook, Twitter and the share setting on Indigogo!

Twitter: @tcprior

Facebook: facebook.com/tomcprioractor

 

For Further Reference; 

http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/9205751.Future_s_looking_bright_for_prospective_RADA_student_TOM/

http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/9178742.Former_Thomas_Hardye_pupil_accepted_by_RADA/

 

http://www.thisisdorset.co.uk/Harpist-concert/story-13154025-detail/story.html#axzz2NFYkSEhf

 

http://buzz.bournemouth.ac.uk/aspiring-actor-accepted-at-rada/

 

http://www.dorchesterdorset.com/event.php?eventID=593

 

http://www.viewfrompublishing.co.uk/news_view/13198/15/1/dorchester-the-final-chapter-of-combined

story:
We Are...

Kristine Haruna Lee, Stevo Arnoczy, Sasha Arutyunova, Andrew Butler, and Lauren Swan-Potras and we are putting up a brand new play titled Plum de Force at the highly acclaimed Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn as part of the Propeller Project Series this fall 2013.

We are so grateful for any contribution you can make, big or small, because with your generous support this collaboration will be able to reach its full potentials, and the play will truly soar! 

 

Plum de Force

Bushwick Starr September 5-8 at 8pm

 

Written and Directed by: Kristine Haruna Lee

Stage Manager: Maggie Yeomans

Costumes by: Karen Boyer and Bevan Dunbar

Lights by: Sarah Lurie

Set by: Greg Laffey

Original Music Composed by: Kathryn Hathaway

Sound by: Mike De Angelis

Projection Design by: Stevo Arnoczy

Photo Design by: Sasha Arutyunova

 

Starring: Stevo Arnoczy, Andrew Butler, Matt Carr, NicHi Douglas, Jo Lampert, Anastasia Olowin, Cyndi Perzcek, Julia Sirna-Frest, Lauren Swan-Potras, Chinaza Uche and Marisa Lark Wallin.

 

What the Plum it's all about...

Johnny is a farmer who can talk to plums. He’s also in love with one, too. When the illicit affair becomes a public scandal, the adulterous plum and her sisters receive their grim sentence- plucked and sent to an ultra-chic supermarket, which, from their perspective, is a Berlin Night Club full of lights, music, plastics, pesticides, and not to mention, some dangerous looking fruit. A psychedelic trip offered by one dubious apple sends the plums to a circus in Calcutta (of all places), where bread and butter sing, a bag of sugar sweet talks, and a courtroom waits to cast their final verdict. 

 

The play follows the life cycle of five plums who are also witches: from tree, to being plucked, to supermarket, to being peeled. Each segment of the cycle is brought to life through the exploration of their landscape as imagined to be experienced by the plums themselves. This tragic journey of fruit following their inevitable fate as part of the greater food chain also historically mirrors the sense of calamity that was prevalent during the early 16th century witch-hunts and trials. The tree then becomes a space of home, rootedness, and of deep spiritual connection to nature, where, on the flip side, the supermarket becomes a space of artifice and trial: where lights, music, plastic, pesticide and the introduction of other foreign produce becomes a whole other daze for the plums to contend with. 

 

Your Contribution...

Your contribution will help us buy the materials we need to build the set and costumes. Most importantly, we'll be able to rent some extra rehearsal space and compensate our insanely talented artists and collaborators. 

 

"Kristine is a bright authentic theater star (truly) and anyone who encounters her work would be hard pressed not to find themselves opening up to new possibilities and falling in love." - Taylor Mac

story:
(NB: This Indiegogo was originally set up here http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/harry-my-cat-died-the-tour/x/3671392 - but my fat fingers made the deadline the 21st June instead of the 21st July. So, here it is again, minus the sum raised in the first one. However, Indiegogo have now made it so the deadline is 10th July. I've honestly no clue what the hell is going on.)

What IS Harry, My Cat Died?

Harry, My Cat Died is a twitter account which focuses on the weird world of One Direction fans. Because, for some reason, teenagers feel the need to tweet Harry whenever their cat dies. Over the year collating info, we have also discovered that fans are willing to write episode ballads, tweet during funerals and even pretend that their own parents are dead just for attention from the band. Yeesh.

What is Harry, My Cat Died: The Tour?

The stages of grief are many. When coping with the loss of a close one, some people get emotional. Others seek comfort in religion. Sometimes, people turn to drink. Others like to tell Harry out of One Direction.
Join Professor Stephen Frizzle from the Harry, My Cat Died Research Centre as he presents the results and findings of a year-long psychological study. Who are these "Directioners" who devote their time in trying to get Styles' attention? Why does Harry ...need to know when there is a dead cat in the world? Is sending a photo of your just-then dead grandma really an effective tool in getting Harry to like you? And just how scary IS a cactus?

All these questions and more will be reviewed, studied and hopefully answered in HARRY, MY CAT DIED.

Harry, My Cat Died is a one-off Free Fringe show based on the Twitter account, @HarryMyCatDied, written and presented by its creator. Monday August 12th at 4.45pm. Bashee Labyrinth Cinema, Niddrey Street, Edinburgh. It's a one off show...

... but it doesn't have to be.

With your help, Harry My Cat Died can get his word out there. The problem is that travel expenses are ridiculous these days. This is where you can help. And, look! Rewards in return! How delightful.

From October 2013 onwards, the staff of Harry, My Cat Died plan to tour the UK with their warnings about cat death and singing haircuts.

So how can you help?

I want to take this show to as many places as possible. At the moment, I have confirmed dates for Newcastle, Liverpool and London - but travel is quite a problem. With petrol and train prices rising by the house, it's turning out that some of the venues are cheaper to hire than they are to travel there. There's also a lot of technology involved in the show, and I'd need a few helpers to travel with me and assist with that. All the funds raised will only go on travel and hiring staff to help out during the tour.

Another main risk with this project is that if parents find out what cat-killing haircut-worshipping cult their children have signed up to, they will blame me. This cannot happen. I WILL NOT LET THIS HAPPEN. The truth will out.

story:
In 2005, The Man Who Laughs, Stolen Chair's live silent film for the stage premiered to sold-out houses and rave reviews.  NYtheatre.com called it "a triumph...[a] bona fide tour de force of theatre," and Trav SD, author of Chain of Fools: Silent Comedy and Its Legacies from Nickelodeons to Youtube, called it "Utterly tremendous!"  Now, in celebration of the 10th anniversary of our founding, Stolen Chair is bringing this innovative piece back to NYC this February in a brand new, completely reinvisioned production.

About The Man Who Laughs

In The Man Who Laughs, six live actors transport the audience to a movie house in 1923, when glamorous stars told larger-than-life stories without a single spoken word. Grab a bag of freshly popped popcorn, take a seat, and watch the hilarious and heartrending story of Gwynplaine, a clown whose face has been surgically disfigured into a permanent smile. Performing with his adoptive sister and father, Gwynplaine gains fame and a very modest fortune for his comic acts-and his comical face. Secretly he yearns to be more than a freak and a joke-but when his yearning leads him into the arms of a debauched duchess fascinated by grin, the results are disastrous for Gwynplaine and for his family.

Based on Victor Hugo's novel The Man Who Laughs, the play is performed in the style of a silent film, complete with live piano accompaniment, projected title cards, and a vibrant black-and-white set. The Man Who Laughs transforms silent film into live action, taking us back to a time when performers didn't need to speak to pull on our heart strings and tickle our funny bones.

Why we are asking for your help...

As a 10 year old company, we've gotten pretty darn good at managing our limited resources to create challenging and delightful original works of theatre.  Through in-kind donations of materials and labor and a little old-fashioned ingenuity, we've found a way to reduce our overall budget to a mere fraction of its original size.    The good news?  We've already secured that sum through past box office returns, generous donations, and support from the New York State Council on the Arts.  The bad news?  We had to sacrifice elements from the marketing, staff, and materials budgets in order to bring our overall budget down so low.
 
The show's gonna go on no matter what!  We've made sure we've got enough to pay our bills and our artists.  But, with your help, we can make sure:
  • That our marketing can reach people who've never heard of us, bringing a new audience to this very special show ($1500) 
  • That the show is professionally staffed with house managers and stagehands, so the actors can devote their attention to acting, not to shuffling furniture around during the show ($750)
  • That our pianist is playing a real (freshly tuned) piano instead of a keyboard ($750) 
  • That we're projecting our title cards from a real, theatrical digital projector instead of the creaky and labor-intensive classroom overhead projector we used in 2005. ($1000)

That comes to $4000, just a fraction of the production's overall budget.  Think you can help us out?

What you get...

Our heartfelt gratitude AND...

Extra ($10): Your name in the lobby on a list of Indiegogo supporters

Comic Relief ($25): All the above AND a signed glossy of Gwynplaine

Character Actor ($50): All the above AND 1 free ticket to The Man Who Laughs

Romantic Lead ($100): All the above AND MP3 of The Man Who Laughs' original score by Eugene Ma

Mantinee Idol ($250): All the above AND 2 (in total) free tickets & a signed copy of Playing with Canons (a play anthology that includes the 2005 version of The Man Who Laughs, Ed. Martin Denton)

Big Shot Producer ($500): All the above AND 4 (in total) free tickets & backstage tour

Studio Mogul ($1000): All the above AND 8 (in total) free tickets and private Q&A with the creative team behind The Man Who Laughs

Other Ways You Can Help

Please SPREAD THE WORD:

Follow The Man Who Laughs on Facebook (Facebook.com/StolenChairTheManWhoLaughs), then share with all of your closest Facebook friends. 

Follow @StolenChairTC on twitter and tweet to your followers about how far their $10, $25, or $100 can go for #TheManWhoLaughs

Reblog our behind the scenes snapshots from our Tumblr blog: stolenchair.tumblr.com

Sign up for Stolen Chair's enews and forward it to everyone you know who loves theatre/silent film/victor hugo/the 1920s

Oh, and come to the show! Bring your friends!  Bring your family! Bring everyone!  TICKETS: http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&showCode=MAN41&BundleCode=&PackageCode=&GUID=9022ec41-9f25-471e-b174-5cde554c8866

THANK YOU!

And thank you to our fabulous cast and crew who continually inspire us to make this show even better: 

Written by Kiran Rikhye | Directed by Jon Stancato | Dramaturgy by Emily Otto | Music by Eugene Ma | Makeup by Jaclyn Schaefer with Stephanie Cox-Williams | Costume Design by Julie Schworm | Lighting Design by Daniel Winters | Set Design by Michael Minahan | Stage Management by Colin Miller | Props & Graphic Design by Aviva Meyer | Photos by Carrie Leonard | Publicity by Emily Owens

Featuring Raife Baker, Dave Droxler, Jon Froehlich, Molly O'Neill, Noah Schultz and Rebecca Whitehurst

Sincerely, 

The Chairs
story_txt:
In 2005, The Man Who Laughs, Stolen Chair's live silent film for the stage premiered to sold-out houses and rave reviews.  NYtheatre.com called it "a triumph...[a] bona fide tour de force of theatre," and Trav SD, author of Chain of Fools: Silent Comedy and Its Legacies from Nickelodeons to Youtube, called it "Utterly tremendous!"  Now, in celebration of the 10th anniversary of our founding, Stolen Chair is bringing this innovative piece back to NYC this February in a brand new, completely reinvisioned production.


About The Man Who Laughs

In The Man Who Laughs, six live actors transport the audience to a movie house in 1923, when glamorous stars told larger-than-life stories without a single spoken word. Grab a bag of freshly popped popcorn, take a seat, and watch the hilarious and heartrending story of Gwynplaine, a clown whose face has been surgically disfigured into a permanent smile. Performing with his adoptive sister and father, Gwynplaine gains fame and a very modest fortune for his comic acts-and his comical face. Secretly he yearns to be more than a freak and a joke-but when his yearning leads him into the arms of a debauched duchess fascinated by grin, the results are disastrous for Gwynplaine and for his family.
Based on Victor Hugo's novel The Man Who Laughs, the play is performed in the style of a silent film, complete with live piano accompaniment, projected title cards, and a vibrant black-and-white set. The Man Who Laughs transforms silent film into live action, taking us back to a time when performers didn't need to speak to pull on our heart strings and tickle our funny bones.


Why we are asking for your help...
As a 10 year old company, we've gotten pretty darn good at managing our limited resources to create challenging and delightful original works of theatre.  Through in-kind donations of materials and labor and a little old-fashioned ingenuity, we've found a way to reduce our overall budget to a mere fraction of its original size.    The good news?  We've already secured that sum through past box office returns, generous donations, and support from the New York State Council on the Arts.  The bad news?  We had to sacrifice elements from the marketing, staff, and materials budgets in order to bring our overall budget down so low.



 

The show's gonna go on no matter what!  We've made sure we've got enough to pay our bills and our artists.  But, with your help, we can make sure:


That our marketing can reach people who've never heard of us, bringing a new audience to this very special show ($1500) 




That the show is professionally staffed with house managers and stagehands, so the actors can devote their attention to acting, not to shuffling furniture around during the show ($750)




That our pianist is playing a real (freshly tuned) piano instead of a keyboard ($750) 




That we're projecting our title cards from a real, theatrical digital projector instead of the creaky and labor-intensive classroom overhead projector we used in 2005. ($1000)

That comes to $4000, just a fraction of the production's overall budget.  Think you can help us out?
What you get...
Our heartfelt gratitude AND...
Extra ($10): Your name in the lobby on a list of Indiegogo supporters
Comic Relief ($25): All the above AND a signed glossy of Gwynplaine
Character Actor ($50): All the above AND 1 free ticket to The Man Who Laughs
Romantic Lead ($100): All the above AND MP3 of The Man Who Laughs' original score by Eugene Ma
Mantinee Idol ($250): All the above AND 2 (in total) free tickets & a signed copy of Playing with Canons (a play anthology that includes the 2005 version of The Man Who Laughs, Ed. Martin Denton)
Big Shot Producer ($500): All the above AND 4 (in total) free tickets & backstage tour
Studio Mogul ($1000): All the above AND 8 (in total) free tickets and private Q&A with the creative team behind The Man Who Laughs




Other Ways You Can Help

Follow @StolenChairTC on twitter and tweet to your followers about how far their $10, $25, or $100 can go for #TheManWhoLaughs
Reblog our behind the scenes snapshots from our Tumblr blog: stolenchair.tumblr.com
