story:
Diamond Girls Stage Play and Documentary

The Diamond Girls Stage Play debut will be held on Saturday, November 3 at the Paul Robeson Theater here in Detroit, MI. There will be 2 shows...a 3:00pm Matinee and an 8:00pm main show.

Diamond Girls Synopsis

Charlene Diggs is 25 years old and has just married the love of her life, Marquis Diggs and they are expecting their first child. They have a brand new home, several successful businesses, and all the money they could ever want. There’s just one problem, Marquis, also known as “Hollywood”, is the boss of a major drug organization known as “The Brotherhood”. As Charlene contemplates the future of her family, especially her unborn child, she tries to convince her husband to give up the street lifestyle and to focus on their legitimate businesses. She explains that she fears for his safety and doesn’t want to raise their son by herself. But Hollywood’s drug organization is growing larger and larger and he explains to Charlene that he hears her but can’t get out of the business right then. On the night that Charlene goes into labor Hollywood is gunned down outside their home in an apparent drug hit.

 Five years later Charlene is a single mom, successful business owner, and a faithful member in her church, but she is worried about her girlfriends Portia, Keisha, and Stacey, who are dating Hollywood’s former lieutenants that are now the new bosses of The Brotherhood. She sets out to help them see that dating men in the street life is a dead end road that leads to loneliness, heartache, and even jail or death. The girls all hear what she’s saying but don’t really listen. 

 But little do they know that a perfect storm is brewing for The Brotherhood. An ongoing federal investigation, a budding street war with a rival dealer, and a very unlikely member of their organization who has become an informant for the feds, will all have severe consequences for not only the Brotherhood leadership, but also anyone connected to them, including the women who love them. 

 It’s a race against time as Charlene tries to convince her girlfriends to change their ways and abandon ship before the storm that’s brewing hits. Will she succeed? Find out as you witness this story of love, deception, danger, tragedy, and triumph. 

Who I Am

I am a Detroit based music producer, writer, and CEO of Soul Food Entertainment, LLC, an entertainment firm that specializes in all areas of media production and development. During my 20+ years in the entertainment business, I have worked with countless independent and major Gospel, Jazz, and R&B artists, either playing keyboards, producing, writing, or arranging for them. Some of my current and past clients include Dorinda Clark Cole, The 3x Grammy Award winning Clark Sisters, Fred Hammond, Warner Brothers Records, Sony/BMG Records, NBC, and EMI Records to name a few. In addition to music, my company is also developing several projects in the areas of TV, Film, Radio, as well as Fashion. Also, I have served as music director and/or production manager on several local and national stage plays, and am now stepping out with my own endeavor, which is the Diamond Girls project. I strongly believe that my years of creative and technical experience, along with a strong and experienced support team will be a major factor in the success of this project.

Why I'm Doing This Project

My desire for this project is not just to entertain, but to tell a story that hasn't been adequately told, and to deliver a message that I believe will help not only women, but also men think about the choices they make and how it affects those around them. The media paints such a glamorous and romantic picture of the street lifestyle when there's so much death and destruction attached to it. My desire is to remove the mask and show the lifestyle for what it really is...a life full of pain, disappointment, death, and lost and stolen dreams...and to show that it's never too late to change and turn things around for the better.

I NEED YOUR HELP!!!

In order to make this project happen I need you, yes YOU!!! The money you donate will go towards the production of the stage play, the documentary, and the soundtrack. We have already began production of the documentary and the soundtrack but need additional funds to complete them. Some of the expenses include:

  • Theater Rental
  • Lighting and Sound Rental
  • Cast and Crew (some actors and crew members will be volunteers and others will be paid professionals to ensure the quality of the production)
  • Marketing and Promotions (Fliers, Posters, TV and Radio Advertising, Street Team, Website Development)
  • Rehearsal Venue Rental
  • Set Design and Construction
  • Musicians
  • Video Crew (For the taping of the show)
  • Finishing Production of the Documentary (Filming, Editing, and Manufacturing)
  • Finishing Production of the CD Soundtrack (Recording, Mixing, Mastering, and Manufacturing)

For helping us with this endeavor there are several perks and benefits that I am offering, including play tickets, copies of the documentary and soundtrack, special seating at the play, as well as several perks not open to the public, such as behind the scenes footage of the production and entrance to some of the invite only events such as the Soundtrack Listening Party. A detailed list of the perks can be found on the right side of this page.

The Impact

I believe that this project will touch many lives and cause many to soul search and rethink their decisions, as well as make them laugh and be entertained. Eventually, this play will tour around the country as well as be turned into an actual full length feature film. I even plan to start a Diamond Girls non-profit organization that will help young women. But we must start somewhere and with your help we can start something that will be more than just a play, or a movie, or a soundtrack...we can start a Diamond Girls MOVEMENT!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

As you can see there are many differnt donation levels from great to small and every little bit helps and even if we don't make our $10,000 goal, whatever we get will be a blessing to this project. But in addition to finances, I need you to SPREAD THE WORD!!! Send the link to this campaign to all your Facebook friends, Twitter followers, Linked In contacts, email contacts, etc. Indiegogo has made it easy to share the link...so even if you're not in a position to donate, please help me get the word out about this project!!!

Thank you and God Bless.

As you can see there are many differnt donation levels from great to small and every little bit helps and even if we don't make our $10,000 goal, whatever we get will be a blessing to this project. But in addition to finances, I need you to SPREAD THE WORD!!! Send the link to this campaign to all your Facebook friends, Twitter followers, Linked In contacts, email contacts, etc. Indiegogo has made it easy to share the link...so even if you're not in a position to donate, please help me get the word out about this project!!!
Thank you and God Bless.

story:
We are Monday Night Productions, a not-for-profit company operating under The Field.  We believe in creating paid opportunities for theatre artists and working with a diverse group of professionals. We are primarily a donation-based company. The contributions of others have allowed us to extend our working base to include actors, directors, designers and theatre technicians of varying ages and experience.  It is our philosophy that professional-grade theatre can be produced in the city with a wealth of “undiscovered” talent and the generosity of donors.  Every dollar contributed not only funds this current production but also insures the continuation of this small company’s growth and our future productions.

Our hope is to raise $2000.00, which will be combined with past donations to help us cover productions costs for "Sight Unseen."  Every donor becomes part of the Monday Night Productions Family and has the choice to be notified of future productions, discounts and auditions.  In addition to raising funds, we’re also looking to expand our company’s community.  To get involved or for more information, please e-mail the producers akyzer@yahoo.com and Maurya.scanlon@gmail.com. Many thanks!

story:
Here is a breakdown of my summer thus far. Things keep sprouting up, so I will continue to up date this info:

May22: I hit the road on my Motorcycle and travel towards Nashville Tennessee

May 24: Lecture Demonstration of my newest version of 11 in Nashville, Tennessee

May 25: Set out for NorthHampton, Massechusettes 

May 28: Teach Master Class in Urban Fusion 

May 29: Teach Community Workshop in Urban Fusion

May 30: Teach Master Class in Urban Fusion

June 1/2: Perform 11 Spring Wide Open presented by Wire Monkey Dance

June 3: Set off for Montreal Canada

June 4-10: Work with Danielle Russo's company for a performance at Jacob's Pillow

June 11: Head for Chicago, IL

June 15: Set New Work on the Joel Hall Dancers

June 31: Head for Durham, NC

July 1-10: Set solo on Iowa Performer Amanda Hamp

July18-28: Participate in New Waves Festival in Trinidad

August 1: Perform with the Danilelle Russo Dance Company at Jacob's Pillow

August 2: Head back to Chicago

August 5-15: Teach workshop in Chicago, IL

As you can see there are many communties that I will come into contact with. Please help me get to these destinations and make this be one moving experience after another. Thank you in advance. Peace

story:
Who We Are

Concrete Vertigo Productions is a production company that was founded in 2010 with the goal of producing Las Vegas style burlesque musicals. All Singing, All Dancing and All Sexy. The show revolves around - what else? - Brothers Grimm fairy tales - but with a sexy, contemporary twist.

Grimm Girls will be our third and most ambitious production yet. We aim to do something different and unique within the Vancouver theatre scene. The fusing of traditional musical theatre with the art of Burlesque is not only exciting but brings different kinds of artists together under one roof.

The production team includes co-directors Dawn Ewen (also choreographing) and Mike Kovac, Musical Director Maddison Popov, Sound Designer David Kovac, Producer/Writer Cameron Chase and co-producers Sable Strub and Rosie Simon. The supremely talented cast includes Jacqueline Breakwell (pulling double duty as our costume designer) Sable Strub, Rosie Simon, Ranae Miller, Jeremy O'Driscoll, Mike Kovac, Ryan Bolton, Megan Solis, Ben Bilodeau, Emily Kapahi, Javia Selina, Alex Gullason, Jennifer Doan, Lauren Gula, Stephanie Liotopoulos, Kate MacQueen, Nilsen Tiefenbach and Dimitrios Stephanoy.

The Show 

Grimm Girls aims to not only be a show, but an experience where the worlds of Burlesque and Musical Theatre fuse to create a sexy, hilarious romp in which classic Brothers Grimm fables collide. The world created will be familliar yet surprising, filled with well known characters being updated to a sexy, contemporary twist. We guarantee you have never seen Snow White, Cinderella, Red Riding Hood and the Evil Queen quite like this before.

What We Need & What You Get

As this is our most ambitious production to date, we are in need of a bit more funding than usual. Our large cast of 18 will be performing in the PAL Theatre in downtown Vancouver, which of course costs money, as do elaborate sets and gorgeous costumes (sequins cost a lot of money!)

Every penny from you backers counts towards making this production the best it can be. In exchange for your kind and generous hearts, you will receive a variety of perks. Among said perks are advanced tickets, good karma, signed posters of the cast and even the possibility of a Producer's credit! Let's be honest, who wouldn't like to throw around the "yeah, I produced theatre" gloat? 

The Impact

Grimm Girls is not our first, not our second, but our third show based in Vancouver. Our first two productions, Ruby Red Burlesque and Lost Girls of Neverland, were classic tales turned on their sides (and spanked) for a new audience. Both were big hits and sold out both their runs.

When Ruby Red Burlesque was produced, we never imagined that the public would respond with such enthusiasm and support. We tried to one up ourselves with Lost Girls of Neverland, and we succeeded! Now, with Grimm Girls, we are aiming to prove that the best things come in threes. 

There are other ways you can help if you cannot contribute money to our production. Sharing this page and getting the word out to friends, family and social networks is just as fantastic and something we appreciate with all our hearts.

story:
"All Alone Together"

Spartan Theatre Company presents a series of performance art one-man shows all tied together in one show. Featuring artists from the Chicago and New York performance art scene, we will bring you a night of discovery, wit, and recollection.

"In a night of hilarious and thought-provoking performance art, Chicago artists come together to deliver three separate stories of film, identity, and childhood. Featuring Joseph Galizia's “Cocaine Cinema”, Brendan Meyer's “White Ghost”, and Kestutis Nakas' “Remembrance of Things Pontiac”. Come join an evening of discovery, wit, and recollection."

Funding

Any and all funds will go towards our rent, costumes, props, and advertising for the production. Every dollar goes towards a better and more complete production that will reach to a farther and wider audience.

What this does

With this production, we hope to bring performance art to those who haven't had the opportunity to see professional, well-written, and accessible one-man shows. By funding the production we will continue our drive to bring quality and successful theatre as we have in the past with shows such as "Talk Radio" and "Train of Thought".

For more information

Check out http://www.spartantheatre.org/

story:
Look out world: Rubenesque Burlesque is about to shake things up internationally! Your absolute favorite troupe of round and rowdy rump shakers have been selected to perform at the 5th annual Toronto Burlesque Festival with a number that promises to shake up the neo-burlesque scene.


But in order for us to sock it to 'em like only Rubenesque Burlesque can, we are reaching out to the community for a helping hand. We would be honored for any assistance our fans can provide, be it getting the word out or sponsoring one of your favorite fat gals' airfare to Canada!

Help us get our round rumps to Canada, eh!!!



RUBENESQUEBURLESQUE.COM

story:
"Pit" explores the relationships that were made and broken during the 1984 miners strike in South Wales, a turbulent time that has left a scar on the Welsh valleys for generations to come.

A word about us:

Long View Theater Company believes in honestly portraying the human condition with compassion and humor.  We want to inspire audiences and give voice to original points of view. We believe theater can provoke thoughtful discussion by portraying the powerful movements, harsh situations, and myriad of inter-connections that end up defining people’s lives.  Through this portrayal, we gain understanding of ourselves and our own stories.

"Pit" is exactly one of these stories - "Pit" tells the story of a mining community in Wales shaken by the effects of the 1984 miners strike as it brings the best and the worst out of this tight-knit community. Exploring how these people cope with adversity through laughter and camaraderie and the lengths to which they will go to survive.

Your generous contributions will allow us to tell this story. Your donation will go directly to creating this production, covering the cost of the theater rental for three weeks, rehearsal time and space, paying the actors, set and costume design.  Every penny that you donate will go directly into the production.

We are very proud and excited to be producing this project, and hope that you can join us on this journey from page to stage.

And as they say in Wales -

Diolch am eich cefnogaeth!

---

CATRIN
It’s illegal you know. What the government are doing. You know, stopping the
benefits of striking miners families and all.
VAL
Don’t be soft love, it’s not illegal if the governments doing it - they make the bloody law.

story:
This Fall 2012, at Rapier Wit, Canada's oldest stage combat school and production company, I hope to attend their Advanced Combat Certification Program, which runs from the beginning of September until the end of the year just before the holidays.

A little bit about Rapier Wit:

Based in Toronto, ON, it was founded in 1991 by Daniel Levinson, establishing its first permanent studio in 1996.  Rapier Wit’s goal is "to promote action-motivated theatre and the art of stage combat by training actors, stunt people, directors, and stage management in the art of theatrical violence."

Disciplines include broadsword and shield, advanced smallsword, rapier and companion, eastern martial arts weapons, and found weapons.  Successful completion of this workshop would result in advanced recognition by Fight Directors Canada, a nonprofit educational entity dedicated to the education, development, advancement, and proficiency of action-oriented entertainment.

I've already secured a place to stay, brainstormed travel expenses, and am working to apply towards a work visa, so that living expenses (yay debt!) suddenly don't become impossible to support.

The only problem is: the workshop cost is just out of my reach.  I might be able to secure enough work to cover both the cost of living as well as the program, but the truth of the matter is, I don't think I can afford the training on my own.  That's where you come in.

The cost of the program is just a little under $2000, so I thought I'd round up to give the project goal a nice even number.  The money you would be pledging would just go straight to tuition, anything extra would go into the Coffee & Donut Fund (food for this surprisingly metabolistic petite).

The success of this campaign would not only mean a chance to go to Toronto and train with these fantastic individuals, but also a chance to see what the theatrical and cinematic community is like in the New York of the North.

Help put this American girl in Toronto.  Thank you for all your support in advance!

Cheers,
-A

 

http://www.fdc.ca
http://www.rapierwit.com

story:
Thank you to everyone who donated to our campaign and came to see the show! Through our efforts on Indiegogo, personal emails, and letters, we were able to meet our goal and have a fantastic run of Savage in Limbo! 
Your support means the world, truly! This project never would have happened without YOU. 
See you soon, 
Kim Dillon

-------------------------------------

Short Summary

DOGFACE Theatricals was created out of a need to explore strong political, social and emotional content. We want to talk about subjects you may not know about or are difficult to digest. Our mission is to take the themes of every piece we produce and match it to an organization that could benefit from it, whether by charitable donation or other outreach. 

This campaign is in support of our very first production - "Savage in Limbo" by John Patrick Shanley ("Doubt", "Moonstruck").  The issues in the character's lives are universal: loneliness, fear, wanting more out of your life and choosing whether to take a risk to create a better one. 

We will be donating a portion of every sold ticket to PerScholas. Located in the Bronx, PerScholas is a national nonprofit organization that breaks the cycle of poverty by providing technology education, access, training and job placement services for people in low-income communities.

By donating to this project, you will help us break ground on a company which will be dedicated to putting out material that is relevant to the human experience, no matter how difficult it may be to face. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The funding we need goes specifically to the performance rental of the Parkside Lounge, our rehearsal studio space, the pay given to every actor and crew member of the production, costumes (leather pants for Tony!), royalties, marketing (including postcards and mailings to our potential audience and members of the industry), Set design (specifically the bar that's being made exclusively for our production), Props (Santa Suit for Murk, bar glasses, beverages), and Insurance among many others...

We want you involved in the success of this project. With each donation level you receive the opportunity for priority booking to see the show, free tickets, video updates on our rehearsal and production progress, show dedications, invites to rehearsals and signed programs! Because we are a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, your donation (at any level) will be tax deductible. 

If we don't reach our goal the show will go on, but we'll be really in debt and that's no way to start a business that cares about our community and the world at large. Every penny that we do earn will go to making sure that we get all the rehearsal that the director and actors need to make sure they are prepared and performing at the best of their ability and that the Parkside Lounge venue is paid. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate monetarily right now, we totally understand. Please consider forwarding this campaign to your friends, relatives, business associates...anyone who believes in theatre, in art, and making a difference through creative pursuits.

Indieogogo makes it super easy to share and we encourage you to do so!

Thank You so much for your time and for reading. 

All the very best, 

Kim Dillon, Producer at DOGFACE Theatricals

story:
Short Summary

Tarzana Elementary School has no funding for drama, leaving the kids with little or no theatrically creative outlet. We are reaching out to all of you who understand how important it is to keep imagination alive in the minds of young kids.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $1500 in order to offer ten children partial scholarships for our after-school program and then have $500 left over for costumes, props, a set and theatre equipment.
 
If we raise more than our goal, that extra money will go toward future years and developing a drama program within the school, in hopes of making theatre even more available to the students.
 
What do you get? There aren't many things we can offer as far as "perks" go, we're still working on those, but you can totally get our undying love and gratitude...and the knowledge that there is a wonderfully creative child out there thanking you for the ability to delve into imagination. :)

The Impact

Theatre promotes creativity and imagination, which are some of the most important parts of growing up. It allows children to grow, build confidence and expand their critical thinking outside of the normal "box." Without creativity and imagination, things like the internet, movies, the computer, and even major breakthroughs in science would not have been or continue to be possible.

Kids need to be allowed to use their imaginations and encouraged to grow in a creative space, so offering ten children partial scholarships for the program would open doors for some students for whom this may not have been an option for in the past. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we understand. These are tough times, but we'd love for you to put a blast out on your facebook page, send an email to someone you know, or just tell someone about our campaign.


If you work in theatre or the entertainment industry and can donate time or equipment, please shoot me an email: alyssa.appleton@gmail.com

 

You all are amazing, and we thank you for your endless love and support on this project.

story:
Our Story

The RST proudly brings newly re-imagined classics to  unusual spaces and diverse audiences. In order to do so, we depend on the support of those invaluable collaborators who stand with us in pushing the dialog of the theatre into public space and the public 
consciousness.

The Impact

In 2011, the RST expands to Manhattan, where we will be working on a multi-floor, site-specific production of Hamlet in conjunction with the Tank for their first-ever Theater at the Tank series.  


We are simultaneously launching an educational outreach with a series of workshops entitled "Classical Relevance: Old Stuff and Why It Matters," where we partner with NYC schools to bring Shakespeare to after-school programs and students in Brooklyn and other boroughs.  With the money we raise, we hope to provide free tickets and talkbacks for students who want to delve deeper into the world of Shakespeare, and continue developing relationships with students interested in classical work to foster a new generation of innovative classical theater.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Thumb Biters ($1-$10) Buys us an hour of rehearsal space, bottles of water, a yard of cloth, copies of Hamlet.        Signed Program from the Cast 
  • Steel-Stained Profaners ($10-$50) Pays for a weeknight rehearsal,sends us to a school to do a workshop          Signed RST memorabilia AND Tickets to our March fundraiser at Galapagos
  • Enemies to the Peace ($50-$100)  Pays for a costume, buys copies of Hamlet for our whole cast, funds ten free student tickets to one of our show Signed RST memorabilia, Two tickets to our March fundraiser at Galapagos,  Personal Letter from a Subject
  • Kings of Cats ($100 or more) - We can pay our actors, fund another show at Lefferts House, sponsor a whole class of kids to come to our show and take a workshop with the cast Signed Program and Company Photo, Two Free Tickets to a Show of Choice, Two Free Tickets to the Obstacle as Opportunity Fundraiser and Letter from the Artistic Directors

Other Ways You Can Help


SPREAD THE WORD! Start the dialogue.  Post the video on your Facebook, on your Twitter.  Go to our website. Like our Facebook page. Post a news story about Hamlet.  Re-post if you agree with what we say. Tape yourself reading Hamlet and send it to us. Start the dialogue. Buy a ticket to our show. Come to our fundraiser. Send us an old television for our multimedia show. Send us an old camera. Join the rebellion. Tell your friends. Tell us about the production you've always wanted to see. Send us an email. Invite us to your school to talk about Shakespeare. Host a Shakespeare reading at your local bar. Write a sonnet.  Read a sonnet. Donate clothing for costumes. Post our website to your facebook profile. Get five friends to donate a dollar.  Donate a dollar.  Donate ten dollars. Bring five friends to our show. Spread the word. Start the dialogue. Join the rebellion.

story:
Our Story

Kansas has a reputation... and it's not a good one. Whether it's the topic of evolution or the arts, we've gotten a lot of bad press. It's our firm belief that lack of artistic opportunity in the state of Kansas will lead to another generation of boring, selfish, television watchers. Kansas needs to make opportunities to learn a creative skill - and that's where the Kansas Improvisation Foundation comes in.


The KIF will create opportunities for the people of Kansas to be exposed to the many varieties of improvisational acting. KIF will use its funds to give scholarships to take improv classes, to bring in outstanding teachers from other cities, and to provide classes and performances to areas with no other access to this kind of art form.


The KIF is just getting started, and needs funding to make its launch official - that means it needs 501(c)3 status to be able to apply for grants and other help.


Don't let the forces of evil win. Help spread the fun and skill of improv all over the state of Kansas!

What We Need

In order to obtain 501(c)3 status, we need $20 to file in the state of Kansas as a non-profit. We need $400 to file with the IRS, and we need $100 for the legal fees and fund-raising charges to help make this happen. We're made up of current improv professionals that want to see the art grow, and are helping out with their talents and resources.


Other Ways You Can Help

No matter how much you're able to give (even zero...), you can help out this great cause by sharing the campaign with others you know that love improv, art, acting, and stopping the flow of ignorance. Every little bit will help make this organization a reality! Use the share tools on this site, post it on Facebook, print it out and mail it to your elderly relatives. Let's make some noise!

story:
Our Story

As two theatre professionals living, working and raising families here in Peekskill, Katie Schmidt Feder and Sol Miranda found ourselves dreaming of a journey:  We had both left NYC several years ago, put some of our artistic aspirations on hold to raise young families, to create homes and to find a community.  Peekskill inspires us with its diversity, its energy, its tenacity.  The strong presence of artists here and the studios and galleries which support visual artists are a great asset to the city.

During our time in this area, however, working in various capacities as directors, performers and arts instructors – it has become obvious that Peekskill lacks a true home for its performing artist community.  Despite the beautiful renovation of the Paramount Theatre, the venue lacks wing space, fly space, suitable dressing rooms, a scenic or costume shop or rehearsal/studio capacity and hosts a house too large for intimate or experimental productions.

For this reason, we came to the decision one year ago to embark on a journey of research, outreach and fundraising with the ultimate goal of creating a performing and literary arts home in Peekskill.   We have met with city officials, the Chamber Director, local businesses, community members and several performing arts groups from Peekskill and surrounding communities, many who seek a permanent home for their companies.

 

To bring greater awareness to our endeavor, demonstrate our abilities to gather, produce and organize, as well as hopefully inspire, entertain and bring many people to our wonderful downtown businesses, we have proposed PEESKILL's FIRST FALL PERFORMING ARTS FESTIVAL. 

The Impact

We need to raise $2,000 by mid-August to combine with our other sponsorships, to move forward with this Festival.

 

We want to demonstrate to the community, to possible donors, foundations as well as the City adminstration of Peekskill and surrounding communities that Peekskill can and will support a lively performing arts scene. 
(Also, we hope that others will support us from afar!)

 

This festival will in many ways be a preview of the scene we hope to create in our facility once developed.  This facility would house 2-3 theatres of varying size from a very small 75 seat intimate theatre/lecture hall to a larger expiramental space that could double as an creative event facility.  We would also have rehearsal rooms, practice/music lesson rooms, shared set and costume shops and storage, writing rooms, a children's craft and sewing room,  a gallery, perhaps a cafe and small retail shops. 

 

By supporting this festival, you are supporting the ultimate vision of the space. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

With the $2,000 earned from this campaign, we can do the following:

 

  • Secure the booking of the show which will anchor to our festival, LA CUCARACHITA MARTINA, a family puppet rock 'n roll musical in Spanish and English by Teatro Sea from New York City.   Your contribution will ensure that this quality production will be accessable and affordable to children in our community and will bring all families in the commmunity together. 

 

  • Pay for marketing and promotional materials for the festival, creating postcards and advertisements.  This will help us continue our outreach, to make sure we do reach all segments of our community.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Share this with anyone who loves or who loves theatre, dance, music, writing, reading, crafts, sewing and all other art forms!
story_txt:
Our Story
As two theatre professionals living, working and raising families here in Peekskill, Katie Schmidt Feder and Sol Miranda found ourselves dreaming of a journey:  We had both left NYC several years ago, put some of our artistic aspirations on hold to raise young families, to create homes and to find a community.  Peekskill inspires us with its diversity, its energy, its tenacity.  The strong presence of artists here and the studios and galleries which support visual artists are a great asset to the city. 
During our time in this area, however, working in various capacities as directors, performers and arts instructors – it has become obvious that Peekskill lacks a true home for its performing artist community.  Despite the beautiful renovation of the Paramount Theatre, the venue lacks wing space, fly space, suitable dressing rooms, a scenic or costume shop or rehearsal/studio capacity and hosts a house too large for intimate or experimental productions. 
For this reason, we came to the decision one year ago to embark on a journey of research, outreach and fundraising with the ultimate goal of creating a performing and literary arts home in Peekskill.   We have met with city officials, the Chamber Director, local businesses, community members and several performing arts groups from Peekskill and surrounding communities, many who seek a permanent home for their companies.
 
To bring greater awareness to our endeavor, demonstrate our abilities to gather, produce and organize, as well as hopefully inspire, entertain and bring many people to our wonderful downtown businesses, we have proposed PEESKILL's FIRST FALL PERFORMING ARTS FESTIVAL.  

The Impact
We need to raise $2,000 by mid-August to combine with our other sponsorships, to move forward with this Festival.
 
We want to demonstrate to the community, to possible donors, foundations as well as the City adminstration of Peekskill and surrounding communities that Peekskill can and will support a lively performing arts scene.  (Also, we hope that others will support us from afar!)
 
This festival will in many ways be a preview of the scene we hope to create in our facility once developed.  This facility would house 2-3 theatres of varying size from a very small 75 seat intimate theatre/lecture hall to a larger expiramental space that could double as an creative event facility.  We would also have rehearsal rooms, practice/music lesson rooms, shared set and costume shops and storage, writing rooms, a children's craft and sewing room,  a gallery, perhaps a cafe and small retail shops. 
 
By supporting this festival, you are supporting the ultimate vision of the space. 
 
What We Need & What You Get
 

With the $2,000 earned from this campaign, we can do the following:
 
Secure the booking of the show which will anchor to our festival, LA CUCARACHITA MARTINA, a family puppet rock 'n roll musical in Spanish and English by Teatro Sea from New York City.   Your contribution will ensure that this quality production will be accessable and affordable to children in our community and will bring all families in the commmunity together.  
 
Pay for marketing and promotional materials for the festival, creating postcards and advertisements.  This will help us continue our outreach, to make sure we do reach all segments of our community.
 
 
Other Ways You Can Help


 
Share this with anyone who loves  or who loves theatre, dance, music, writing, reading, crafts, sewing and all other art forms!

story:
Our Story

Les Petites Taquines formed in November of 2008. Les Petites Taquines translates as “the little flirts”, and we continue to flirt with inovation, possibility, and the boundaries of dance style and form.The Company first appeared in Doktor Luke Productions’  Wintergarten Cabaret. Later that year the company performed pieces in Vintage Valentine (Stones Throw Productions) and were featured in A Mid Winter Romance (XuaXua Productions) . The group is defined by its versatility in dance styles; with a foundation in classical technique each member also has there own specialty whether in contemporary, tap, broadway and clowning adding a richness and diversity to the company. To date, all of Les Petites Taquines pieces have been choreographed by company members making the pieces uniquely ours: our voice, our movement, our expression. 

The Impact

"When I was, Qui Je Suis" is a premiere of a new production we have been rehearsing for the past year. This show is about growing up, about coming to terms with who you were and embracing who you are. Through movement we explore the journey of growing up as a comedy, a tragedy, and a fairytale. We strive to connect to our audience, to move them, to make them laugh, and to give them hope.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to pay for our theatre venue, our lighting and costume designer, cover printing and marketing costs, and pay for prop and costume materials. In exchange we would love to give complimentary tickets (2 per $50 donation) for our show running August 4-6. We can also negotiate listing you as a sponser in our program. (Oh and we are baking cupcakes for opening!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Invite people to our show at Pacific Theatre in Vancouver at 8pm August 4-6, 2011!

story:
Hi there!

In the run-up to the Fringe we have managed to clear nearly every cost! With only days to go, however, we have found ourself strapped for the necessities required of our production at the Fringe! With only a few days to go until our run we're hoping that there are some kind, theatrical souls out there who could donate whatever they can to help up market our production to the fullest extent possible whilst we're at the Fringe. 

With having already invested so much into this project, namely time, creative juices and coinage, it would be such a shame if we couldn't promote our show to the widest possible audience whilst finishing our UK Tour at the Fringe!

Any and all contributions would be incredibly welcomed by this theatre-thirsty bunch of students!

Many thanks, 

The Superhero Club

story:
Short Summary

Coming to the Etcetera Theatre for the Camden Fringe August 26th and 27th 2017: Sam Went's hilarious, outrageous and uplifting stand-up show 'Bicentennial Fan'! Directed by Amy Larham and written and performed by Sam Went, this debut show is not to be missed.

But we need YOUR help to bring this show to the stage. We now need the funding to make this show happen, and for it to be the best it can be. After months of hard work, gruelling rehearsals and far too many viewings of 'Bicentennial Man', Sam is ready to tell his story.

Sam Went got dumped and did the entirely normal thing of transferring his feelings onto the 17th worst film of all time – Bicentennial Man. In his debut solo stand-up performance, up-and-coming comedian Sam Went explains how the romantic odyssey of a creepy-yet-endearing robot butler healed his broken heart.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are aiming to raise £250 pounds to put on this production.
  • Your donation will go towards Fringe registration fees, props and marketing/printing.

In return for helping to support 'Bicentennial Fan': 

  • Win a chance to meet and hang out with the comedian after the performance!
  • Donations of £15 or over you will receive a ticket to the show on the night of your choice included! (Tickets are £5 on Fringe website)
  • Donations over £20 will also receive one free drink of your choice (up to £4) at the theatre bar before or after the performance,
  • For particularly generous donations exceeding £30, join Sam (and director Amy Larham) for his 16th viewing of the film, with running commentary and alcohol provided. (details and date TBC)
  • (Perks may stack upon request)

Other Ways You Can Help

Remember you can also support this production by purchasing tickets at https://cam.tickets.red61.com/performances.php?...

Please also remember to share our campaign and spread the word!

We look forward to your support!

story:
Short Summary

Every year, for the last 9 years, we have an intense movement of theater public and productions during the Hollywood Fringe Festival.

With the objective of offering the latin public and spanish speakers, plus the general public - that can still understand the play through subtitles - a cultural experience, we are happy to bring to The Broadwater Theater stage, "Paisaje Marino con Tiburones y Bailarina".


Ben, a lonely writer, fears to be alone. Tracy, a ballerina with no balance, fears to be loved. He can´t seem to take concrete actions towards his goals. She is always destroying everything she touches. This dance of care and insecurity, trust and vulnerability, staying and leaving, may be just that addictive cycle of killing and giving birth to our true selves - those never ending waves we are all afraid to live in. The world is full of sharks, isn´t it?

 

What We Need & What You Get

Do you know what are the basic costs of doing a theater production?

  • First we paid the Inscription of the Festival.
  • Then we paid the copyrights for the author + the translation.
  • Then we book a venue with insurance.
  • Marketing: poster, art, flyers, social media, program of the play, Fringe website, Fringe magazine.
  • Finally, rehearse! It costs to drive around L.A., right?
  • Scenario + costumes!! (we had to buy a smoke machine and a record player, isn´t this fun?)
  • Transportation for the scenario.
  • People to work: actors, directors, producer, set designer, light designer, box office, stage managers...
  • There is always something that happens in the middle of the way... (lets hope it´s cheap!)

Yes, it´s a lot to do! And we do all of this for the sake of having fun with you at the theater! You just gotta sit and enjoy!  :D

 

 

DATES:

JUNE

Friday, 15th - 11 pm

Saturday, 16th - 8:30pm 

Saturday, 23rd - 9 pm

Sunday, 3rd - 4pm

Sunday 24th - 2:30pm

 

The Impact

Latin community is half of California state, do you guys know that?
We want to offer cultural service, breaking as many barriers as possible:

You can come to the theater! You will not have problems with the language! 

Plus, it is very cheap!!

  • We won a Hollywood Fringe Festival Scholarship of $500 for being a project that contributes to the cultural diversity of the festival!! 

 

Risks & Challenges

This project is already happening. Please follow us on social media and visit website for details for the play and the party.

www.paisajemarino.com

The only risk you have is not seeing the play - we just have 250 seats. 

Once you buy it, you have no risks.

Not everything in life is that easy!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help the play to continue after the festival, or you feel that the tickets are worthy more than what you are paying, feel free to "tip us out".

Write an email to spacciari@gmail.com and let us know if you have any questions.

Also, spread the word!!! Maybe you have a friend that is bored and looking for something different to do...

story:
The Idea

Think about Marilyn Monroe, Amy Winehouse and Sylvia Plath. These incredible women that made a huge impact during their lives, and still hold cultural relevance today. 

Think about how we experience these women today. We know these women through what they left behind--their bodies of work, their possessions, and most importantly the memories of people they met.

In Vestige, we meet Livia who's memory is kept alive in the stories told by those who knew her.

We'll meet three other characters: a biographer, a portrait artist, and an archivist. They talk about the times they shared with Livia. They tell us how they've captured her essence through their different media. What transpires is that they have very different accounts of who Livia was.  

Vestige exposes the fact that we have very little control of the narratives of our lives once we have passed; how we are remembered will ultimately be constructed by the living. 

 

When and Who's Involved

Vestige will have its first preview on the 25 February 2017 at Rich Mix Theatre in London and a further two performance in the summer of 2017.

It’s a bold new step for the company and a new line of inquiry for Wayne's work that explores the potential relationships between text and movement to create a multifaceted and rich way of telling stories.

So we want to make sure it is as good as it can be!

With the development of Vestige we have built new partnerships with English National Ballet, East London Dance, Cambridge Junction, Rich Mix, Theatre Royal Stratford East, Akademi and further developed our existing relationships with DanceEast and The Place. This puts us in a really strong position to make a big impact with this work.

We have some fab collaborators on board.

Wayne Parsons- Artistic Director/Choreographer

Wayne has worked with some of the world's leading contemporary dance companies including Sydney Dance Company, Richard Alston Dance Company and the National Dance Company of Wales. He formed Wayne Parsons Dance in 2013 and this is his second and most ambitious work for his company.

Ankur Bahl- Writer

Ankur holds a BA and MA in Journalism from Northwestern University. He has been a performer with DV8 Physical Theatre, the Royal Shakespeare Company and The Globe. He was the writer for the dance film ‘The Art Of Defining Me’ produced by Seeta Patel.

Pooja Ghai- Dramaturg/Director

Pooja Ghai is Associate Director at Theatre Royal Stratford East. Her most recent productions include ‘Counting Stars’ and ‘The House of In Between’ that both had successful runs at Theatre Royal Stratford East.

Nicolai Hart-Hansen (Set and Costume designer), Angus MacRae (Composer and Musician) and Doug Currie (Production Manager and Lighting Designer)

And… some amazing performers who are Sonya Cullingford, Katie Lusby, Sarah Baltzinger and Ian Garside.

 

What We Need to succeed

We have worked tirelessly over the past year and secured financial investment in the form of funds and grants, as well as securing lots of space in kind to create the work. We have raised 90% of the total and now need the last 10% to get us to our fundraising target for Vestige.

Your contributions will go towards the Production elements of the work, including set, costume, lighting and sound design. Help us make this work to the highest possible standard!

The funds will also go towards getting the preview performance filmed. This will mean we have a professional standard video of the work to use for promotional purposes after the preview to send out in hopes of getting further performances of Vestige. 

 

Why we are asking for money

It sounds like we are doing really well, right? Absolutely we are. But the company is still at an emerging stage. We have applied for match funding from the Arts Council England and we were successful in our bid, but that still doesn’t mean we have all we need. The partnerships we have built are wonderful and it will mean these partners will get to see the work during it’s creation and hopefully in performance--amazing!

But, as we are still emerging, there was a limit on how much we could apply for from the Arts Council England if we wanted the application to succeed. The deficit needs to be raised by the company. These means that philanthropy is our way of ensuring way have the total amount needed to create the work. A challenge for such a new company, I know, but I think you’ll agree from watching the video--the work is good, and worth your investment

Share, Share, Share

If you have connected with the work, its  themes and ideas, or know someone involved in the project then please do share with your friends and family. Please help us get the word out there by sharing this Crowdfunding campaign.

story:
Hello all ---

We're back!

In 2014, Always Love Lucy presented Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman with a South Asian Loman family and multicultural friends and neighbors.

Despite being a new theatre company with no Hollywood names, we had a full house on opening night and were seen by over 500 people in our 15 show run.

We believe this is due to showing a classic through a new lens, and showing what people have always known --- these situations are universal and cross-cultural.

Now we are bringing George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion in a whole new light, with diverse talent and exploring transgender themes in Eliza's transformation. Many of our Salesman cast are back, along with some amazing new additions, to  this Pygmalion to life! 

Our goal is to fill every seat at every performance in our 7 show run May 4-7, 2016. Any monies raised will be used for our publicist Dan Demello -- who got us in the New York Times in 2014 --- and rehearsal space.

All contributors will receive a comp ticket and a thank-you in the playbill, as well as additional perks for additional funds.

Even more valuable is spreading the word. Please share this link and our FB page (www.facebook.com/alwayslovelucy) with your friends, and come to the show!

As the smiling guy by my coffee shop says "You don't have to be a Rockefeller to help a feller!"

Thanks -- and we will see you at the show!


- Saima Huq, Founder/Producer?Actor, Always Love Lucy Theatre.

story:
What is the ITCH?

Insert Theatre Company Here is a new 501(c)3 theatre founded by recent ASU Alumni with a passion for grassroots theatre and comedy!

  • We make theatre with young and emerging artists. This season we have 5 runs planned (one of which is a double feature).

  • On weekends without a play going on we will have comedy! Our comedy nights will have new, original sketches every Saturday night, followed by improv, stand-up, a burlesque show, who knows? We can do anything!

  • Oh, and because we are a 501(c)3, your donations are tax deductible! You heard that right. Would you rather give your money to the IRS or us? We are cuter... And we have PERKS! 

The ITCH Theatre is for the community! We have a strong desire to build a collaborative relationship with our audience so we can learn as much about theatre as they can!

What does the ITCH need?

Let us break it down (before putting on the itching ointment):

  • Lighting: $2190.00. This includes rigging, cable, DMX converters, light console, and well, lights.

  • Sound: $810.00. Microphones, a stand, soundboard, XLR cable, speakers and amps. You know, sound stuff.

  • Chairs: $1,000.00. This will get us about sixty chairs. Unless you want to bring your own, we are going to need some money.

  • Janitorial supplies: $545.50. I mean unless you want a dirty theater with no toilet paper… Talk about itchy.

  • Putting up a couple walls, the space might need it: $500.00. This is in case we need it. When we get the space it might not be perfect.

  • Space: $3,000 first three months. Rent isn’t cheap.

  • Misc: $1,954.50. This is for utilities, insurance, unseen problems, and to give the campaign a round number.

Please help us reach our goal!

Why scratch the ITCH?

The mission of the ITCH is to produce live theater that frees and enlightens ourselves and others. By working with emerging artists, the ITCH creates a space for the reflection and inclusion of the community in which we live. The ITCH believes that through artist-audience collaboration, we can strengthen cultural awareness and inspire those around us.

Do you also have an ITCH?

Don't worry, we are contagious! Are you an emerging artist with a piece of theatre/art you would like to produce? Are you an established artist wanting to see/experience something new? Or, are you someone who thinks they are funny and have a semi-okay stand-up routine for the nights we go dark? Then please, CONTACT US! We would love to hear from you!

< http://www.itchtheatre.com/ >

What is the ITCH?Insert Theatre Company Here is a new 501(c)3 theatre founded by recent ASU Alumni with a passion for grassroots theatre and comedy!
We make theatre with young and emerging artists. This season we have 5 runs planned (one of which is a double feature).
On weekends without a play going on we will have comedy! Our comedy nights will have new, original sketches every Saturday night, followed by improv, stand-up, a burlesque show, who knows? We can do anything!
Oh, and because we are a 501(c)3, your donations are tax deductible! You heard that right. Would you rather give your money to the IRS or us? We are cuter... And we have PERKS! 
The ITCH Theatre is for the community! We have a strong desire to build a collaborative relationship with our audience so we can learn as much about theatre as they can!What does the ITCH need?Let us break it down (before putting on the itching ointment):

story:
xoxo moongirl is an autobiographically inspired circus fantasia that incorporates breathtaking aerials and acrobatics to tell the story of a girl in a troubled home, and her flight to the moon to escape and prevail. Directed and co-created by Almanac co-founder Ben Grinberg and with created with input from an ensemble of artists over almost two years, the show is critically acclaimed, honest, and emotional. Barrymore award winner Mel Hsu composed a haunting and at times groovy original score for the show, which she performs live on Cello, Guitar, Vocals, and Looper Pedal. Amanda Jenson offers lighting design and Mia Rocchio co-directs.

During the solo performance, internationally acclaimed acrobat Nicole Burgio shares stories from her childhood, at times inviting audience volunteers to join the theatrics. As the story unfolds, Burgio uses the virtuosic performance languages of aerial circus arts, dance, hand balancing, and a hint of magic to tell her on-going story of survival, resilience, and overcoming abuse.

After premiering in Philadelphia for a 3 day workshop performance in June, 2018, Almanac has taken xoxo moongirl to Mexico City, where it was performed entirely in Spanish. Then, in June, 2019, the show was reworked and remounted for 12 performances, where it was Barrymore recommended and critically acclaimed. In August, we're taking the show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival -- one of the largest performance festivals in the English-speaking world, at Assembly -- one of the most prestigious venues at the festival. 

The Impact

xoxo moongirl is one of Almanac's 11 full length works that combine dance, theatre, and contemporary circus in the service of important stories. The show is stylistically innovative and inspiring, as circus, and the strength it requires, becomes a clear metaphor for Nicole's resilience in the face of trauma. The show has been very well received by audiences and critics alike in Philadelphia, and we are excited to bring it to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, where we think that it can have a big impact at the Festival, and hopefully also attract the attention of other producers and curators who would want to bring the show to other places and other communities. We've been accepted to perform at Assembly as part of their curated line-up of shows alongside some of the biggest names in circus and theatre. 

Here are some reviews of the show in its Philadelphia productions: 

Broad Street Review (2019)

thINKingDANCE

Philadelphia Dance Journal (2019)

ToiTime

Philadelphia Dance Journal (2018)

 

Risks & Challenges

The Edinburgh Fringe is huge. With over 3,000 different shows happening in just over three weeks, it is difficult to stand out in the line-up. There is a good likelihood that some nights, we will be performing for audiences of 10 or fewer people. Yet we really believe in this show and in our ability to attract the attention of press, media, producers, and audiences alike. 

Spread the word!

Thank you so much for viewing this campaign and reading this far! Please do consider making a contribution and be sure to review the great perks that the team has assembled for you. 

Whether or not you're able to make a donation, please share this campaign on social media or via email. If you know anyone who will be in Edinburgh in August, please let them know about the show, and encourage them to buy tickets!

Thank you so much for your support. As always, we couldn't do this without you.

Yours,

Ben, Nicole, Mel, Kate, and the whole Almanac team

story:
Why Next Iteration Needs You

Next Iteration Theater Company (NITC) is a professional Houston theater company focused on content and exploration beyond what is known and expected, into the new, the divergent and the unfamiliar. Houston is one of the most diverse cities in the USA and we are passionate about developing theater that recognizes this.

NITC focuses on underrepresented voices, diverse artists and collaborations that reflect our city and engage a broad audience base. We believe that such theater deserves to be produced in a professional manner at professional venues. We are committed to compensating all of our artists and technicians.

Your tax-deductible* contribution today will help NITC bring this diversity of voices and theater to Houston!

What’s Coming in Our Season

March 2016: NITC is producing the world premier of THE BABY, by Lisa Omlie, a Houston and London-based playwright. THE BABY is a tense and current family drama, in which unthinkable personal choices, public appearance and political personae spiral into a firestorm.

May 2016: NITC brings the INTERCULTURAL PLAY READING SERIES to Houston, featuring, amid other intercultural offerings, a staged reading of THE WHO AND THE WHAT by Pulitzer-Prize-winning, Tony-nominated playwright, Ayad Akhtar.

Where Your Contribution Will Go

The upcoming productions of THE BABY and the INTERCULTURAL PLAY READING SERIES are projected to cost approximately $32,000:

  •   Artist Compensation: $14,000

  •   Technical Costs & Set: $9,500

  •   Performance Venues: $5,500

  •   Audience Outreach and Marketing: $3000

This campaign is an integral part of raising the funds to ensure we can bring these voices to Houston audiences.

Your tax-deductible contribution* will go toward paying the artists and theater technicians who will work to bring this art to you!

The Difference You Make

In October 2015, NITC kicked off its season by producing an unprecedented collaboration in the Houston theater scene: READFEST HOUSTON. The READFEST was free to the public and offered 6 new play readings by 6 Houston theater companies in 1 weekend at the city’s wonderful new performance space, the MATCH. The READFEST was only made possible with the financial support of our sponsors and donors just like you!

THE BABY and the INTERCULTURAL PLAY READING SERIES employ theater professionals who need your engagement now to ensure support for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  •   Spread the word about this campaign: Email this link to those who care as much as you do, use your favorite social media channels, or the Indiegogo share tools right on this page!

  •   Buy tickets to the shows: watch our website for more information coming soon

  •   Volunteer: contact us via our website to let us know how you would like to get involved in bringing more living, breathing, thought-provoking theater to Houston

* Next Iteration Productions is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Next Iteration Productions must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
For the past three years, Yehoodi.com has provided -- free-of-charge -- a high quality live video broadcast from the International Lindy Hop Championships. We are asking for your support so we can do it again at ILHC 2015 this August!

Founded in 1997, Yehoodi.com has been supporting the lindy hop community through our discussion forums, live events and dances like the Frim Fram Jam, a streaming swing radio station, and audio & video podcasts like The Track, Hey Mr. Jesse and SwingNation.

Since 2012, we have been live broadcasting the International Lindy Hop Championships, producing a high quality internet showcase for amazing talent from around the world. Thousands of viewers have joined the hundreds of dancers assembled in Washington DC to cheer for their favorite competitors, swoon over beautiful performances, and dance along in their living rooms and local ballrooms.  

We want to do it again this August, but we need your help.

 

What Yehoodi Provides

  • An experienced production staff 

  • Professional video streaming equipment

  • Slick digital assets

  • Expert commentators and special guests 

  • A public video archive of the event afterwards

All of this does come at a cost, unfortunately. Digital assets have to be created; production notes and research has to be prepared; the crew has to be transported, housed, and fed; internet hosting and streaming fees need to be paid; and video archives have to be prepared afterwards. We keep our costs as low as possible, but in the end, a production of this scale does not come cheaply.

A Killer Production Team

As we demonstrated at ILHC 2012-2014, during the Frankie Centennial, and for our weekly show "SwingNation," we can put out a high quality video production on a shoestring. Our crack video production crew includes:

  • Producer Manu "Spuds" Smith
  • Producer Frank "Frankyboy" Dellario
  • Managing Editor Rik "Rikomatic" Panganiban
  • Videographer Jim "The Tricaster Master" Thorpe 

Yehoodi has been producing online video for as long as it's been available. Our first online talk show was launched in 1998, and we’ve been producing some version of it ever since. We've learned so much since those humble beginnings 17 years ago, putting together the crew and the technology to make this happen.

It's important to mention that the organizers of ILHC 2015 have again graciously invited us to be their video production partners, for which we are extremely grateful.


Funding Goals

Base Goal: $3,500. Yehoodi is able to fund the travel for the production team, their accommodations, and pay for our basic production costs.

Stretch Goal #1: $5,000. Yehoodi is able to fund a much needed upgrade to our live streaming equipment and shoot more behind-the-scenes footage, interviews with dance legends, chats with international competitors, and more!


Live from ILHC!

We love lindy hop so much, and want people around the world to be able to see it performed at the highest possible quality. We've seen that the general viewing public tunes in by the millions for live dance competitions -- whether it is "Dancing with the Stars" or "So You Think You Can Dance." We believe that lindy hop showcases like ILHC can have that same broad appeal... if done right. 

If you have watched any of our live broadcasts in the past, and believe that what we do is a valuable service to the lindy hop community, we hope you will consider supporting us to return to ILHC this year.

story:
About Lucrece

Commissioned by Washington Shakespeare Company in 2007, Lucrece is a stage adaptation of Shakespeare's poem "The Rape of Lucrece," which tells the story of Prince Tarquin's assault of the titular character,  a noblewoman and wife of the general Collatinus. Though silence would have assured her safety, Lucrece decried Tarquin before committing suicide. The news shook the Romans' already-faltering faith in the monarchy and set into motion its overthrow. 

 In re-workshopping the existing play, our goal is to explore its layers of theatricality. We plan to tailor the existing text to an entirely new company of actors. Each actor was cast independently of gender or type, emphasizing the art of storytelling and the power of imagination over realistic reeneactment.

Who We Are

We are a mobile, unaffiliated group of theater artists from all over the United States with a common goal of artist-driven storytelling. Members include:

  • Lorne Batman
  • Ian Carlsen
  • Kelly Chick
  • Tiffany Nichole Green
  • Callie Kimball
  • Will Madden
  • Bari Robinson
  • Cait Robinson

Where Your Donation Goes

Thanks to generous outside donors, we have reached our initial fundraisinggoal, which allows us to:

  • Rent the building for artists to sleep, shower, and prepare food.
  • Buy and prepare food for one meal a day for every artist.
Any donations received on or after June 29th will go towards expanding our food budget, limiting the financial strain on the artists. 

Other Ways to Help 

  • Know somebody who might be interested in what we're doing? Please share our campaign with them directly, or post to social media!
  • We need groceries! Email cait.f.robinson@gmail.com for a wishlist and how to help.
  • Are you local? We're seeking a spare bedroom for one of our artists in the Brooklin area from August 2 to 9. Email cait.f.robinson@gmail.com for more info.

story:
What is DAS?

Dead Arts Society (DAS) is a student organization focusing on producing original works of student written theatre. We are a club for actors, dancers, singers, directors, choreographers, playwrights and anybody else who has a passion for any of the performing arts. All levels of experience and majors are welcome! 

With your support, we're hoping to earn enough money to pay for our performance space, as well as all the props, costumes, and other production expenses that go into making showcases a success! All your kind donations keep the showcase a free event for all students, faculty, friends, and family wishing to attend and support the cast members. 

Our Spring Showcase:

With all that in mind, we hope you come check out this quarter's amazing set of student-written works:

Spring Showcase 2015: DAStruggle Is Real

WHERE: Arena Theater (Wright Hall)

WHEN: May 28 - 6-9pm
               May 29 - 6-9pm
               May 30 - 1-3pm and 6-9pm

WHAT: This quarter, we're excited to present THREE incredible one-acts, including

  • "Never Better," by Leah Daugherty 
"Never Better" is a piece written by Leah Daugherty and directed by Kazia Hart and Adeline Xu. The premise: Jamie Magnussen is visited by PANIC, the Panel Administering New Insecurities and Confusion, and attempts to maintain her composure.

  • "Daddy Issues," by Shubha Arehalli
"Daddy Issues" is a piece written by Shubha Arehalli and directed by Sarah Brown and Rahi Suryawanshi. Here's the premise: It’s Father’s Day and a family reunion. But when you’re one of the many illegitimate children of Zeus, family reunions take on a whole new level of crazy. Cursed by her stepmother, Hera, and grasping for some sense of normalcy, Phoebe struggles to hold together the chaos that is her family. 

  • "Horrors of the Female Body," by Deanna Siegel
"Horrors of the Female Body" is an autobiographical piece written by Deanna Siegel and directed by Deanna Siegel and Kendall Larsen about dealing with the treatment of endometriosis, relationships, American Jewish culture and womanhood. There will be music by Arcade Fire, a dance piece choreographed by the talented Isabel Fischer and even a uterus pinata!

Contact Us:

For more information about Dead Arts Society, our spring showcase, or any questions you may have, feel free to...

  • Email us at deadartssociety@gmail.com!
  • Follow our Dead Arts Society Facebook page!

Thank you!

story:
Why Seven Santas?

We chose 'Seven Santas' to kick-start 2017, as our productions of 'The Eight: Reindeer Monologues' proved very popular and we adored the writing style from Jeff Goode.
This play allows us to perform the dark humour that we enjoy so much whilst also exploring darker themes of Christmas.

This production delves into the psyche of Santa Claus and seven representations of him; each with their own views on what Christmas means. Set in a Alcoholics Anonymous meeting lead by the biggest drunk of them all: Mrs Claus, the Santas own up to past experiences, addictions and dark, dark secrets.

This production is a dark-comedy with adult themes and language - not for the faint-hearted!

Gallows Productions

We are a young theatre company based in Hampshire, England with drive and passion for creating theatre. Gallows Productions was established in 2013 to provide unconventional and provocative theatre that challenges audiences, whilst bettering our artist’s experience and confidence within the theatre industry. 

Our Aims as a company are to  offer unique opportunities and practical experiences within theatre and performance for new artists and to create unconventional and thought-provoking theatre for both new and established audiences.

Gallows Productions don't receive funding like many other theatre companies - we have made it work on our own terms through nothing short of blind faith, endless perseverance and sheer determination. ​However, as we embark on the next stage of our journey to bring interesting and creative theatre to audiences, we need all the help that we can get.

This campaign is extremely important to us as a company as this gives us the chance to improve our production value, connect with our audiences, give you the best that we can be.

How Your Contribution Helps

We aim to raise a total of £500 for this production to help with costs such as:

- Set, props and costume
- Theatre usage
- Licensing fees
- Marketing (printing, advertising, etc.)

This will also give us more resources to use as they help us create an immersive setting for our characters and our audience. By contributing, you are actively supporting your local creators and helping us to progress our company and furthermore, our passions and your entertainment, to new heights.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute with money? That's OK, there are other ways to support us:

Please share: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube and our Website.

Contact us (d.guy@gallowsproductions.co.uk) if you want to donate equipment, labour, or time. We value all contributions! 

Share using the Indiegogo share tools below.
 

A big thanks from everyone at Gallows Productions; we look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
Short Summary

Dancing Queerly is an annual dance festival for the LGBTQIA+ community, its friends and allies. Because people approach dance for a variety of reasons and with different intents, Dancing Queerly provides queer-centric dance events for students and professionals, audience members and enthusiasts. Founded on the belief that the queer community is largely underserved in traditional dance spaces, Dancing Queerly gives LGBTQIA+ dancers and dancemakers the opportunity to create and perform for an LGBTQIA+ centered audience, and invites community members to explore and expand their relationship to dance as audience members and participants.  

The 2019 festival features artists including Lilly Valore (Boston, MA), Nick Daniels (Pittsburgh, PA), Toby MacNutt (Burlington, VT), Queens With A Mission (Boston, MA), and Kareem Khubchandani (Boston, MA).

We are putting the 2019 festival together with the help of some foundation support, but we also need your help to pay for space rental, technicians, artists, travel expenses and publicity. Extra funds raised will support the festival going into 2020 and beyond, and fund additional free tickets and workshops for community members who are unable to pay.

More about us

Producers Maggie Cee and Michael Winward met while dancing together in the 2016 and discovered a mutual passion for sharing dance with a wide range of audiences and for giving LGBTQIA+ audiences, performers, and choreographers an opportunity to experience work that reflects and/or embodies queer experiences.


In June of 2017, we co-produced our first concert, “A Queer Time and Place”, at The Dance Complex in Central Square.


With support from The Boston Foundation, in 2018 we were able to expand two sold out shows and five well-attended workshops, approximately 200 people participated in Dancing Queerly as students, audience members, and panel discussion attendees. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the campaign via social media! 
  • make sure your friends know about our events, too
  • ask a small business or organization to purchase a program ad!

story:
Our Company

The Mimesis Theatre Project is a devised musical theatre company.  "Devised" means that our actors and collaborators are imperative in the construction of our pieces, and "Musical Theatre" in that all of our work includes dance, text, and music.  

Our First Season

In 2017, The Mimesis Theatre Project will be launching its first season with three freshly created pieces:  

1. Open Forum. APRIL 15th @ 3pm. The 92nd Street Y.  

     Three artists devise a theatre piece with their voices at the forefront.   

2. Resurrexit. MAY 26th @ 10pm. Dixon Place. 

     An exploration of identity, faith, and the power within.  

3. The Chosen One. JULY 1st. Garner Arts Center/August 1st-15th. Piknik Theatre Festival. 

     Using The Torah and Superhero mythology to explore good, evil, and the "other."  

What We Need 

In order to get off the ground as a company  and produce our first season, we need to raise $11,000.  

We are using this campaign specifically to raise the $7,500 needed in order to SUPPORT OUR PERFORMERS AND COLLABORATORS with housing, travel, and sustainable compensation for their time with company:

  • Open Forum (3 Artists, 1 Director): $1,000
  • Resurrexit (7 Artists, 1 Director, 1 Music Director, 1 Choreographer): $2,500
  • The Chosen One Developmental Lab (5 Collaborators): $1,375 
  • Transportation to and from The Garner Arts Center (5 Collaborators): $650
  • Housing in Garnerville, NY (5 collaborators): $1,575
  • Stage Management and Marketing Personnel: $400

Impact

By donating to this campaign, you will be giving emerging artists the ability to bring their work to life.  

The Mimesis Theatre Project was established in order to explore what is shared between all artists and all peoples. By creating collaborative efforts on our stage, we hope to incite a collaborative effort in our audience, bringing peoples and communities together in order to communicate through stories and self-expression.  

As stated above, I think at this time in our human history it is most important that we sit down with people unlike ourselves, look each other in the eyes, and listen to each other's stories.  I know your donation will go directly towards creating work where this is possible. 

Dream to Reality

Without your support, we run the risk of not being able to get off the ground at all. Your donations are imperative at this juncture.

"The word Mimesis has been with me since I was 15. Very plainly, mimesis means 'to imitate,' but I was drawn to the word for a more theatrical translation: ' to bend reality.' As I have grown, so has my understanding of the word's magnitude. By imitating our surroundings, our stories, and our lives, we have the capability to bend the reality within which we live.  The theatre is powerful, and Mimesis is its tool. This project has been a dream of mine for over a decade, and I cannot believe how close we are to bringing it to life. Now, more than ever, are the arts necessary to open communication and bring us all closer together.  Help us bend our current reality in to a stronger, brighter and more compassionate tomorrow. "- Andrew Garret Karl, Founder and Artistic Director 

Please Share 

Please share this campaign with your friends, relatives, yoga classmates, and cab driver!

Follow us on instagram @themimesistheatreproject, or find us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/themimesistheatreproject

*If interested in a tax-deductible donation or to donate by check, please email @ mimesistheatreproject@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Genesis Theatrical Productions in association with Redtwist Theatre in Chicago will present "Muse of Fire" in February of 2016.  This play by Jake Rosenberg seeks to  deepen and enrich our cultural understanding of Holocaust art and expanding what it means to remember.

"In Auschwitz, 1942, Jewish prisoners took it upon themselves at grave personal risk to perform comedy. This is their story, as one group struggles to perform a farce based on the first great anti-Semitic tragedy of the 20th century: the infamous Dreyfus Affair. As the play goes on, and dark secrets begin to emerge about the reason for its performance, those performing must ask themselves, can comedy truly have meaning in the face of horror? Who really has the last laugh?" 


Our goals for this production are to sensitively and accurately explore the complex and subversive subject matter of this play while still making sure it hits an emotional chord.  We want to make sure the story is historically precise, emotionally authentic and accurate without being insensitive and that it is accessible to as large an audience as possible without alienating those who might find its subject matter displeasing.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $5,000 to cover the cost of rent on the performing space, publicity and printing.

We are offering a wide range of perks to those who can contribute.

The Impact

Genesis Theatrical Productions will be celebrating its 10 year in 2016 and in that time has offered some of the most innovative and powerful new works to the Chicago theater audiences.  They will be associating with Redtwist Theatre on this project which is another highly regarded, much honored company.

Genesis' mission is to offer the new works that engage an ever widening audience and also works to promote the work of women in theater.

This is a play that will engender discussion and contemplation of the Holocaust, a subject which is never fully understood.

Risks & Challenges

There is always a risk that not enough funding can be raised to enable us to do as much publicity as needed but Genesis has always overcome such problems in innovative ways and with the help of numerous supporters from the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help by spreading the word via Facebook, Twitter and other social media as well as using the Indiegogo share tools.
