story:
"Theatre has no memory, which makes it the most existential of the arts. No doubt that is why I keep coming back - in hope that someone in a dark room somewhere will show me an image that burns itself into my mind, leaving a mark more permanent than the moment itself." - Sarah Kane

Blasted comes to Boston

Off the Grid, the bold young company that brought Equus to a Boston storefront last year, is back with their most daring production yet, Sarah Kane's Blasted. John Kuntz directs Christopher James Webb, Alexis Scheer, and Maurice Emmanuel Parent.

Violent, unrelenting, and brutal conflict manifests both in and outside of a small hotel room where three individuals grapple with their own cruelties, fears, desires, and basest instincts.The initial critical response to Kane's first play Blasted at the Royal Court Theatre in London ranged from laudatory to morally condemning but there was unanimous agreement that a singularly original form of theatre had been born. Today, Blasted continues to shake the nerves and sensibilities of its audiences with its savagery as well as its compassion for the lowest depths of human desperation, pain, and ultimate redemption. 

What We Need

Blasted is Off the Grid's largest-scaled production yet. 4 years ago we were performing/squatting in a school basement, wearing things found in our closet, and opening/closing the same night. This September we'll be making our home at the Calderwood Pavilion at the BCA, hiring a whole design team, and will play a limited three week engagement. We've come a long way, but we still need help.

Alexis Scheer is this years recipient of the New World School of the Arts Alumni Foundation Inspiration Grant. The grant, along with ticket revenue, will help pay for rights and most of the artists involved in the production.

Your contribution via IndieGoGo will specifically go towards:

  • Space rental (this is our big ticket item)
  • Fight Choreographer (help keep us safe!)
  • Designer fees
  • Set materials
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Poster/program printing
Any funds raised beyond our goal will pay admin fees taken by Indiegogo and Fractured Atlas (10% of everything we raise), and then go towards our marketing efforts.

What You Get

We've got an excellent assortment of perks for all levels of giving, including:

  • An Off the Grid tshirt for you to wear around town.
  • Tickets to the show.
  • Private pre-show reception with John Kuntz.
  • An all-inclusive dinner for you and your guests with John, Chris, Alexis, and Maurice. We're pretty cool people. This is a total steal.

Other Ways To Lend A Hand

We know not everyone is in a position to give. Good news is there are other ways you can support us!

  • Share this campaign. Facebook/Twitter/Email/Snapchat/CallYourMom
  • Come see the show! Bring a friend. Bring a date. Bring your mom. Don't bring your child though. This play contains graphic scenes
    of physical and sexual violence and nudity. Not intended for audience members under age 17.
Blasted by Sarah Kane presented by Off the Grid Theatre Company at the Calderwood Pavilion at the BCA. 527 Tremont St. Boston, MA. September 2-18, 2016. www.offthegridtheatre.com

Off the Grid Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Off the Grid Theatre Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
WHO WE ARE

Ananya Dance Theatre is a professional dance company of women artists of color who create “People Powered Dances of Transformation.” We are cultural activists, working through dance and artistic processes to engage audiences, build community, and move toward social justice and beauty.


OUR PROJECT

Our campaign project supports “Horidraa: Golden Healing,” our 2016 production that explores healing practices and women’s work as healers.

The year: 2053. A patient, dark of skin, has been checked into urgent medical care in a state of collapse. Her name is given as Ashwarnahm BahrAili KofucheeNané and she self-identifies as “the child of many continents.” Who is she? What healing does she need? Follow her journey as she travels into the recesses of memory and imagination to conjure a magical healing experience that invites all into its joy-filled dance.

Choreographer Ananya Chatterjea (named Best Choreographer by the Star Tribune’s 2016 Best of Minnesota) works with the exquisite dancers of Ananya Dance Theatre, director Marcus Young, sound artists Greg Schutte, Queen Drea, Pooja Goswami, and Tenzin Ngawang, visual artist Alison Hiltner, and lighting designer Kevin A. Jones to create an original dance theater production inspired by the remarkable properties of turmeric, the root ingredient of many cuisines and recipes that heal from within!

“Horidraa” is the third in a series of five evening-length dances around the theme “Work Women Do,” each celebrating the little-acknowledged labor of women to sustain and transform their communities.

“Horidraa” will premiere at The O’Shaughnessy on the campus of St. Catherine University, St. Paul, September 16-18, 2016. 


OUR CAMPAIGN

We successfully completed and met our campaign goal of $10,000 with very generous support from 194 donors! These gifts make it possible for us to fully engage the collaborating design artists of our production: music, sets, costumes, and lights. 

The campaign will remain online until early September. All additional funds raised will help us advertise our production and make it accessible to youth so that we can reach the largest number of people and build our audience. For example, $630 will buy one advertisement in the Star Tribune newspaper; $1,260 will buy two. Another $930 would buy two ads in the St. Paul neighborhood where we perform. $200 more will support transportation to and from schools serving students from primarily immigrant, refugee, and urban communities of color, $900 more will support tickets for these beautiful young people who would not be able to afford to come otherwise.

We invite your support for this outreach.


MAGNITUDE OF CONTRIBUTIONS

We are committed to honoring the hours of creative labor by all the artists in our process, and providing the materials and other resources needed to bring their designs and efforts to fruition: dancing, sound, scenery, costumes, lighting. Your support lifts us to the realm of production excellence in the layered movement imagery and haunting sound scores of this multi-disciplinary artistic project. Viewers will know they have accompanied courageous women through stories of healing journeys! 


IMPACT

Every dollar that was contributed to the campaign goal significantly helps manifest stories of healing! Each contribution is valued for the hope and encouragement it lends to our efforts and the investment it imparts to our audience experiences!

Each additional dollar donated beyond the original goal will invigorate and help extend our marketing efforts to reach audience members who should attend this production. Thank you for your help!

"I wept at the end of your show because it....reminded me of the power of art to change minds and feelings, to build community, to love, to believe in the possibilities of our dreams." –Soyini Madison, Professor, Northwestern University

 “A revolution.…ends with the performers leading an exuberant celebration in the aisles.” –Caroline Palmer, Star Tribune

“The audience at the National Theater was fully engaged with this social justice-themed dance performance and was cheering after each section.” –Tibebeselassie Tigabu, The Reporter, Ethiopia

“Exceptional and pivotal in my personal and dance journey.…This company continues and strives to keep us ‘woke’ and conscious in our community and abroad.…Be ready for ADT to break you off in the most fierce way.” –Audience member

“Absolutely stunning and important.…Powerful work, discipline, story and hearts. Thanks for a wonderful evening, a Friday's rainy eve incredibly well spent.” –Audience member

“Creates a deep interaction with its audience, engaging them in a dialogue.…about the world in which we live and the barriers above which we can rise to taste the world with a bit more truth than how it is fed to us.” –Clarence White, Saint Paul Almanac

“Created and performed at a totally different level. The percussive dance perfectly accenting the music, the music took me on a complete journey and kept my head and body moving in my seat. The poems and spoken word pieces helped to guide me through this journey. The solos were nothing less than amazing, the lighting was perfect, and the beginning created a social/community atmosphere....Thank you for birthing this work and sharing it with the world.” –Audience member


RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Large-scale theatrical works about issues and stories that are the stuff of lived experiences, but not necessarily light entertainment, carry elements of risk. Groups of artists committed to conveying compelling stories of our time proceed on faith.

This is not new for us. Our audiences have supported us over many years with vital support! We stand in gratitude and invite you to join them as we embark on this artistic journey.

explores healing practices and women’s work as healers.
The year: 2053. A patient, dark of skin, has been checked into urgent medical care in a state of collapse. Her name is given as Ashwarnahm BahrAili KofucheeNané and she self-identifies as “the child of many continents.” Who is she? What healing does she need? Follow her journey as she travels into the recesses of memory and imagination to conjure a magical healing experience that invites all into its joy-filled dance.
Choreographer Ananya Chatterjea (named Best Choreographer by the Star Tribune’s 2016 Best of Minnesota) works with the exquisite dancers of Ananya Dance Theatre, director Marcus Young, sound artists Greg Schutte, Queen Drea, Pooja Goswami, and Tenzin Ngawang, visual artist Alison Hiltner, and lighting designer Kevin A. Jones to create an original dance theater production inspired by the remarkable properties of turmeric, the root ingredient of many cuisines and recipes that heal from within!“Horidraa”
is the third in a series of five evening-length dances around the theme “Work
Women Do,” each celebrating the little-acknowledged labor of women to sustain
and transform their communities.
“Horidraa”
will premiere at The O’Shaughnessy on the campus of St. Catherine University,
St. Paul, September 16-18, 2016. 
 
OUR
CAMPAIGN

We successfully completed and met our campaign goal of $10,000 with very generous support from 194 donors! These gifts make it possible for us to fully engage the collaborating design artists of our production: music, sets, costumes, and lights. The campaign will remain online until early September. All additional funds raised will help us advertise our production and make it accessible to youth so that we can reach the largest number of people and build our audience. For example, $630 will buy one advertisement in the Star Tribune newspaper; $1,260 will buy two. Another $930 would buy two ads in the St. Paul neighborhood where we perform. $200 more will support transportation to and from schools serving students from primarily immigrant, refugee, and urban communities of color, $900 more will support tickets for these beautiful young people who would not be able to afford to come otherwise.We invite your support for this outreach.MAGNITUDE
OF CONTRIBUTIONS

We are
committed to honoring the hours of creative labor by all the artists in our
process, and providing the materials and other resources needed to bring their
designs and efforts to fruition: dancing, sound, scenery, costumes, lighting.
Your
support lifts us to the realm of production excellence in the layered
movement imagery and haunting sound scores of this multi-disciplinary artistic
project. Viewers will know they have accompanied courageous women through
stories of healing journeys! IMPACT
Every dollar that was contributed to the campaign goal significantly helps manifest stories of healing!
Each contribution is valued for the hope and encouragement it lends to our
efforts and the investment it imparts to our audience experiences!Each additional dollar donated beyond the original goal will invigorate and help extend our marketing efforts to reach audience members who should attend this production. Thank you for your help!"I wept at the end of your show because it....reminded me of the power of art to change minds and feelings, to build community, to love, to believe in the possibilities of our dreams." –Soyini Madison, Professor, Northwestern University
 “A revolution.…ends with the
performers leading an exuberant celebration in the aisles.” –Caroline Palmer, Star Tribune
“The audience at the National Theater was fully engaged with this social
justice-themed dance performance and was cheering after each section.” –Tibebeselassie Tigabu, The Reporter, Ethiopia“Exceptional and pivotal in my personal and dance journey.…This company continues and strives to keep us ‘woke’ and conscious in our community and abroad.…Be ready for ADT to break you off in the most fierce way.” –Audience member“Absolutely stunning and important.…Powerful work, discipline, story and hearts. Thanks for a wonderful evening, a Friday's rainy eve incredibly well spent.” –Audience member“Creates a deep interaction with its audience, engaging them in a dialogue.…about the world in which we live and the barriers above which we can rise to taste the world with a bit more truth than how it is fed to us.” –Clarence White, Saint Paul Almanac“Created and performed at a totally different level. The percussive dance perfectly accenting the music, the music took me on a complete journey and kept my head and body moving in my seat. The poems and spoken word pieces helped to guide me through this journey. The solos were nothing less than amazing, the lighting was perfect, and the beginning created a social/community atmosphere....Thank you for birthing this work and sharing it with the world.” –Audience member
RISKS AND
CHALLENGES
Large-scale
theatrical works about issues and stories that are the stuff of lived
experiences, but not necessarily light entertainment, carry elements of risk. Groups
of artists committed to conveying compelling stories of our time proceed on
faith.
This is not
new for us. Our audiences have supported us over many years with vital support!
We stand in gratitude and invite you to join them as we embark on this artistic
journey.

story:
WHAT WE ARE DOING

Aaron Salazar and Nate Suggs have teamed up to create Poseidon Theatre Company a new company that focuses on the Exploration of the Classics and The Development of New Work:

Creation. Exploration. Inspiration. Communication.

Theatre is a vital tool in keeping us all connected in this day and age of ever advancing technology. Not all theatre happens on the stages of Broadway. It is in the small independent non commercial theatre community that new voices are honed and produced. That is what we are trying to do with Poseidon Theatre Company. By exploring these timeless classics from the Greeks through the contemporary post modern classics, to the harnessing of new playwrights and creative talent, we hope to become part of the heartbeat of the theatre community offering our audiences and our artists a home to gather and revel in the art of theatre. 

WHAT WE NEED

Your money! Seriously. Theatre is a team sport, a community, and we can't do what we do without you. 

    YOUR IMPACT

     The costumes, the scenery, the make-up, the lights. The audience that lifts you when you're down.-Irving Berlin. 

     Your donations literally pay for these things. Without you, there is no show. Like these lyrics state, there really is no business like show business. And whether we like it or not, business requires cash to make it a possibility. We are fortunate to be a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, making our donations tax deductible and keeping our budgets for our season transparent. As is the case with most new theatre companies, all of our funds raised pay for all material costs, insurance, theatre rental, rehearsal space and performance rights. 
    If we meet our goal, then YOU have helped pay for our entire First Season of shows! 
    That's a whole year of talent and creativity and community of which you will belong!

      OTHER WAYS TO BE INVOLVED

      Like free tickets? More discounts? Parties, galas, events? Us too.
      Become a Muse or join Poseidon's Circle to find out more about our variety of different annual (and totally tax deductible) donation levels. And all the cool perks that come with it.  
      Click the links Below:
       
      MUSE our MEMBERSHIP PROGRAM 
      POSEIDON'S CIRCLE
       

      Poseidon Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Poseidon Theatre Company must be made  payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
MIAMI IS SINKING / PASTELTIO GUERRERAS tells the story of four best friends reuniting on Miami Beach one hour before Miami sinks back into the ocean to perform a sacrificial ritual that will turn them into the immortal goddesses of Miami they were never able to become when the city was still afloat. There's gonna be RAP, there's gonna be BLOOD, there's gonna be SANTERIA MAGIC, and there's gonna be a lot of CHONGA REALNESS.

But we need your help!

We are raising funds to pay for the salaries of our actors, of our technicians, of our designers, of every part of our MASSIVE team that will be devoting countless hours of their time to turn MIAMI IS SINKING / PASTELITO GUERRERAS into the theatre event of the year in the heart of MIAMI, FLORIDA.

Any CENT you donate is going STRAIGHT into the pockets of our team, and we could not be any more thankful for your contribution!

Miami Is Sinking / Pastelito Guerreras
Written and Done by: Thomas Daníel Valls

At: Artistic Vibes Miami, September 25th, 26th, 27th, 28th. 
With: Cristy Blanco / Amanda Ortega / Jackie Garcia / Vanessa Red Thompson
Stage: Quills Rodriguez / Michelle Lavergne 
Dramaturg: Jackie Garcia
Set & Props & Stuff: Mike Engelmann
Fight and Dance: Francesca Toledo
Looks: Penn Aragon

story:
Help bring this timeless classic to U of M’s campus — just in time for Arthur Miller’s centennial year!

1950’s working class New York sets the stage for Arthur Miller’s "A View From  the Bridge." A longshoreman by trade, Eddie Carbone lives with his wife, Beatrice, and their niece, Catherine. When their family agrees to harbor two illegal immigrant  relatives, dark secrets are revealed, tension mounts, and the Carbone family falls to  tension and violence. 

"A View From the Bridge" illustrates themes of family tension, the complicated politics of desire, and our place within our own communities. From the beginning, the tragic end to the story is clear, the entire play acting as a precursor to catastrophe. Our mission with this show is to illustrate the timelessness of tragedy, and show how pertinent the themes are even today. We aim to explore the American attitude toward immigrants, and the ways that tension can slowly and insidiously tear our lives apart. This story mirrors modern life in many ways, and we want to leave the audience with food for thought.

 

Arthur Miller’s "A View From The Bridge" is directed by Paul Mayer, produced by Ian Cook, and stage managed by Madeline Dickins. The show is assistant directed  by Samuel Francey and assistant stage managed by Lindsay Zinbarg. Performances are on Friday, Nov. 13, Saturday, Nov. 14, and Sunday, Nov. 15. The cast list is  as follows:

Eddie: Isaiah Zeavin-Moss

Beatrice: Emma McGlashen

Catherine: Suzanne Wdowik 

Marco: Ryan McGriff

Rodolpho: Jackson Tucker-Meyer

Alfieri: Patrick Mullan-Kofoupolous

Mike: Will Arnuk

Louis: Jimbo Schneider 

Tony: Jordan Khalaf

First Immigration Officer: Nathan Shepherd

Second Immigration Officer: Willy Su

Mr. Lipari: Kyle Stefek

Mrs. Lipari: Alex Konwinski

'Submarine' 1: Charlie Callis

'Submarine' 2: Guyot Lapointe

Neighbors: Skyler Tarnas, Rebecca Godwin

 

All proceeds from the Kickstarter will be put towards the production. This includes costume design, set design, props, scripts, and publicity costs. We deeply appreciate any and all donations, regardless of size. Thank you all, and please share with your friends and family! The show is being presented through the RC Players, a theater performance group at the University of Michigan.

story:
Dear friends and colleagues, 

We filmed this short video in summer, rehearsed and filmed in two days, with unfinished music, to explore some ideas, and we are currently working on the development of the full Hourglass project, recently selected for Resolution! 2016.

We are crowdfunding to make sure our work Hourglass can be created properly. We need to pay all dancers & crew as well as rehearsal studios & props. Help us to make it happen! If you can’t donate, please spread the word! Thanks!!!!

Also, if you’d like to come, it would be great to see some known faces in the audience on the 9th February http://www.theplace.org.uk/drishti-dancebridget...

Queridos amigos, hicimos este video en verano, ensayado y grabado en dos días, y la música sin acabar, para explorar algunas ideas para el desarrollo de Hourglass, que ha sido seleccionado para Resolution! 2016. Estamos intentando recaudar fondos para poder pagar a los bailarines, al equipo, el alquiler de los estudios y el atrezzo. Hemos puesto ya mucho trabajo y muchos recursos pero nos queda un poquito! Ayúdanos a hacerlo posible, si no puedes ayudarnos económicamente, pasa la voz! Gracias!!!!!

Venir a vernos el 9 de Febrero!!! http://www.theplace.org.uk/drishti-dancebridget...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hourglass is a dance-theatre piece directed by Laura Obiols, using recorded voice-overs, a cinematic original score & dancers interacting on stage that explores growing up in a society full of expectations and fear of taking risks, where time seems to be chasing you.

You can see some of the process here: http://www.alacarte.uk.com/work.html

Why are we fundraising?

We are committed to recognition of the value of professional artists by the awarding of proper and fair payment. We have been working before Xmas and we will work for one more month until the  show date (9th February) with established dancers, composers, lighting designers, technicians, costume designer, set designer & musicians. I want to make sure that they are paid fairly for their skill, expertise and inspiration that they bring into the studio. 

The perks that you will get for helping me are aimed at giving  you an insight into the process of making Hourglass, through images, video, open rehearsals and even tickets to see the show in London.

Reaching our target of £4,500 will allow us to pay everyone. 

What's in it for you?

There's a feeling you get when you've helped realise someone's dream. We'll promise you that.  We'll also thank ever donor individually across all of our social media. Top-level supporters will also become acknowledged Patrons of Hourglass, and get tickets to the show! 

Your support - whether it's £10 or £1000 - will make an enormous difference to what we're able to do.  You'll be  supporting the creation of a new work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with friends and family. Spread the word, any help is hugely appreciated.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Laura Obiols is a choreographer based in London who is part of À la carte collective & creates dance music productions inspired by contemporary stories. Her pieces are driven by the intention of capturing, in some way, the conditions of human life. www.alacarte.uk.com

story:
It’s been a great first few years for Broken Nose Theatre, and we couldn’t have done it without the more than 200 artists who have helped us bring to life ten productions for over 3,000 audience members. From critically acclaimed premieres like Beautiful Broken, ROOMS: a rock romance, and From White Plains, to our late night hit My First Time, to three iterations(and counting) of our annual (and award-winning) Bechdel Fest, we count ourselves lucky to have worked with such a wide variety of top-notch talent in a city rich in it.

Now, as we enter a new phase in our company history, we are excited to continue sparking conversation, cultivating empathy, providing opportunities for underrepresented voices, and making theatre more economically accessible for all audiences. As featured in American Theatre Magazine, our women-centric 4th season is our first as an all Pay-What-You-Can (PWYC) organization, and will feature two female-penned productions: the world premiere of A PHASE, written by BNT Associate Artistic Director Elise Spoerlein, and the Chicago premiere of HUMAN TERRAIN, by award-winning playwright Jennifer Blackmer.

Bringing this ambitious season to life will require the time, talents, and work of over 50 artists: actors, writers, designers, directors, stage managers, technical staff, crew, and more. To ensure that we have the funds in place to pay all of these incredible, hard-working artists, we are asking for your help to raise $6,450, every cent of which will go directly to paying the artists working on these two shows. Anything raised above the minimum will also go towards artists' pay on these and future BNT productions, as well as compensating artists for an upcoming workshop reading of KINGDOM by Michael Allen Harris as a part of our Paper Trail series.

We are thrilled to produce these timely and compelling plays, and to tell these important and relevant stories, and to compensate the next wave of Broken Nose artists for their time and talents, but we need your help and generosity to do it. Here are just some of the Broken Nose artists your contribution will support (this list will be updated once the cast and crew for Human Terrain have been announced):

Laura Baker, Dennis Bisto, Jennifer Blackmer, Caitlin Boylan, Juliana Brecher, Benjamin Brownson, Sam Brownson, Andrew Cutler, Spenser Davis, Richard Eisloeffel, Rose Hamill, Michael Allen Harris, Taylor Horst, JT Nagle, Shariba Rivers, Josh Servantez, Evan Sesak, Dagoberto Soto, Iris Sowlat, Elise Spoerlein, Amy Sunshine, Anthony Venturini, David Weiss.

Broken Nose Theatre is a 501(c)3 organization, so make your tax-deductible contribution today and support economically accessible theatre and the next wave of Broken Nose artists!

story:
All Aboard!

The Glass Eye is producing a new adaptation of Twelfth Night with original music, in the style of classic 1930's musical comedies, a la Anything Goes. 

Directed by Artistic Director Kyle Metzger, with original music by Tim Duncheon, and beautifully costumed by Rivkah Spolin.

Twelfth Night will be performed June 15th-23rd at The Access Theater in NYC, and June 25th & 26th on the beach in Stonington, CT. Reserve your tickets here: https://www.artful.ly/store/events/9147

About the show: 

After a shipwreck, Viola is stranded on the island of Illyria and disguises herself as a man. Soon she falls madly in love with the Duke Orsino, who is madly in love with the Countess Olivia, who is madly in love with Viola (in disguise)! But wait! The snobbish servant Malvolio loves Olivia too! As does the moronic knight Sir Andrew! And that’s all before Viola’s twin brother Sebastian, thought to be lost at sea, washes ashore and gets tossed into the madness as well. 

How You Can Help

Like all Glass Eye Summer Shakespeare productions, Twelfth Night tickets are free, so anyone can enjoy this 90 minute escapade of secret identity, love, and foolishness. In addition to the general audience, we have a variety of arts education programs and school groups attending, introducing kids to theater for the first time!

Producing a show that's free to the public costs money. The money we raise in this campaign will directly fund the following expenses:

Travel: $372

Space Rental: $575

Marketing: $200

Insurance: $200

Administrative Fees: $470

Costumes, Set, and Props: $300

Artist Fees: $1436

Your donation will help us introduce theater to new and under-served communities by allowing us to offer tickets free of charge. 

Bon Voyage, and see you at the show!


Twelfth Night is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Twelfth Night must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Twelfth Night will be performed June 15th-23rd at The Access Theater in NYC, and June 25th & 26th on the beach in Stonington, CT. Reserve your tickets here: https://www.artful.ly/store/events/9147
About the show: 
After a shipwreck, Viola is stranded on the island of Illyria and disguises herself as a man. Soon she falls madly in love with the Duke Orsino, who is madly in love with the Countess Olivia, who is madly in love with Viola (in disguise)! But wait! The snobbish servant Malvolio loves Olivia too! As does the moronic knight Sir Andrew! And that’s all before Viola’s twin brother Sebastian, thought to be lost at sea, washes ashore and gets tossed into the madness as well.    How You Can Help Like all Glass Eye Summer Shakespeare productions, Twelfth Night tickets are free, so anyone can enjoy this 90 minute escapade of secret identity, love, and foolishness. In addition to the general audience, we have a variety of arts education programs and school groups attending, introducing kids to theater for the first time!
Producing a show that's free to the public costs money. The money we raise in this campaign will directly fund the following expenses:
Travel: $372
Space Rental: $575
Marketing: $200
Insurance: $200
Administrative Fees: $470
Costumes, Set, and Props: $300
Artist Fees: $1436
Your donation will help us introduce theater to new and under-served communities by allowing us to offer tickets free of charge. 
Bon Voyage, and see you at the show!

    
Twelfth Night is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Twelfth Night must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Welcome to the campaign page for “My Big Heart: On”

They say the best way to get your work out there is to produce it yourself. That's great, except it costs a lot of money to do so. As your typical paycheck-to-paycheck starving actor in NYC, it's hard to find the funds. As Shakespeare said, “The struggle doth be real.”

I suppose I could always live on the streets for a couple of months to save on rent; but it's really hot outside, sunscreen is expensive, and I haven't found any Yelp reviews for the best cardboard boxes to live in. I could always sleep in the subway, but that's gross and you can't Snapchat down there. 

That’s why I've found myself here at Indiegogo, the headquarters for independent gogo dancers.

OK, but what about the show? 

“My Big Heart: On” is taken from my experiences with women, and presented as a hilarious (I think), and sometimes heartbreaking (to me, at least), retrospective journey through my past. 

Basically, it's a show about relationships and the realization that being a nice guy doesn't make you a good guy. 

And who the heck are you? 

I'm Brandon Duncan, a writer and actor with a passion for life, love, and speaking my mind in creative yet accessible ways. 

Basically, I'm a guy who likes to connect with people and make them feel. 

Reviews about me: 

The New York Times:

"...a hilarious Mr. Duncan in drag...resembles Phyllis Diller more than she does a Disney queen."-Laurel Graeber (Don't worry, I'm not in drag in this show. No one needs to see that...)

DC Metro Theatre Arts:

"...[Duncan's] comic prowess cuts to the quick of each articulated funny bone. Like all great comic actors, though, his style is layered with gravitas and restraint."-Terry Byrne

The Duncan Household:

"I've never missed a show of his. He's the greatest thing since sliced bread...actually, sliced bread isn't that great."-Mom

What does my money buy? 

-My happiness. 
-Your happiness (Check out the incentives to the right!).
-Theatre rental, props, set pieces, printing/advertising, future festival fees. 
-My Director, Jill Carucci.

Speaking of whom:

Who is Jill Carucci? 

Jill is a great friend of mine (and occasional writing partner...well, we try) and is currently the Industry Practicum Director at CAP21. She is a resident  teaching artist with McCarter Theatre Center and co-founder of Tunnel Theatre Company. She most recently directed Alice Ripley's All Sondheim cabaret at 54 Below.

Having her on board also makes for a 50% less boring cast party. 


So there you have it! 

Please consider giving us whatever you can. Every little bit counts. Truly. 

We are having an eight show run 11/12-11/15, so spread the word, follow the show on Facebook, tell your friends and wealthy family members. 

Thank you in advance, and I look forward to showing you “My Big Heart: On”

story:
The Center of an Epic, in Portland Oregon

Synopsis: 

In the dead of night, Troy was massacred. By morning, all men are dead, and the city burns. The women and children left alive try to cope with the new ‘normal.’ The occupying Greek power grapples with the aftershocks of a war that lasted ten years. 

Since its first production in 415 BCE, The Trojan Women has been celebrated as a titan of world literature. This fresh adaptation pays homage to civilian victims of war, and honors the struggle individual soldiers endure to keep light in their hearts during and after duty.

Already in development for more than two years, Women of Troy is now moving into its next stage! We invite you to join our campaign to produce the world premiere of this exhilarating new version with an inaugural run of 15 performances in Portland, Oregon. 

Participate

Women of Troy began development in February 2014 with actors and staff donating their time and expertise. Taking part in this campaign will ensure that the actors, technicians, and other collaborators working on Women of Troy will be compensated for their beautiful, rigorous, and inspired work. 

Funds raised will also cover important necessities on the business side of a theatre production, such as rehearsal and performance space, printing for posters and programs, as well as props and costumes.

Impact

When a story stands the test of time for more than 2,000 years, it is an excellent starting point for mind-blowing theatre! Under the ugliness of war and brutality, Women of Troy is a beautiful story about individual strength. It is about personal courage and holding on to hope in the face of extreme loss, suffering, and fear. Inasmuch as any myth will always be about ‘Now,’ Women of Troy inspires by showing people who keep going long past their breaking points. That is always a real life victory. As such, the project is about giving a gift of optimism.

What do you get in return? (Besides warm, fuzzy feelings?)

This is truly a story worth telling. We want to thank each person who helps our production blossom! Each level of giving garners an awesome set of THANK YOU PERKS. 

If you decide to donate anonymously, we welcome and appreciate your gift. Regrettably, we will not be able to send you your thank you perks, because we will be unable to contact you.

PERK Timing

Facebook / Twitter Mentions:  Before opening.

Mailed Items:  After opening.

Downloadable Items:  After opening.

After party details – Opening Night, venue and time TBA.

Spotlight thanks:  Opening night.

story:
We believe passionately in social justice. We advocate for it through the arts. That's why we program pieces like AS ONE, an opera about a Transgender person. We know that we can change and open minds through our work.

UrbanArias has been producing critically acclaimed work for five years. Our mission is to bring new audiences to the opera by programming work that is SHORT, CURRENT, and RELEVANT. Past successes include PAUL'S CASE, an opera we produced in both DC and New York City about a gay teen, and BLUE VIOLA, an NEA-supported commission which featured inner-city African-American characters.

We need to raise just a bit more money to completely fund our production of AS ONE and put us over the top. We want to move people with a beautiful story of a transgender protagonist, and educate people about transgender issues. This short opera, AS ONE, will bring these issues to a whole new public.

With your contribution, you will help bring a trans person's story to life, to share that story with people who have not heard it, and who know very little about the issues facing this community. AS ONE highlights many stepping stones on a trans person's journey: the confusion they feel, the censure they experience from educators and family, and the threat of violence they face from an ignorant and hostile public. And yet, our protagonist transcends all this, finds acceptance of herself, and true inner peace.

Your contribution will fund our production.

Opera is expensive. We pay our singers, our instrumentalists, our stage director, our scenic, costume and lighting designers, our conductor, our stage crew, and our stage manager. We build the set, make the costumes, rent lights. Trans filmmaker Kimberly Reed has created a film that goes with AS ONE - we need to rent a sophisticated projector to show it.

Ticket sales account for about 20-25% of our total production costs; this is normal for opera. So we need tax-deductible donations to make up the rest.

For a $100 donation, you get a fabulous UrbanArias t-shirt! These sell out at all of our shows - simply but beautifully made, they feature our sleek logo on the front and our subversive motto on the back - "If you're looking for a quickie, this is your opera company."

$75 gets you a poster created by top DC marketing firm LMO, SIGNED by the cast; $50 gets you YOUR OWN NAME sung in an opera video by our cast.

Feeling even more generous? $150 gets you a private voice lesson with classically-trained Broadway veteran Susan Derry; $200 gets you a conducting lesson with UrbanArias founder Robert Wood; $250 gets you a special sneak preview of AS ONE at one of our dress rehearsals, and $500 gets you tickets to the show - PLUS DRINKS!

Every dollar we raise will go to our advocacy through art. And because we are a non-profit, every dollar you contribute is fully tax-deductible to the extent provided by law.

    Art Changes Lives. Music Changes Minds.

    Small initiatives can open minds one at a time. Major news stories reach millions of people, but an intimate theatrical production gets at your heart and soul. When you go to an UrbanArias performance, you see every facial expression of the cast, and you don't just hear every note they sing, you FEEL them resonate in your own body. Personal connections like these are what move people. They may feel bombarded by media, but at UrbanArias, they come to be moved, and leave broadened.

    AS ONE informs and educates people about the Transgender community, and arouses compassion. Your donation helps that compassion happen.

    UrbanArias is no stranger to LGBT issues and causes. Our world premiere of PAUL'S CASE got stunning reviews in the New York Times, the Wall St. Journal, and the Washington Post. The New Yorker named us one of the Top Ten performances of 2014. We reminded people that gay teen suicide is a serious issue, and we reached people who were not keyed into this issue, but who told us how moved and motivated they were by our performance. Art Works.

      Raising money for opera is always a challenge. People tell us it's an elite art form, or that it's old-fashioned. We know they're wrong. We have proven that by sculpting this venerable art form into a modern package - one that delivers its message in the same amount of time as a feature film, and that is sung in English - we can reach people who thought opera wasn't for them, and make converts of them.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute, we understand - but please help us get the word out about AS ONE! Share our advocacy efforts with your friends on Facebook, Twitter . . . anywhere and everywhere. And if you do contribute, please also - share, share share!

story:
The acting troupe entitled Amber’s Sweets is bringing the rising cult phenomenon ‘Repo! The Genetic Opera’ to Sacramento audiences by way of spectacle. Part horror film, part rock-opera, the feature film plays in the background as live actors bring the world of Repo! to life on stage in screen accurate costumes, sets, and with plenty of fake blood and gore to drench those daring enough to sit in the “splash zone”.

This stunning combination of film, live theatre, aerial acrobatics and special effects will be held at the Historic Colonial Theatre in Sacramento, CA.

Receiving five stars from the Sacramento Press and the San Francisco Chronicle, ‘Repo! Live’ has been called “an abundance of guts, gore, blood, skimpy clothing, swearing, and audience participation.” and “an impressive, elaborate production that feels like a live concert.”

Please see what we are all about at http://www.AmbersSweets.com

story:
Our Story

We're a developing theatre company working in NYC with artists from around the world. We were born in December 2009 and have presented work by Tennesse Williams and now Austin Pendleton.


Mississippi Mud Productions is proud to present the first NYC revival of Orson's Shadow this fall. It's a special play about art, love, memory and dreams.


The Impact

We had a wonderfully successful fundraiser in March however we were $1500 short of our goal. This is a chance to make a difference supporting innovative and brave art in NYC with an Indie theatre company. Your support helps us meet the cost of this production and thus enables us to go for the future.


What We Need & What You Get

The $1500 will go towards paying for props, costumes, lighting, sound, hair and makeup and Orson's steaks fundamental to the action! And of course the actors. Come be a part of the glamour, grit and greasepaint. Depending on what you give there are a fun array of perks to select from. Want to spend an hour with Austin Pendleton and the cast having cocktails? 


Other Ways You Can Help

As you know we couldn't do what we do without you. So please...help us spread the word. Share this link!!! Tell us who sent you when you stop by and visit. Post it on Facebook and go like our page while you're there! https://www.facebook.com/MississippiMudProductions Tweet away. It's all about the grassroots after all.


Anything above and beyond the $1500 will go towards Mud projects planned for 2012!! If we don't make our $1500 goal, well we're a resourceful bunch and we'll make it happen!


Please join us at our show - it's going to be a great production. And we've got 8 talkback dates with playwright Austin Pendleton and team.

story:
In Short...

In the few short semesters since the creation Temple University's chapter of Alpha Psi Omega, the National Honorary Theatre Society, they have received more requests than they could count for increased opportunities to do undergraduate work. From this, the Backstage Season was born. A season that runs paralell to the Temple Mainstage season and serves to enhance the quality and consistency of student works in Theater.

Shakespeare's Julius Caesar is the first show we want to tackle. But unfortunately, the department doesn't have the funds needed for us to fully realize this work. That is where you lovely people come in!

As far as our concept for the show; it's pretty snazzy. We're doing the show on the front steps of our theatre - where we feel so at home that we consider it our city hall. We are setting it in modern society and gender bending, making it more accessible to the modern audience. We also want to command the space: To be in your face with the political nature of the show, reflected in the presidential elections the week our show runs. We also want to bring Shakespeare to people who may just happen across it. In this way, we hope to provide opportunities for people involved in the show, as well as people experiencing the show.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money. Sad, but true.

We are looking at a $550 budget for our entire production - lights, sets, costumes, etc. That's not a ton of money, but we know we will be able to put up a splendid show for that amount.

The technical aspects of the show is where the money will end up going - whatever we raise. Lumber, costumes, electric rentals - all that fun stuff we need to perform.

However much we raise - that is our budget. If we only raise $100, then we will do a very minimalistic show. If we raise over our expected budget - the excess will go toward any unprecidented expences and then be tucked away to support more student projects next semester. And belive me, there will be more this spring. And, not to fret, you will hear about them!

We have perks (not to mention great theatre)!

  • $1 - Our UNDYING Love and Gratitude
  • $10 - A Special Thanks Credit in the Playbill, and a copy of said Playbill
  • $15 - A physical manifestation of our Love and Gratitude - A handmade friendship bracelet!
  • $25 - A Signed Publicity Poster, friendship bracelet, and Special Thanks Credit & Playbill
  • $50 - Two reserved seats at a show, a signed poster, a friendship bracelet, and a Special Thanks Credit
  • $100 - We invite you to a feast! Well, it's dinner. But the director, designers, and executive board of Julius Caesar will be there. Unfortunately, we cannot afford your plane ticket to Philadelphia, so you'll need to be from around here. But if not - we invite you to a Skype Dinner instead! That's close, right? We'll have a feast and chat about the show over the internet! Also included is the Poster, reserved seats, friendship bracelet, Credit, & Playbill.

The Impact

We are here to provide opportunities. Many of the undergraduates do not get to perform, as we only have a limited number of shows a season. That's the sad reality of theatre. But with this show, we are hoping to reach more people.

But this is not just for the actors. Many undergraduate designers only get to see their designs in one-inch scale. We want to provide a space for their designs and passions to be realized as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute - please spread the word! We love you all.

The Show

Performances will be Thursday-Saturday November 8-10 at 5:00pm - dusk. There will also be a 2:00pm matinee on Saturday the 10th. There will be a preview performance at 5:00 on Wednesday, November 7. Sunday the 11th will be a rain date.

All tickets are pay-what-you-can on a first-come, first-served basis.

$100 - We invite you to a feast! Well, it's dinner. But the director, designers, and executive board of Julius Caesar will be there. Unfortunately, we cannot afford your plane ticket to Philadelphia, so you'll need to be from around here. But if not - we invite you to a Skype Dinner instead! That's close, right? We'll have a feast and chat about the show over the internet! Also included is the Poster, reserved seats, friendship bracelet, Credit, & Playbill.

The Impact


We are here to provide opportunities. Many of the undergraduates do not get to perform, as we only have a limited number of shows a season. That's the sad reality of theatre. But with this show, we are hoping to reach more people.
But this is not just for the actors. Many undergraduate designers only get to see their designs in one-inch scale. We want to provide a space for their designs and passions to be realized as well.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute - please spread the word! We love you all.
The Show
Performances will be Thursday-Saturday November 8-10 at 5:00pm - dusk. There will also be a 2:00pm matinee on Saturday the 10th. There will be a preview performance at 5:00 on Wednesday, November 7. Sunday the 11th will be a rain date.All tickets are pay-what-you-can on a first-come, first-served basis.

story:
Summary

Hi!  I'm Abby, and I'm a professional hula hooper.  In 2008, I left an 8-year marketing career to pursue my hoop dance business.  My company specializes in professional, hand-made dance hoops for fitness and fun.  I also run a performance troupe, teach hoop dance classes, and entertain children at birthday parties and special events.

This campaign is to raise funds for a kids' hoop dance DVD.  This project is wildly important to me because it will impact the lives of children by promoting happy, healthy play with hoops.  It will also promote creativity and self confidence through music and dance.

In a far away land, there is a place called Hooperville... a magical, colorful world that's united by love and imagination.  In Hooperville, monsters roam the town, but they aren't the type of monsters  you've ever seen before.  These happy, creative beings are called Hoola Monsters, and they have special powers.

When Hoola Monsters spin their magic hoops, wishes are granted and dreams come true.  But right now, the monsters are trapped!  They exist only in the mind of their creator.

This is a campaign to FREE THE HOOLA MONSTERS so they can spread joy, good health and confidence to children all over the world.

What We Need & What You Get

I currently have one investor on board (Yippie!!!) but I still need to generate funds for attorney's fees, which will support operating agreements, talent contracts, music licenses, and work for hire forms.

I will also put funds raised towards grassroots marketing efforts to promote the DVD. I have been invited to go on tour with a national, traveling music festival in the summer of 2013.  There, I will introduce hoop dance to tens of thousands of kids at every show!  I'll do this by performing on stage and selling the DVD at the merchandise booth (where I will also offer mini lessons to the kids)!  This is a great opportunity to promote the DVD, but unfortunately, there isn't a performance art budget available.  So, part of the funds generated with this campaign will go towards the tour.

This campaign will also support hoop-making help.  Up until now, I have been hand-crafting every hoop that's sold through my company.  I have a team of people ready to jump in and assist, and I need to have funds available for compensation and materials. (Professional hoops will be sold with the DVD).

I have a big vision for this project.  This includes original art and set design elements, as well as fantastic videography and editing. 

If I don't reach my entire goal, the funds will still go to the DVD project.  As mentioned, I have one investor who is already committed.  The DVD is happening, and the sooner I can generate the remaining 10K, the quicker we can move forward with the project.  We are so excited to get started!  I should also mention the DVD will be very movement-centered/ participatory. Children will get a great workout!

So, what's in it for you?  I'm offering all kinds of great incentives... from hand-made children's dance hoops to early releases of the DVD and music CDs!  I will be extending invitations to our DVD launch party, with special hoop dance performances, giveaways, live music and appearances by the Hoola Monsters!  To learn more about my company, check out www.hoolamonsters.com 

The Impact

"Live your life from your heart.  Share from your heart.  And your story will touch and heal people's souls." ~ by Melody Beattie

Hoop dance promotes creativity, self confidence, good health (both physical and mental), well-being and imagination.  I have seen it transform the lives of people young and old.  

When children realize that the "impossible" is "possible,"it enables them to dream big. I believe that play and imagination make the world a better place.

Meanwhile, there is an obesity epedemic in our country.  On average, hoop dance burns 420 calories an hour.  Fitness experts agree that when exercise feels like play instead of work, then the liklihood of "sticking with it" increases exponentially.

My company was the first full service hoop dance company to open in the state of Florida. In 2012, I also launched a hoop dance curriculm that received approval by the American Council on Exercise.  I have been quoted as a hoop dance expert in media outlets nationwide.

I have the experience, passion and dedication to create an amazing DVD that children  and parents will love.  The DVD will be supported by original music with inspirational messaging.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute financially, and support comes in many ways.  Maybe you'd consider:

  • Helping to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign

  • Indiegogo has lots of great share tools!  Maybe you are connected to someone who would like to support this project?  Sharing is caring :)

Indiegogo has lots of great share tools!  Maybe you are connected to someone who would like to support this project?  Sharing is caring :)

story:
Adapted from Franz Kafka’s Metamorphosis, the peculiar yet self-aware story of a man who wakes up one morning inexplicably transformed into a giant beetle, this is a production that is surprising in both its tragedy and its universal nature. 

 

Through an exploration of movement, manipulations of physical bodies and seemingly ordinary set pieces, and rich text, Matt’s adaptation questions what we do when confronted with a newly-inaccessible family member, someone we are meant to support unceasingly and without question, and the difficulty of caring for someone we no longer understand. The show also seeks an understanding of the other side of such a situation, that of Gregor, suddenly foreign in his own body and completely alienated from the people who are meant to love him most of all.

 

It’s a show about speaking, about not speaking, about discovering when your own needs take precedence above all others. It’s dark, and fascinating, and engaging, and our team can’t wait to share it with audiences.

 

But, before we can do that, Metamorphosis needs your support! In order to ensure that we can bring this entirely undergraduate produced, directed, acted, and designed production to Northwestern, we ask you to consider becoming a supporter of the production by contributing any generous donation to our production’s budget, in whatever amount you are comfortable giving. Even a small contribution goes a long way!

 

We are hoping to fundraise so thoroughly that we can avoid the usual $5 admission, instead opting for pay-as-you-can and putting the funds towards Josie Nordman, a peer of ours at NU whom the theatre community has rallied around to raise money for her very expensive and very necessary lung transplant.

  • Grete: Danica Rosengren
  • Gregor: Jake Drummond
  • Father: Ben Dorfman
  • Mother: Kathryn Watts
  • Anna: Elsa Gay
  • Manager: Rashaad Spence
  • Hans: Khari Shelton

Production Team

  • Dramaturg: Samantha Mueller
  • Costume Designer: Cassie Bowers

  • Technical Director: JJ Marquis
  • Master Electrician: Bobby Ramirez
  • Lighting Designer: Gracie Schwartzenberger
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Maddie Burg
    • Lighting Mentor: Alison Mahoney
  • Sound Designer: Kathy Hong
    • Sound Mentor: Mitch Johnston
  • Set Designer: Jack Eidson
  • Scenic Painter: Wyatt Fair
  • Properties Designer: Jacob Trauberman
    • Assistant Properties Designer: Daniel Bender Stern
  • Publicity Director: Brandon Johnston
    • Publicity Team: Justine Gelfman and Aurora Real de Asua
  • Fundraising Director: Laura Smith
    • Fundraising Team: Jacob Trauberman
  • Snack Designer: Olivia Probetts
    • Assistant Snack Designer: Scott Egleston
  • Tech Week Joy Ninja: Kyle Sherman
  • Dream Goddesses: Emily Fishkin, Sarah Cartwright
  • Social Chair: Phoebe Gonzalez
  • Violin Coach: David Corlew

story:
The Denizens Theater Company was created with the aim to craft compelling productions that showcase the diverse and ever-changing world we live in.  Formed in 2017 by two women, DTC seeks to establish a local creative community. Through relatable themes, unique stage design, non-traditional casting, and outreach efforts, our goal is to redefine the theatrical experience,  making it accessible to all. 

Our inaugural season is entitled “Woman is a Word.”

Each piece selected, chronicles the formidable experience of woman. The characters featured demand focus, equality, empathy, and a rejection of the status quo. Our next performance will be “Marisol” by Jose Rivera. The setting is the end of the world in NYC, completely destroyed as a result of a vicious war in heaven. Marisol, a Puerto Rican woman, goes head to head with angels, nazis, and pregnant men, perilously navigating her way from the Bronx to her best friend in Brooklyn.

We are asking for donations for: 

  • Renting and providing seats for our audience. 
  • Purchasing props, designing, and building our set. 

Please give whatever amount you wish at the door or suggested $10 here. Your donation gets you into the party, featuring: 

-Life-size Jenga and board games galore. 

-An exclusive performance of a scene from our upcoming show. 

Raffle tickets are also available. Prizes include a bottle of small-batch gin, free classes at Chaise Fitness, tickets to our show, and more.

Thank you for your genorsity!

story:
“People think laughter means you are not a serious person because we live in a world so technically oriented and competitive. If you are not serious, you are no one, you will not make it. Steve Jobs did not become boss of Apple by laughing. This is the kind of thinking we are fighting against.”

Lee Delong, director

 

Engaged theatre

One would be curious why Dario Fo's „Mistero buffo“, a Nobel prize winner, famous for turning the image of popes, kings and politicians upside down, never had a theatre premiere in Zagreb, Croatia? The play is telling episodes from the lives of saints, uncovering the myths and making politicians and religious leaders naked in front of the audience, giving people the power in seeing the world with their own eyes.

This is one of the most challenging and intriguing solo pieces, done in Zagreb, Croatia. It represents the engaged theatre form whose function is to enlighten, initiating a form of individual thinking and attitude. Because of all that “Mistero Buffo” is an exceptional piece of theatre, cause all it does, and the way it is done, is directed towards humans and the idea of individual freedom.

 

Performed by

Dražen Šivak is one of the most versatile actors in this part of Europe. His approach is one of total actor’s theatre, where a performer needs no props, using his own body and voice to perform a range of complex situations and relationships. “Mistero Buffo”, as a true challenge for a modern actor, is just the right challenge calling upon versatile actors of Commedia dell’arte and their skillfulness, always in contact with the time and context surrounding them.

 

What we need

We need to raise 3.500 USD to cover productions costs as the production company Grupa did not receive any support from the Ministry of Culture and the City of Zagreb. Donations will cover play rights, costume, theatre rental, director's expenses (travel and accommodation costs), design and print, lightning and sound, adverts and promotion. It is important for us that you know that the team is donating their time and resources - we will not be collecting any of the money personally.

Your support for this project is a statement of social responsibility and philanthropic investment in art!

End of January is our D day, the preparations are in full swing!

As participants of the independent art scene, today we need, more than ever, support to bring this play to life. This is a project of social awareness in its beginning. Any donation is appreciated, investing in this project, with a strong note of social responsibility, brings along a gratitude and each of the donators will receive a gift from the production company, and of our great designer Klara Rusan.

 

We are..

Successful in different theatre styles, Dražen Šivak has played a wide range of roles – from classical ones in the National theatre in Zagreb (HNK Zagreb) to non-verbal theatre. As a stage movement expert, he has worked at the National Academy (ADU) for 7 years, he initiated the successful THEARTO project of educating children, invited on behalf of State Department to USA as the first person from the arts and culture field from this part of Europe, and recently has been invited to be part of the Nouveau Clown Institute in Barcelona. His last performance, “Democracy” with Zijah A. Sokolović, has won 10 theatre awards in the region. He has won the National actor’s award three times.

Lee Delong, director. American-French actress living and working in France, and Europe too, for the last 30 years. Educated formally at the Theatre department of West Virginia University, she continued at Ecole Jacques Lecoq in Paris, and then with Peter Brook at Bouffes du Nord. Lee writes, directs and teaches, too. She was the acting coach at Jasmila Žbanić’s movie “On the road” and assistant director/choreographer/writer of lyrics at Žbanić’s movie “Love island”. Lee is very well acquainted with the work of the Italian artist Dario Fo.

For her solo performance “Woman alone” of Dario Fo and Franca Rame, she has won the audience award and best actress award ad MESS in Sarajevo in 2007., the award for virtuosity in Mostar in 2009. Performance was made at Theatre du Chaudron, la Cartoucherie in Paris. She often plays in the legendary Theatre du Chatelet in Paris, in works of Emilio Sagi and Robert Carsen.

   Jana Šivak, producer. She has been working as an independent producer since  2004. in performing arts, festivals, has a long year experience as event manager for corporations, worked on short features, documentary and animated films, followed different training courses and participated in many co-production and pitching forums. Her point of interest turns towards the film education for kindergarten and primary school children. Recently she has joined the production team of Children's rights festival and at this point her professional career continues in the field of media and film literacy of children and young people. She enjoys working with his brother in the production company Grupa trying to bring to life new plays and creative ways of producing.

story:
I truly believe that my life’s work is to make theatre training programs and the theatre industry as a whole more inclusive of trans, gender non-conforming and non-binary artists. This show is one that I hope to be able to expand to a full-length work in the future. 

But I need your help! Your donations will help cover the bare minimum of production costs as well as provide comp tickets to LGBTQ+ youth for every show. 

A Genderqueer Cabaret opens on my 32nd birthday. The costs I’m hoping to cover are broken out below. If we’re able to raise $932, all the ticket sales from the show will be able to go directly to the artists: myself, my director and my accompanist. 

I’ve been able to get publicity photography donated (thanks, Panfocal Photography) and am doing all the promotion and graphic design myself. I believe in frugal, well-produced shows that leave the audience with something to think about (in this case, disrupting the gender binary!) 


Production costs: 

$500: Small venue rental fee
$200: Boulder Fringe Festival listing fee
$80: Radical hospitality tickets: 2 set aside for each show for those for whom the ticket price would prevent them from seeing the show
$110: Publicity (printing/shipping of postcards and program printing)
$42: crowd-funding fees

I’ve been able to get publicity photography donated (thanks, Panfocal Photography) and am doing all the promotion and graphic design myself. I believe in frugal, well-produced shows that leave the audience with something to think about (in this case, disrupting the gender binary!)

story:
Help Spread Improv and Help create equal opportunities in comedy for women:

  • Anjali, Jahnavi and Suhani, are India's first all women Improv trio who have been invited to the international Improv Festival.
  • In April 2018 we will participate in the all women Femproviser fest 2018 held in San Francisco.Femproviser Fest 2018  http://www.femprovisorfest.com/
  • With your contributions we will be able to ensure that women in India are represented on an international level of Improv Comedy and Theatre.
  • All money will go for buying Plane tickets, covering visa fees, accommodation and learning expenses

We need your support & in return you will receive lots of love and admiration in the form of shout outs, and passes to our shows.

  • We will be Paying for 3 flight tickets costing $1300 per ticket, $200 for Visa fees per person, and $1500 for accommodation for 3
  • Depending on your donation the more personalised reward you will receive.
  • If our goal isn't met we wont be able to send all the performers.

The Number of women in Comedy is growing in India but there is still a lot of work to be done for Improv Comedy and Theatre

  • Improv promotes listening and communication between cultures
  • In a world where communication and harmony is at its worst it is important to invest in something that builds equality and an international community across borders.

We have applied for our Visas in advance, the only thing holding us back is the money to buy our Flight tickets.

  • We have been working really hard at practicing our skills as improvisors and training consistently to shell out good quality improv theatre.
  • We have a bunch of trained and professionally working actors as a part of our trio who are awaiting your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • It would be a tremendous help if you contribute, but for those who cant, please help us spread the word by sharing our campaign, and help us reach people who are ready to support our cause.
  • To do the same you can use the Indiegogo share tools, and we will forever be thankful to you.

Depending on your donation the more personalised reward you will receive.
If our goal isn't met we wont be able to send all the performers.

Improv promotes listening and communication between cultures
In a world where communication and harmony is at its worst it is important to invest in something that builds equality and an international community across borders.
We have applied for our Visas in advance, the only thing holding us back is the money to buy our Flight tickets.
We have been working really hard at practicing our skills as improvisors and training consistently to shell out good quality improv theatre.
We have a bunch of trained and professionally working actors as a part of our trio who are awaiting your support.
Other Ways You Can Help
It would be a tremendous help if you contribute, but for those who cant, please help us spread the word by sharing our campaign, and help us reach people who are ready to support our cause.
To do the same you can use the Indiegogo share tools, and we will forever be thankful to you.

story:
Since 1989, hereandnow Theatre Company has been producing plays in Los Angeles and touring the nation with original shows, sharing our voices and stories from our beloved communities.

We are very excited about our latest piece "The Brahmin and the Tiger".   This magical play is an accumulation of some of the Asian American and Asian folktales that we have collected over the past twenty years, along with the premiere of new narratives, featuring an original score with live music and Taiko. Co-produced with Company of Angels, the longest running repertory theatre company in Los Angeles,  it will be one of the largest productions hereandnow has ever undertaken.

With the rising costs to do quality theatre here in LA, we are asking for your help to make this play a success.  It is our goal to raise $3000.00  for this production.  With your generosity, we will be able to bring this show to life.

The Brahmin and the Tiger
             And other stories of love, loss and courage in between.

The Brahmin & the Tiger:  and other stories of love, loss and courage in between, is a collection of fairy tales gathered from throughout Asia and the Pacific Islands. Blending oral tradition with an original score and live Taiko, these stories will entertain and delight people of all ages.

Directed by John Miyasaki
Composed by Masato Baba
Produced by Rudy Marquez
Stage Manager: Dennis Bover
Assistant Stage Manager: Alex Ximenez
Scenic Design: Sasha Monge
Lighting Design: Bosco Flanagan
Costume Design: Ken Takemoto
Graphic Design & Typography: Xavi Moreno

Featuring
Michael Hagiwara
Diana Toshiko
Tripp Pickell
Rona Par
Jully Lee
Samantha Valdellon
Kamil Haque
Victor Chi
Masato Baba
Jen Baik
David Wells

For more info and to purchase tickets, please go to: http://companyofangels.org/the-brahmin-the-tige...

story:
Hello and thank you for checking out my page! This little acrobat-turned-aerialist needs your help! If I wish to achieve my goal of becoming a full fledged aerialist, I'll need a trapeze to call my own. Come autumn, I will no longer have access to the equipment I've been training on, which could mean the untimely demise of my dream. I'm only a trapeze away from truly taking flight. Read on to learn more!

My Story

Eight years ago, I made a choice that would forever change my future, and alter my life in ways I never thought imaginable. That choice was to follow a dream. But not just any dream. It was one of those big dreams that you keep tucked away inside because most people would shake their heads and chuckle, or else tell you that it could never be done, so why bother? For me that dream was to be in the circus.


And so, in 2003 I was accepted at the National Circus School of Montreal, one of the best circus schools in the world! I wanted nothing more than to be an aerialist, but in the end, the school had other plans for me. I started off on aerial silks, but it wasn't a good fit for me. After some happy accidents, I found my way to the German wheel. I still wanted to minor in an aerial discipline while at school, but by that point, it was decided that I didn't have the flexibility and just wasn't cut out for aerials. I best stick to the ground like a good little acrobat.


I'd be lying if I said I wasn't completely smitten with German wheel. But it would also be a lie to say that the little voice in my heart that started me on my circus journey ever stopped looking skyward and sighing.


And so, after working as an acrobat for the last five years, I've decided to take hold of my dream once more and shape it in the way I've always imagined. I'm going to become an aerialist and specialize in static trapeze!


The Impact

Completely changing disciplines may seem like a huge task, but the reality is, once you've started circus work, your base becomes so strong that every time you take on a new discipline, the learning time becomes shorter and shorter. What really makes a difference is the time you are able to commit to learning the new skill, and the resources available.


Leaving school has meant losing access to coaching and equipment, which makes it difficult and sometimes dangerous to develop new skills. The fees for hiring private coaches and renting training space add up startlingly fast and most people can only afford a few classes at a time. As a result, the time needed to master new techniques and to create a commercially viable act ends up being spread over a long period of time. Typically, this is counterproductive as the creation process is driven by continuous work, and technical development requires consistent practice. As a result, many new acts fail to see the light of day because the artist just can't commit the time and resources to their chosen artistic endeavour while simultaneously supporting themselves.


When I began this project, I was amazed by how quickly the various costs began to add up. But I've waited long enough to fully realize my dream, so this is the year that I'm biting the bullet and jumping in head first. My pockets may be lighter, but because I've been training with a coach so consistently, I've been able to master difficult skills quickly (in a month or less). And by remaining focused on act development, I've been able to delve much deeper into the creative process, and maintain an environment where artistic growth has been able to flourish.


What makes me different from other trapezists? Very often, a static trapeze act will showcase flexibility (of which I have little) and poses. As a strong, skilled acrobat, my goal is to transform traditional trapeze into something a little more explosive. I want to explore how acrobatics performed on the ground can be transferred to a trapeze, and create a daring act that balances bold, dynamic tricks with artistic vision. Contemporary circus, being about more than tricks, combines dance, emotive depth, and being able to project to an audience. All of this is necessary for a truly exceptional act, which is where my years of performance experience in both theatre and contemporary circus will be an enormous asset.


So far I've been funding classes and studio rental on my own. But the equipment I've been working on has been borrowed. If I want to find work, and continue training and developing my skills when I go back on tour in the fall, I  will need my own trapeze.


What happens if I don't reach my goal? I believe Samuel Beckett said it best: "Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try again. Fail again. Fail better."


This is already my second attempt at funding. The first was a grant application with the Canada Council for the Arts. While I was told that my project had merit and was highly recommended for funding, my application was unsuccessful due to a lack of available funds...


What I Need

A trapeze to call my very own!

All funds raised that cover the primary goal of $1500 will be used to purchase a trapeze and basic rigging. (carbiners and webbing). I know $1500 seems like a lot, but when you factor in the cost of materials, labour, taxes, and the fact that a trapeze is highly specialized equipment that you can't pick up just anywhere, you can see why the cost is so elevated.

If the fundraising gods smile upon me and I manage to raise more than $1500, that money will also be put to good use! Depending on the amount raised, any extra funds would go toward the following:

  • Gaiters (protective shin guards that double as an element of costume) - $270
  • Having a costume made -  typically between $400 and $450
  • Portable, Inflatable crash mat (big tricks = big falls) - Price unknown, I'm still researching this.
  • Additional classes -  $50 per 1 hour class
  • The development of new promotional material (DVDs, business cards, website, etc.) - this will depend on how much I'm able to do myself.

What You Get

As you can see to your right, there are all kinds of fun perks. But! The really exciting part is that you will be able to follow me on my journey of transformation into an aerialist! As classes progress and I get further and further into the creation process, I'll post updates on how things are going, and share my insights on being a professional circus artist in the here and now!

Not only that, but in the circus we believe that those in the biz shouldn't have to pay to see shows. I will keep all donors up to date of where I will be preforming and if ever I happen to be someone near you, and you'd like to see a circus show, I will do my very best to get you in free of charge. It doesn't matter if you donate $1 or $1000. In circus, that's just how we roll.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! If this is a project that rings true to you, let your friends and family know about it! If it doesn't really resonate with you but probably would with one of your friends (you know the one), send this their way! I'm a firm believer in the power of one. Be it one voice, one gesture, or one dollar. Thanks for your support!

story:
UPDATE: STRETCH GOAL

THANK YOU THANK YOU for all of your contributions, we met our goal within the first 30 hours of our campaign!

All funds raised beyond our goal will help us ensure the artists involved in STATIONARY are properly compensated for their work.

Now we'd love to offer you more! If we can reach $3,000 we'll print a deluxe limited edition CD for everyone who has donated $25 or more. 

 

And of course if you would still like a digital copy of our Cast Recording or any of our other perks but haven’t donated yet, please feel free to contribute now and we will be more than happy to get them to you.

 

STATIONARY: a recession-era musical

Produced in July of 2012 by the Neanderthal Arts Festival and Delinquent Theatre, STATIONARY: a recession-era musical is a new musical written by Christine Quintana (book and lyrics), Mishelle Cuttler (music) and Brian Cochrane (rap lyrics).  STATIONARY follows the lives of 6 young people at a moment where big dreams meet reality checks.  Following our July production, we want STATIONARY to have a future, and you can help.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money to have 2 days of recording time in a professional recording studio, and a limited run of hard copy CDs to share with our fans and potential producers.  Check out our perks - we can offer everything from a digital copy of the cast recording to a private concert and a song written just for you.  

The Impact

A professional cast recording would help us in a variety of ways.

  • We would be able to share our music with folks who saw the original production and wanted to listen to it again and again
  • We can preserve the original performances and interpretation of our musical in this production
  • MOST EXCITINGLY: we have a quality recording of the show to help us in our future endeavors to extend and expand STATIONARY: a recession-era musical

The Bottom Line?

STATIONARY: a recession-era musical was a special experience for us, and from what we've heard, it was special for you too. Help us make a quality cast recording of our show, and we'll be happy to share it with you.  This recording is a big step towards the future of our little musical, and we hope you'll be a part of it.
