story:
Welcome to Rogue!

We are a performing arts troupe made up of almost thirty performers and musicians. We are located in Harford County Maryland where we have performed everything from concerts to traditional theatre, but we have become known for our modernized Vaudevilles. Songs from every genre woven together to give them a new twist and create a new story for our audience to enjoy.

Since COVID 19 shut live performances down we have adapted and taken to YouTube to keep entertaining people during an incredibly difficult time. We created a video series last spring on Youtube and performed a Halloween mixed media livestream event last October.

This year we are seeing the light at the end of the tunnel and cannot wait to get back in front of a live audience when it is safe for everyone. In order to do that we need your help.

So what is the game plan?

A new video series! But this time we thought we would mix it up and have our audience choose the songs we will cover. We have curated a collection of songs previously performed live over the years by Rogue and the songs with the most votes will be the ones chosen for the video series. 

Simply, your donation amount is the number of votes you receive. You can use those votes all on one song or spread them out however you want! Just email us at Rogueswantheatre@gmail.com with the name you listed in your donation and the songs you are voting for. 

Once the fundraiser ends we count the votes, announce the winning songs and then start making the videos. The videos will be released on our Youtube page beginning in late spring.

Now onto the important part! Here are the songs you can vote on:

Category A:

  • Chandelier - Sia
  • A Little Priest - Sweeney Todd
  • El Tango de Roxanne - Moulin Rogue
  • We Are Not Alone - Karla Devito
  • Guy What Takes His Time - Burlesque 
  • Mr.Blue Sky - Electric Light Orchestra 
  • Cabaret - Cabaret 
  • Your Fault - Into the Woods
  • Agony - Into the Woods
  • In a Big Country - Big Country
  • I Found a New Baby - Bullets Over Broadway
  • Big Yellow Taxi - Joni Mitchell
  • I Want to Hold Your Hand - The Beatles

Category B:

  • One Day More - Les Miserables
  • Big Spender - Sweet Charity
  • Don't Tell Mama - Cabaret
  • Ghost of Stephen Foster - Squirrel Nut Zippers
  • B*tch of Living - Spring Awakening
  • Bottom of the River - Delta Rae
  • All For the Best - Godspell

So again, what do you do?

Pick your perk, it shows the number of votes you get and once it is submitted just email us at Rogueswantheatre@gmail.com with your song selections.

If you can't donate right now, that's okay! Share the fundraiser and spread the word and check us out on Facebook and YouTube!

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCOW5fRopoXQOQr...

Thank you for helping our troupe keep moving during COVID! We can't wait to perform for you all again.

story:
Yes, you read the title right. With your help, I will be attempting to ride a pedal-start, vintage 2-stroke Puch Maxi in a 1400 mile, 5 day race.

A love story:

     It was just another balmy afternoon in Savannah, Georgia, when I laid eyes on her for the first time. She was leaning against the bike rack, nonchalant, stray sunlight gleaming through the grime she wore proudly. Dented, scratched, and weathered as she was, she was still a beautiful contraption; she had style, two wheels, a motor and… pedals?

     This moped, the name for a vintage motorized vehicle charmingly equipped with pedals, was my introduction to the world of cheap, temperamental transport.  For a kid starting college in a small city and a job at a pizza joint, the compact size and minimal expense to maintain, upgrade, and fuel made mopeds a good investment, and as I would learn, a growing obsession. From college freshman to college graduate, Savannah to Atlanta, not knowing what a carburetor was to getting an engine designed for 35mph to go 70, getting hit by cars to hitching rides in trucks, going to rallies as far away from Atlanta GA as New York City and Denver and meeting people from all over the country, the culture of the moped community has continued to occupy my life and fascinate me, leading me to the point of this introduction, and  with your help, my greatest moped test and adventure so far…. The Pinball Run.


The Pinball Run:

     Established in 2013, The Pinball Run: 2 Strokes to Paradise, Portland, ME to Key West, set a precedent of wonder and test of skill within the moped community worldwide.  The Pinball Run is a race, in which teams of moped riders from all over the country seek to push their mopeds, as well as themselves, to the limit, all the while making connections with fellow riders and others along the way across the country. 

     Hard Times to the Big Easy, The Pinball Run 2: The Adventures of Tomos Sawyer, is a 1400 mile, 5 day, moped race beginning on September 1st, 2014 from Minneapolis MN to New Orleans LA along the Mississippi river. Starting at the origin of the United States’ greatest river in Minneapolis, down through the flowing fields of the country’s heartland in Cedar Rapids, IA, St Louis, MO, Memphis, TN, on into the deep south of Jackson, MS, and finishing in the soaked delta plains of New Orleans, LA this year’s race is my first opportunity to participate in such an event.  After being unable to partake in the first race as I was finishing up my undergraduate in Printmaking, I am hoping to see parts of the country I have never experienced, accompanied by team members, and the gurus that introduced me to mopeds, Pat Norris and Tim Ostrum. Also joining our team are my good friends from Sumpter, SC, Charles Maynard, founder/ president of the Buzzards Moped Club, and co-founder/ secretary, Tommy Barwick.


Mopeds?

     Now you may still be wondering what constitutes a moped exactly. A moped is a class of motorized vehicle typically defined by the law as a two-wheeled vehicle powered by a single speed or automatic if multi-speed, motor up to, but not exceeding, 49 cubic centimeters in cylinder volume or displacement, with a top speed of 35 mph. these restrictions have allowed for minimal operational requirements, which vary from state to state but general only require a DOT helmet, working head light and tail light, and a valid learners permit. No plates, no registration, and no insurance.  Though the moped has mostly died out production wise after the late 80s to make way for the modern scooter, the DYI mentality, ease of modification, low cost, easy maintenance, fuel economy and minimal licensing requirements has given rise to a new cultural movement and community of young and old builders/riders/clubs that gather to rally throughout the year all over the nation with each group hosting an event in their major cities.  This community has engulfed me in a vast network of others seeking fun, alternative modes of transportation. 


Here's where you come in:

     In order to complete such a quest, a bold moped-er would need firstly, a moped, secondly, plenty of backup parts for motors, brake cables, tires, inner tubes, pistons, cylinders, clutches, and tools to fix these things. I will also need money for cheap accommodations along the way, food, and gas not only for the moped but for the chase vehicle, too.

Expenses list:

Chase vehicle/gas: $800

Moped gas for the ride: $100

Food for the week: $100

Moped build: $1,672

Portra 400 camera film roll of 20: $40


part quantity price $
Tomos sealed bearing axle 1 24
Tomos/Puch EBR disc brake forks 1 200
Tomos front disc brake caliper&piston 1 120
Sava MC11 moped tire 17"x2.5" 3 81
Sava MC11 moped tire 17"x2.25" 3 78
Puch Hero cylinder kit 3 240
Puch Hero replacement piston 3 105
Puch Monza cylinder head 2 110
moped inner tube 6 48
Mike Thomas Puch 5 star disc brake set up 2 250
MLM Puch Maxi reinforced swingarm 1 85
moped drive chain 3 74
Puch 5 star rear sprocket bolt pack  2 11
Puch Maxi EBR cross bar 1 28
Puch 5 star rear sprocket 45tooth  1 15
Puch 5 star rear sprocket 42 tooth 1 15
Puch 5 star rear sprocket 40 tooth 1 15
Puch E50 drive sprocket 18 tooth 1 8
Puch E50 drive sprocket 17 tooth 1 8
Puch E50 drive sprocket 16 tooth 1 8
Puch E50 case bolt pack 2 24
Trail Tech computer: speed, distance, tach, voltage, engine temp  1 125
   
Total   $1,672

Challenges:

     Yes, there will be challenges on this epic 1400 mile trip. I could break down, be hit by a car, wreck, become butt hurt (see: ass chafing), I could lose a finger, I could lose an eye!

What qualifies me to overcome/ avoid these hurdles is:

-Spare parts, back up motors and the build. That’s why I’m asking for your help.

-I have chosen a motor that I could easily rebuild in my sleep. Or eyes closed, hands tied, hanging upside down. It’s simple, reliable, stock (less likely to blow up). I will also be carrying a range of basic tools and smaller minor spare parts on my moped as I ride. Specialized tools and larger parts that can be used in the event of misfortune, such as a welder or spare motors, will be carried by the chase vehicle that will follow the team as we ride into the sunset.

-Oh yeah, 6 years of daily riding and 4 rally seasons.

Rally history:

Swoop Jockeys, Atlanta, GA  2011

Old School Bret’s camp out, Inverness, FL 2012

Dead Peds, Nashville, TN 2012

Bourbon Bandits, Luisville, KY 2012

The Buzzards, Sumpter, SC 2012

Mission 23, NYC, NY 2012

White Line Riders, Wilmington, NC 2012

Swoop Jockeys, Atlanta, GA 2012

True Grits 50cc Fun Run, Suches, GA 2012

Old School Bret’s camp out, Inverness, FL 2013

Dead Peds, Nashville, TN 2013

Gentlemen’s Ride, Atlanta, GA 2013

Hot N Readyz, Chicago, IL 2013

White Line Riders, Wilmington, NC 2013

Swoop Jockeys, Atlanta, GA 2013

Resurgence, Atlanta, GA 2013

True Grits 50cc Fun Run, Suches, GA 2013

MONO, New Orleans, LA 2013

Old School Bret’s camp out, Inverness, FL 2014

Dead Peds, Nashville, TN 2014

The Buzzards, Sumpter, SC 2014

BLK BLK, Denver, CO 2014

Swoop Jockeys, Atlanta, GA 2014

-I’ve never hard-seized a cylinder, melted a piston, and I’ve been hit by a car in Atlanta traffic and survived to tell the tale.


How else can you help?

     Other than donating your hard-earned moolah, you can help get this trip off the ground by simply spreading the word. Tell any and everyone who may be able to relate to that intrinsically American fascination with travel and getting there by your own grit and gumption (with your help, of course).

     If any of you fine folks out there have experience with photo documentation and would be interested in following around this moped caravan and framing us in just the right light, making us look perdy, stealing some picturesque shots of the diverse landscape we’ll be traversing, just send me a line.



Perks for you:

     Using my creative skills and background in printmaking, I will be designing, printing, and producing a variety of moped-themed items that you will receive for your contribution in making this adventure possible. I’ve made 13 different contribution levels to allow for a wide range of contributors. The perks are located on the right hand side of this page. Feel free to browse, maybe you will find something that interests you. 


 Thank you for reading and taking your time, money, and energy to help me along on this journey.

You can find more info about the Pinball Run here at :
http://pinball-run.com/

http://vimeo.com/73735949

http://bangordailynews.com/video/pinball-run-mopeds-leave-portland-for-key-west/

http://www.advrider.com/forums/showthread.php?t=916528

Yes, you read the title right. With your help, I will be attempting to ride a pedal-start, vintage 2-stroke Puch Maxi in a 1400 mile, 5 day race.   A love story:
     It was just another balmy afternoon in
Savannah, Georgia, when I laid eyes on her for the first time. She was leaning
against the bike rack, nonchalant, stray sunlight gleaming through the grime
she wore proudly. Dented, scratched, and weathered as she was, she was still a
beautiful contraption; she had style, two wheels, a motor and… pedals? 
     This moped, the
name for a vintage motorized vehicle charmingly equipped with pedals, was my
introduction to the world of cheap, temperamental transport.  For a kid starting college in a small city
and a job at a pizza joint, the compact size and minimal expense to maintain,
upgrade, and fuel made mopeds a good investment, and as I would learn, a
growing obsession. From college freshman to college graduate, Savannah to
Atlanta, not knowing what a carburetor was to getting an engine designed for
35mph to go 70, getting hit by cars to hitching rides in trucks, going to
rallies as far away from Atlanta GA as New York City and Denver and meeting
people from all over the country, the culture of the moped community has continued
to occupy my life and fascinate me, leading me to the point of this
introduction, and  with your help, my
greatest moped test and adventure so far…. The Pinball Run.

story:
My Story

Hello and welcome! My name is Luther Bangert, and I'm a professional juggler, originally from Donnellson, Iowa, in the USA. I've been juggling for almost nine years, starting at the age of 19 around when I began attending the University of Iowa. For some years I was part of a circus group based out of Iowa City (Cirque Stupendo) which fostered my interest and growth in the arts and challenges of circus, performing the likes of juggling, unicycling, acrobatics, musical saw, sitar, whips, equilibrism, firebreathing, sword swallowing, and more. After some time I decided to scale back and focus on what always interested me most - juggling, particularly ball juggling, which I've been delving into more and more particularly the last three years.

For a long time my goal with the love of juggling was more or less to become 'amazing,' in the traditional circus sense - the primary focus being masterful tricks that surprise and awe people, and entertain in their difficulty. This method of performing is quite a beautiful thing and I've found it to be an inspiring, sacred, and rewarding phenomenon, However, once I attained a certain level of proficiency with 'pure,' 'amazing,' juggling, I reached a philosophical zone I imagine all artists intrude upon, after the honeymooned time with a particular skill, where I started to question the meaning of my performances, and then, how to change that meaning. The answer has come to me in the form of movement studies and dance.

My style of juggling as it has developed has seemed like a peculiar form of dance to me for some time, and I've been continuing that approach. In my semi - improvisational style, I think of juggling as a way of creating 'problems' or 'situations' in the air and solving these with the movement of the body, creating a compelling canvas of the relationship of objects to the body and the surrounding environment. In much the same way, I consider juggling to be a martial art - an activity that can be continually drawn upon to expand your awareness of a personal kinesphere and the possibilities within it.

And so, I've become interested in dance as a way to explore the possibilities of expression within these fields and add depth to the way I perform, and to push the edges of juggling in new ways. A challenge to be sure, but that's what I'm all about.

The Deltebre Dance Festival

I first heard of the Deltebre Dance Festival from a juggler friend who had attended last summer, and it was exactly the type of experience I was looking for. For two weeks (July 14th - 27th), the Spanish village of Deltebre is turned into a meeting point for teachers, dancers, actors, and circus performers to meet and learn from each other in an intensely immersive environment. I will be one of 150 students attending, all from varied cultures, backgrounds, and performance arts. We will attend workshops just about all day, every day, from heaps of reputed performers, choreographers, movement masters, and the like. It's exactly the push I'm looking for at this point in my art and career.

For more information the specific festival activities, performers, and workshops this year, visit http://www.deltebredansa.cat/d2014/light_eng/index.html. I've also linked above to a lovely documentary that was made on the Deltebre experience last summer.

Where You Come In

I'm overjoyed that I've been accepted to the Deltebre Dance Festival and have been waiting for months to receive word. However, while my current life style of traveling and street performing affords me enough to live, the admission fee (700 Euros = 950 Dollars) is quite out of my grasp at the moment. As I make my living through performing and asking humbly for money, I extend this approach in much the same way, with perks designed to be as personal and fulfilling for both sides as possible.

I am sure this will be a fantastically transformative event for me and my art, and will be incredibly grateful to any of you who may help me to get there.

Feel free to share with anyone you think might be interested in helping a wandering juggler along!

story:
The Story

Joe loves apple pie, Rush Limbaugh, the fourth of July and his wife Jane. He is blue-collar, corn-fed, made in the USA and proud, but when his uninsured wife is diagnosed with cancer his patriotic feelings and passion for the ethos of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are turned upside down. In Mercy Killers, a new one-man play, Joe struggles with the uniquely American experience of losing your health in the land of plenty.

About The Author

My name is Michael Milligan, author and performer of Mercy Killers. I have been a professional actor since graduating from Julliard in 2001 (where I received the John Houseman Prize!) I’ve performed on Broadway in August: Osage County and La Bete as well as many other productions Off- Broadway and Off-Off Broadway. My real bread and butter has been performing in many of our nation’s incredible regional theaters and Shakespeare festivals like the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and the Shakespeare Theater in D.C.

Statement of Purpose- Health Care as a Human Right

Last Spring I was uninsured for the first time in my adult life. About three weeks into being uninsured I experienced excruciating pain while doing a reading of a new play. I had to excuse myself and hobble back to the basement I was staying at in Jersey City. It was a horrible night of nausea, urinating blood (sorry for the gory details!), and unending pain. Worst of all, I didn’t know what was happening. In between the waves of pain, I was at the computer trying to diagnose myself online and googling things like ‘how much will it cost to pay for an ambulance and emergency room.’ Worst of all, I spent the evening performing a gruesome kind of accounting. ‘Let’s see, if I’m experiencing kidney failure, I have an 8% chance of being dead in the morning. However, a trip in the ambulance to the emergency room will cost me $8000, which I can’t really afford. I guess I’ll take my chances and see how I feel in the morning.’

Thankfully, it turned out that I had passed kidney stones- which although seriously painful is not a serious condition. However, the experience made me wonder what it must be like to face a serious health emergency in America without insurance. Kidney stones is one thing, but what about cancer? The experience led to a lot research, interviews, and soul searching.

Mercy Killers is a play about what it can be like for working people to face a major health crisis in America. I gave a number of benefit performances of it in Minnesota in collaboration with Health Care for All Minnesota. Here’s what state senator, John Marty had to say about it:

‘Michael Milligan's "Mercy Killers" is a powerful play that illustrates the urgency of replacing our dysfunctional health insurance system.  In this painfully accurate portrayal of the personal struggles of one couple, Milligan makes public the suffering that thousands of American families experience in private.   I was inspired by the performance, and energized to move our state from health insurance for some, to health care for all.’ John Marty, State Senator, MN.

The Tour

I am putting together a ‘micro-tour’ of Mercy Killers in collaboration with local health care advocacy groups to raise awareness about our dysfunctional health care system. I have reserved a theater in Columbus, Ohio (the swingin’ city of the swing state) for a 3 week run in Feb/March. While in Ohio I will be traveling to towns like Toledo, Akron, Dayton, Medina, and Oberlin to share the story and help generate support for local single-payer advocacy groups. After the Ohio trip, I’ll be heading off to Minnesota and New York to work with advocacy groups and progressive organizations to share Mercy Killers in both big cities and smaller communities around the states to help raise awareness about legislation to create single payer systems at the state level.

Your contribution

Unless I am doing a benefit for a specific organization, performances of Mercy Killers will be free and open to the public (with an invitation to make a donation at the end of the show to help keep the tour going!) Your contribution will help generate an audience of people who normally would not attend the theater. It will help pay for transportation, marketing, a small artist’s fee and in some cases, the rental fee for venues.

Critical Response

I believe Mercy Killers is a powerful story and tool for raising awareness about our health care system. But don’t just take my word for it! Here’s what some of the folks I’ve worked with have to say:

“Michael Milligan’s Mercy Killers is a powerful teaching tool to deliver the emotional impact of how our health care system chews up and spits out so many Americans. This masterfully written and performed play displays the agonizing, dehumanizing suffering needlessly imposed on decent people by a system that turns health care into a commodity instead of a basic human right. Mercy Killers poignantly demonstrated how rugged individualism can’t compete with diseases and expenses that can strike down anyone.” –Buddy Robinson, Co-Coordinator, Greater Minnesota Health Care Coalition.

‘As a long-time advocate for meaningful healthcare reform, I found a refreshing perspective in ‘Mercy Killers’.  When focusing on policy, it can be easy to lose sight of the actual plight faced by real people.  The play provides a very personal look at the blameless catastrophe many average Americans face when they become ill.  As a doctor, I have amassed plenty of my own horror stories of patient suffering.  I was surprised I could be this affected by yet another.  However, Milligan’s acting is superb, and I was completely engrossed in the story from beginning to end.  The tale he weaves brings you into the middle of a needless, mind-numbing tragedy that should never happen in a country as wealthy as ours.  It has power that facts and figures will never offer.  Regardless of political persuasion or beliefs about how to fix the healthcare mess, audience members will leave the performance deeply moved and in agreement that we simply cannot leave things as they are.’ - Ann Settgast, MD, Co-chair, Minnesota chapter of Physicians for a National Healthcare Program

“Mercy Killers is an extremely powerful and heart-wrenching testament to our health care system’s effects on our finances, families, and overall well-being.” Erin Anderson, Executive Director, Health Care for All Minnesota.

“Michael Milligan's breath-taking performance of a shattered man in the throes of a healthcare nightmare, made only worse by the twists and turns of insurance companies, truly humanizes the vast inequities of America's for profit health insurance system. You will be talking about 'Mercy Killers' long after the curtain draws." - Josh Starcher, Healthcare-NOW! NYC

“A deeply affecting love story, Mike Milligan astonishes.” Connie Julian, Revolution Books.

 

Spread the Word!

While financial assistance is appreciated, you can help in other ways as well. Please share this page on Facebook or send a link to friends you think might be interested in the campaign. Also, if you know of any organizations or venues that might be interested in collaborating on a performance, please contact me!
story_txt:
The Story
Joe loves apple pie, Rush Limbaugh, the fourth of July and his wife Jane. He is blue-collar, corn-fed, made in the USA and proud, but when his uninsured wife is diagnosed with cancer his patriotic feelings and passion for the ethos of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are turned upside down. In Mercy Killers, a new one-man play, Joe struggles with the uniquely American experience of losing your health in the land of plenty.
About The Author
My name is Michael Milligan, author and performer of Mercy Killers. I have been a professional actor since graduating from Julliard in 2001 (where I received the John Houseman Prize!) I’ve performed on Broadway in August: Osage County and La Bete as well as many other productions Off- Broadway and Off-Off Broadway. My real bread and butter has been performing in many of our nation’s incredible regional theaters and Shakespeare festivals like the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and the Shakespeare Theater in D.C.
Statement of Purpose- Health Care as a Human Right
Last Spring I was uninsured for the first time in my adult life. About three weeks into being uninsured I experienced excruciating pain while doing a reading of a new play. I had to excuse myself and hobble back to the basement I was staying at in Jersey City. It was a horrible night of nausea, urinating blood (sorry for the gory details!), and unending pain. Worst of all, I didn’t know what was happening. In between the waves of pain, I was at the computer trying to diagnose myself online and googling things like ‘how much will it cost to pay for an ambulance and emergency room.’ Worst of all, I spent the evening performing a gruesome kind of accounting. ‘Let’s see, if I’m experiencing kidney failure, I have an 8% chance of being dead in the morning. However, a trip in the ambulance to the emergency room will cost me $8000, which I can’t really afford. I guess I’ll take my chances and see how I feel in the morning.’
Thankfully, it turned out that I had passed kidney stones- which although seriously painful is not a serious condition. However, the experience made me wonder what it must be like to face a serious health emergency in America without insurance. Kidney stones is one thing, but what about cancer? The experience led to a lot research, interviews, and soul searching.
Mercy Killers is a play about what it can be like for working people to face a major health crisis in America. I gave a number of benefit performances of it in Minnesota in collaboration with Health Care for All Minnesota. Here’s what state senator, John Marty had to say about it:
‘Michael Milligan's "Mercy Killers" is a powerful play that illustrates the urgency of replacing our dysfunctional health insurance system.  In this painfully accurate portrayal of the personal struggles of one couple, Milligan makes public the suffering that thousands of American families experience in private.   I was inspired by the performance, and energized to move our state from health insurance for some, to health care for all.’ John Marty, State Senator, MN.
The Tour
I am putting together a ‘micro-tour’ of Mercy Killers in collaboration with local health care advocacy groups to raise awareness about our dysfunctional health care system. I have reserved a theater in Columbus, Ohio (the swingin’ city of the swing state) for a 3 week run in Feb/March. While in Ohio I will be traveling to towns like Toledo, Akron, Dayton, Medina, and Oberlin to share the story and help generate support for local single-payer advocacy groups. After the Ohio trip, I’ll be heading off to Minnesota and New York to work with advocacy groups and progressive organizations to share Mercy Killers in both big cities and smaller communities around the states to help raise awareness about legislation to create single payer systems at the state level.
Your contribution
Unless I am doing a benefit for a specific organization, performances of Mercy Killers will be free and open to the public (with an invitation to make a donation at the end of the show to help keep the tour going!) Your contribution will help generate an audience of people who normally would not attend the theater. It will help pay for transportation, marketing, a small artist’s fee and in some cases, the rental fee for venues.
Critical Response
I believe Mercy Killers is a powerful story and tool for raising awareness about our health care system. But don’t just take my word for it! Here’s what some of the folks I’ve worked with have to say:
“Michael Milligan’s Mercy Killers is a powerful teaching tool to deliver the emotional impact of how our health care system chews up and spits out so many Americans. This masterfully written and performed play displays the agonizing, dehumanizing suffering needlessly imposed on decent people by a system that turns health care into a commodity instead of a basic human right. Mercy Killers poignantly demonstrated how rugged individualism can’t compete with diseases and expenses that can strike down anyone.” –Buddy Robinson, Co-Coordinator, Greater Minnesota Health Care Coalition.
‘As a long-time advocate for meaningful healthcare reform, I found a refreshing perspective in ‘Mercy Killers’.  When focusing on policy, it can be easy to lose sight of the actual plight faced by real people.  The play provides a very personal look at the blameless catastrophe many average Americans face when they become ill.  As a doctor, I have amassed plenty of my own horror stories of patient suffering.  I was surprised I could be this affected by yet another.  However, Milligan’s acting is superb, and I was completely engrossed in the story from beginning to end.  The tale he weaves brings you into the middle of a needless, mind-numbing tragedy that should never happen in a country as wealthy as ours.  It has power that facts and figures will never offer.  Regardless of political persuasion or beliefs about how to fix the healthcare mess, audience members will leave the performance deeply moved and in agreement that we simply cannot leave things as they are.’ - Ann Settgast, MD, Co-chair, Minnesota chapter of Physicians for a National Healthcare Program
“Mercy Killers is an extremely powerful and heart-wrenching testament to our health care system’s effects on our finances, families, and overall well-being.” Erin Anderson, Executive Director, Health Care for All Minnesota.
“Michael Milligan's breath-taking performance of a shattered man in the throes of a healthcare nightmare, made only worse by the twists and turns of insurance companies, truly humanizes the vast inequities of America's for profit health insurance system. You will be talking about 'Mercy Killers' long after the curtain draws." - Josh Starcher, Healthcare-NOW! NYC
“A deeply affecting love story, Mike Milligan astonishes.” Connie Julian, Revolution Books.
 
Spread the Word!
While financial assistance is appreciated, you can help in other ways as well. Please share this page on Facebook or send a link to friends you think might be interested in the campaign. Also, if you know of any organizations or venues that might be interested in collaborating on a performance, please contact me!

story:
Short Summary

I am trying to raise some money for my daughter Angel.  Angel has a true talent and love for dancing and performing, and has been invited to join her dance academy preform in Disneyworld Orlando, FL, but the cost for the trip is very expensive ($1900).  I am asking that we try and help Angel with her dream and performance of a life time.

My goal is $500 to get her started, but I hope to exceed that number. The full cost is $1900 
 

What We Need

-Round trip airfare from Albuquerque to Orlando

-Four night accommodations at Disney's All Star Resort

-Three day Park Hopper to Disney theme parks

-Motor coach transportation between airport, Disney resort performance 

-Tips for motor coach drivers, tour leaders, etc 

 

The Impact


Help a 5yr old little girl say "I'M GOING TO DISNEYWORLD" for the first time, and fulfill her dream of Performing for Disneyworld.

I believe this would truly help build the self esteem and confidence for a young child and with your help this would become a once in a lifetime opportunity accomplished. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help 

Also please bear with me, as I have never done this before, and all I want to do is help my daughter!

I also understand that money is sometimes tight, and anything you can do to help is valuable to this cause.  Tweet it, Facebook it, do people still use MySpace?  if they do, spread the word every where.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Amadeus in Durham, NC

Power. Genius. Murder. Mozart. A War with God.

Hi! I'm John Jimerson, the Managing Director of Leviathan Theatre Company, and I'm also an actor in Amadeus.  We're asking you to join us in our effort to make Leviathan's production of Amadeus happen in Durham, NC.

Amadeus is a play that drills down into the heart of who we are: deals made with God, fame, genius, hope, jealousy, power, murder, and the beauty of music.  For anyone who has stuggled with their relationship with the Divine, for anyone who is a lover of music, who has struggled to make ends meet, who has felt the joy of celebration, for anyone who knows how sweet revenge can feel, even if only for 5 minutes... this is your play.

Usually told as the story of an older and more powerful man trying to destroy a more gifted younger man, we are presenting Amadeus as a brothers play, with actors of the same age playing the two male roles.  Jade Arnold will play Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and I will play his rival Antonio Salieri.  Molly Forlines will play Constanze Weber, the woman caught between them.  The play is directed by prolific local director Jaybird O'Berski, Artistic Director of Little Green Pig Theatrical Concern. 

Our Creative Team:

  • Director: Jaybird O'Berski
  • Actors: Jade Arnold, Molly Forlines, John Jimerson, Trevor Johnson, Carly Prentis Jones, Liam O'Neill, Tony Perucci, Caitlin Wells, Laurie Wolf
  • Stage Manager: Jessica Flemming
  • Costume Designer: Chelsea Kurtzman
  • Lighting Designer: R.S. Buck
  • Sound Designer: Adam Lindquist
  • Physical Theatre Coach: Lucius Robinson

Our Director's Vision:

"We're interested in rehabilitating the play from it's strong associations with the Academy Award winning film. The decadence of the piece is attractive, where gluttony is tactile (sex), oral (food) and aural (music) and motivates the characters, pitching them into battle over limited resources.

We'll be drawing inspiration from the direction and design of Robert Wilson who marries traditions of restraint with excess, Germanic Calvinism with Mediterranean paganism. 

We expect the production will feel like the work of film directors like Almodovar, von Trier, Jodorowsky and Refn. Grotesque characters will act as foils to elegant creatures, veniality will balance the holy as it does in Mozart's music."

To help this vision happen, we're asking for your help.


What We Need & What You Get

Here's a bit about the funding:

  • Spaces have costs, as do lights, sound designers, costumes, and props.  Our goal is to raise $5,500 to cover the rest of our costs and expenditures, hopefully freeing the artistic team to focus on the play.  We're asking for your help with any part of that amount you feel comfortable donating.

  • On the right side of the screen, you'll see our "perks" for various levels of donations.  These range from your name in the program, to being an insider and attending a rehearsal, to a VIP seat on the stage with the performers, to a free acting lesson from one of the actors.  You give to us, and we want to give back to you! 

  • If we don’t reach our entire goal, your contribution still goes towards helping the production happen.

The Impact

Your contribution will help fund:

  • Costumes, Props, and Lights
  • Marketing/Publicity Materials and Programs
  • Insurance
  • Performance Space and Rehearsal Space
  • Incidentals
  • Stipends for Actors, Director, Stage Manager, and Designers

How You Can Help

DONATE:

All donations go directly to the actual costs of the lights, space, props, costumes, and paying our creative team, and are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE. 

Little Green Pig Theatrical Concern is the fiscal sponsor of our campaign, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that strives to bring provocative work to the Triangle area of North Carolina.  Their artistic model is experimental but accessible, strange and dreamlike, but familiar and immediate.  Little Green Pig is dedicated to Enlightenment values: exploration of imagination, questioning traditional ideas, and subjecting their work to the light of Reason. 

SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN WITH YOUR FRIENDS:

Check out the great perks (at right) that come with supporting the arts!  Maybe your friends would like in on the fun.  You can contribute to the success of Amadeus by sharing this Indiegogo campaign.  

GET IN TOUCH WITH US:

Leave us a note at contact@amadeusdurham.com.  We want to hear how our production of Amadeus may intersect with your work, hopes, and dreams.  

COME SEE AMADEUS:

If you live in the Raleigh-Durham area, please join us at Common Ground Theater for Leviathan's production of Amadeus, March 27-April 12th, 2014, in Durham, NC. 

www.amadeusdurham.com

Thank you, and see you at the theatre!

story:
About Alphabetti

Alphabetti creates and books work for the multipurpose performance space in the centre of Newcastle Upon Tyne - Upstairs @ The Dog & Parrot. What does that mean and what do we actually do?

We preview the latest emerging talent in the north east - music, comedy, theatre, poetry and just about anything else that can be performed. Our venue's capacity is a 50 seater or 100 standing. We keep all our ticket prices below £10 so to keep all our productions economically available to all. 

So when an actor, director, writer finishes their training they're tossed out into the big bad world and expected to find work in hugely cut throat industry; however how do you get work with the big names in the industry when you have nothing on your CV apart from some qualifications? How do you even get a foot in the door? Well that’s where we come in, the work we create gives emerging writers, actors, directors something they can put on their CV as a professional credit and something they can invite professionals to watch as a showcase of their work.

The work we book allows artists the chance to perform without costing them an arm and a leg. If you have a great show that you want to perform but don't have the funds to rent a venue come to us, if they can demonstrate why they should perform in our space we provide them with that opportunity for no upfront costs just a split of ticket sales, we have no hidden add on costs and try to keep costs down to a minimum.

What We Need & Why

We are trying to raise £1,750 to do some much needed home improvements.

  • The majority of the funds is going towards improving our lighting rig, we currently have 3 colour lights this is a great start however it is not bright enough to do a whole production under. So we have to use the normal light switch to add provide the extra light. With your money we will have enough light meaning we can then reduce the staff needed which keeps costs low for the visiting artists and our company.
  • The rest of the funds raised will go on paint and building supplies to do up our toilets, outdoor terrace and back room. 

What Do You Get?

This is your hard-earned cash and we are so grateful for any help you can provide which is why we are offering these thank-you tokens.

£5 + - a tweet ‘shout out’  to our 1,650 followers thanking you, personally.

£25 + - we'll email you a personal picture thanking you.

£75 +  a personal video thanking you

£100 + a handwritten letter plus a picture in the letter

£150+ You will have you name mounted on the Wall of Fame 

£500+ You will receive a season pass for our next season which runs from October 2013 - December 2013 plus being included on the Wall of Fame

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes you just haven't got any cash to give, thank you for reading this far! You can still help and show your support:

Spread the work on social media maybe your wealthy friend could help! (there are share tools on the bottom of this page)

Come to one of our shows! We have stuff on the whole time visit us and enjoy an evening with us! Visit our website to see what’s happening. http://www.alphabettispaghettitheatre.co.uk/

story:
NEW SHORT FILM FROM SOLUTIONS GRASSROOTS: What Millennials Talk About When They Talk About Climate Change 



What is The Solutions Grassroots Tour?

The short version: The Solutions Grassroots Tour is a series of theater, film and concert events that give communities the tools and resources to build their own renewable energy.

The long version: The Solutions Grassroots Tour is much more than a one-night play or screening. It is a series of culture events and campaigns that will galvanize the renewable energy revolution at the grassroots level across the United States.

Conceived and directed by Oscar-Nominated and Emmy-Winning filmmaker and activist Josh Fox, The Solutions Grassroots Tour combines classic storytelling with roll-up-your sleeves organizing to look at the impacts of fossil fuel development and provide a vision for developing renewable energy like no other event on the planet. 

Why Renewable Energy?


The debate is over and the science is in, CLIMATE CHANGE IS REAL, and our current energy infrastructure is what's causing it. If we continue to burn fossil fuels like coal, oil and gas to run our country, soon we won't have a planet we can live on.

The Solutions Grassroots Tour is about building the alternative- democratic, renewable energy. We know there’s tremendous influence from the fossil fuel industry on our government.  If we’re going to take the vision of running our country on 100% renewable energy from the pages of scientific plans and make it a reality in our communities, we will need a strong, organized, grassroots movement to begin building it on the ground.



Why Grassroots?

By touring to over 300 towns with GASLAND and GASLAND Part II, we’ve built an extensive grassroots network of over 500 organizations and individuals that are ready to get out of the fossil fuel cycle, and the lead the way developing renewable energy.

Gasland Grassroots Tour Stops

We believe that to change the economic and political structures that are currently keeping us addicted to fossil fuels we’re going to need one of the most powerful grassroots mobilizations in history.

We’ve seen the power of grassroots organizing first hand. Hundreds of communities around the world have come together to fight fracking, and many of them are winning.



Select Grassroots Campaign Highlights:

  • Fracking moratorium in NY State
  • Fracking  ban in Pittsburgh
  • Fracking  ban in Tompkins County, NY
  • Fracking  ban in Cooperstown, NY
  • Fracking ban in Licking Township, PA
  • Fracking ban in Baldwin, PA
  • Fracking ban in France
  • Fracking ban in Bulgaria
  • Fracking ban in Quebec
  • Fracking ban in Mora County, New Mexico
  • Fracking  ban or moratorium in four Colorado municipalities in most recent election.
  • Continued moratorium in NY State
  • Continued moratorium in the Delaware River Basin
  • Companies vacating leases for over 100,000 acres in Delaware River basin
  • Fracking ban in the Netherlands
  • Continued moratorium in South Africa
  • Continued moratorium in New South Wales, Australia
  • Fracking ban in Vermont

The GASLAND films educated people on the dangers of fracking, but it was our grassroots tour screenings that galvanized communities to organize against fracking. The Solutions Grassroots aims to do the same for renewable energy development.

Gasland Part II Screening in Pittsburgh, PA. Audience size 1700.

Why Theater?

Because the theater is a kind of collective action.  The theater is a motivator.  A great theater production is something that you never forget about all your days.

In addition to making two Oscar-nominated and Emmy-Winning feature films, our non-profit organization, International WOW Company, has made over 25 new works for the stage.  These plays premiered in amazing places all over the world, hence our name.  We performed in Thailand and Japan and the Philippines, we performed in Germany and France, we performed in New York City and in upstate New York.  We made huge, fantastical, epic plays with large casts, striking imagery and powerful politics.

We feel to change a nation's beliefs, you need to change its culture.  You can only change culture through culture.


 


Previous Praise for our theater work with International WOW Company

"FEARLESSLY INVENTIVE. VIRTUOSIC. VERY POWERFUL. They make us want to question ourselves and make deeper sense of what binds the everyday to the cataclysmic." - The New York Times

"IT CHALLENGES YOUR SENSES. IT HAUNTS YOUR DREAMS. Don't miss a minute of this endlessly innovative international theater company."                                 - New Jersey Journal

The Solutions Grassroots Tour so far

This summer we had two workshop performances of The Solutions Grassroots Tour in Callicoon and Oneonta, New York and in September we had a six day run in Brooklyn, New York following The People’s Climate March.

Our Brooklyn run was co-hosted by Mark Ruffalo, Debra Winger, Phylicia Rashad, Sandra Steingraber, Peter Yarrow, Nahko Bear, Bill McKibben, and Zephyr Teachout. 

Co-sponsors included: Citizens Campaign for the Environment, Food & Water Watch, Frack Action, New Yorkers Against Fracking, Sane Energy Project, United for Action, The Mother's Project and 350NYC. 

The Solutions Grassroots Tour in Callicoon, New York

Here’s what our audience members are saying:

"CREATIVITY THAT THE MOVEMENT NEEDS... We've tried many ways to communicate the dangers of fracking, and applaud this bold attempt to use interactive theater as a storyteller."                                                                                               - the team at Sane Energy Project

“A moving, beautiful experience that serves as a call to action. This performance  invites you into the personal realities of why it's so important to fight fossil fuel development and climate change.  The Solutions crew makes sure you leave with a clear path to switch your power to renewables in essence reclaiming power from an out of control industry.  Personal choices matter.”                                                                    -Jill Weiner, Catskill Citizens for Safe Energy

“This piece is a moving, emotional drama which forces one to examine their role in continuing to participate in the disaster that is fossil fuel energy”                              -Bob Eklund, Butternuts Valley Alliance

http://www.riverreporter.com/news/4302/2014/07/23/new-direction-gasland-filmmaker


About Josh Fox, creator and director of The Solutions Grassroots Tour

                                                     

Josh Fox is best known as the writer/director of GASLAND Parts I and II. Among numerous honors, together the films garnered an Academy Award Nomination for Best Documentary and an Emmy for best Documentary Directing.  Along with four other Emmy nominations, the films also received the Sundance Special Jury Prize for documentary, two Environmental Media Association Awards for Best Documentary and widespread HBO distribution.  Fox is internationally recognized as a spokesperson and leader on the issue of fracking and extreme energy development.  He is also the founder and producing artistic director of the International WOW Company. He is available for interviews prior to and during the showcase events.

Josh has toured to over 300 cities with his films and plays.  As a national spokesman on the issues of the contamination resulting from fossil fuel extraction, Josh has appeared on the Daily Show, Real Time with Bill Maher, The Keith Olbermann show, PBS Now, CNN and Democracy Now. He has regularly appeared on MSNBC making frequent appearances on the Chris Hayes shows (Up and All in), The Ed Show, Countdown with Keith Olbermann, Morning Joe, Melissa Harris-Perry, Alex Wagner, Tamron Hall, and Dylan Ratigan.  

Help us take this show on the road!

Between our extensive grassroots network and the artistic strength of our work, we know that if we can take this show on the road, we’ll be able to inspire thousands of people to begin the transition to 100% renewable energy.

Many of our grassroots partners have already requested we bring The Solutions Grassroots Tour to their towns.

These are communities all over the country that are already living with or staring down extreme energy extraction in their backyards. Between fracking, mountain top removal, tar sands, off-shore drilling and all the infrastructure that goes with fossil fuel development, there are more of frontline communities than ever before.

When you start adding in all the communities impacted by climate change, we have a large base of of people ready to start building the alternative.

$75,000 will allow us to bring The Solutions Grassroots Tour and other cultural events directly to our grassroots network so we can begin the transition to 100% renewable energy all over the country.

Join the movement

Sign up for updates at www.SolutionsGrassroots.com

You can also get yourself out of the fossil fuel cycle through one of our vetted-renewable energy partners. Renewable Energy Menu
story_txt:
NEW SHORT FILM FROM SOLUTIONS GRASSROOTS: What Millennials Talk About When They Talk About Climate Change What is The Solutions Grassroots Tour?
The short
version: The Solutions
Grassroots Tour is a series of theater, film and concert events that give communities the tools and resources to build their own renewable energy.
The long
version: The Solutions
Grassroots Tour is much more than a one-night play or screening. It is a
series of culture events and campaigns that will galvanize the renewable energy
revolution at the grassroots level across the United States.Conceived and directed by Oscar-Nominated and Emmy-Winning filmmaker and activist Josh Fox, The Solutions Grassroots Tour combines classic storytelling with roll-up-your sleeves organizing to look at the impacts of fossil fuel development and provide a vision for developing renewable energy like no other event on the planet. Why Renewable Energy? The debate is over and the science is in, CLIMATE CHANGE IS REAL, and our current energy infrastructure is what's causing it. If we continue to burn fossil fuels like coal, oil and gas to run our country, soon we won't have a planet we can live on.The Solutions
Grassroots Tour is about building the alternative- democratic, renewable
energy. We know there’s tremendous
influence from the fossil fuel industry on our government.  If we’re going to
take the vision of running our country on 100% renewable energy from the pages
of scientific plans and make it a reality in our communities, we will need a
strong, organized, grassroots movement to begin building it on the ground.
Why Grassroots? 
By touring to
over 300 towns with GASLAND and GASLAND Part II, we’ve built an extensive
grassroots network of over 500 organizations and individuals that are ready to
get out of the fossil fuel cycle, and the lead the way developing renewable
energy.
Gasland Grassroots Tour StopsWe believe that
to change the economic and political structures that are currently keeping us
addicted to fossil fuels we’re going to need one of the most powerful
grassroots mobilizations in history.
We’ve seen the
power of grassroots organizing first hand. Hundreds of communities around the
world have come together to fight fracking, and many of them are winning.
Select
Grassroots Campaign Highlights:

Fracking
     moratorium in NY State
Fracking
      ban in Pittsburgh 
Fracking
      ban in Tompkins County, NY 
Fracking
      ban in Cooperstown, NY
Fracking
     ban in Licking Township, PA 
Fracking
     ban in Baldwin, PA 
Fracking
     ban in France 
Fracking
     ban in Bulgaria
Fracking
     ban in Quebec 
Fracking
     ban in Mora County, New Mexico 
Fracking
      ban or moratorium in four Colorado municipalities in most recent
     election.
Continued
     moratorium in NY State
Continued
     moratorium in the Delaware River Basin
Companies
     vacating leases for over 100,000 acres in Delaware River basin
Fracking
     ban in the Netherlands
Continued
     moratorium in South Africa
Continued
     moratorium in New South Wales, Australia
Fracking ban in Vermont
The GASLAND films educated people on the dangers of fracking, but it was our grassroots tour screenings that galvanized communities to organize against fracking. The Solutions Grassroots aims to do the same for renewable energy development.Gasland Part II Screening in Pittsburgh, PA. Audience size 1700.Why Theater?
Because the theater is a kind of collective action. 
The theater is a motivator.  A great theater production is something that
you never forget about all your days.In addition to making two Oscar-nominated and Emmy-Winning feature films, our non-profit organization, International WOW Company, has made over 25 new works for the stage.  These plays premiered in amazing places all over the world, hence our name.  We performed in Thailand and Japan and the Philippines, we performed in Germany and France, we performed in New York City and in upstate New York.  We made huge, fantastical, epic plays with large casts, striking imagery and powerful politics. We feel to change a nation's beliefs, you need to change its culture.  You can only change culture through culture.  Previous Praise for our theater work with International WOW Company"FEARLESSLY INVENTIVE. VIRTUOSIC. VERY POWERFUL. They make us want to question ourselves and make deeper sense of what binds the everyday to the cataclysmic." - The New York Times"IT CHALLENGES YOUR SENSES. IT HAUNTS YOUR DREAMS. Don't miss a minute of this endlessly innovative international theater company."                                 - New Jersey JournalThe Solutions Grassroots Tour so far
This summer we
had two workshop performances of The Solutions Grassroots Tour in Callicoon and
Oneonta, New York and in September we had a six day run in Brooklyn, New York following
The People’s Climate March.Our Brooklyn run was co-hosted by Mark Ruffalo, Debra Winger, Phylicia Rashad, Sandra Steingraber, Peter Yarrow, Nahko Bear, Bill McKibben, and Zephyr Teachout. Co-sponsors included: Citizens Campaign for the Environment, Food & Water Watch, Frack Action, New Yorkers Against Fracking, Sane Energy Project, United for Action, The Mother's Project and 350NYC. 
The Solutions Grassroots Tour in Callicoon, New York
Here’s what our
audience members are saying:
"CREATIVITY THAT THE MOVEMENT NEEDS... We've tried many ways to communicate the dangers
of fracking, and applaud this bold attempt to use interactive theater as a
storyteller."                                                                                               - the team at Sane Energy Project

“A moving, beautiful experience that serves as a call to action. This performance
 invites you into the personal realities of why it's so important to fight
fossil fuel development and climate change.  The Solutions crew makes sure
you leave with a clear path to switch your power to renewables in essence
reclaiming power from an out of control industry.  Personal choices
matter.”                                                                    -Jill Weiner, Catskill Citizens for Safe Energy
“This
piece is a moving, emotional drama which forces one to examine their role in
continuing to participate in the disaster that is fossil fuel energy”                              -Bob
Eklund, Butternuts Valley Alliancehttp://www.riverreporter.com/news/4302/2014/07/23/new-direction-gasland-filmmakerAbout Josh
Fox, creator and director of The Solutions Grassroots Tour                                                     Josh Fox is best
known as the writer/director of GASLAND Parts I and II. Among numerous honors,
together the films garnered an Academy Award Nomination for Best Documentary
and an Emmy for best Documentary Directing. 
Along with four other Emmy nominations, the films also received the
Sundance Special Jury Prize for documentary, two Environmental Media
Association Awards for Best Documentary and widespread HBO distribution.
 Fox is internationally recognized as a spokesperson and leader on the
issue of fracking and extreme energy development.  He is also the founder
and producing artistic director of the International WOW Company. He is
available for interviews prior to and during the showcase events. 
Josh has toured
to over 300 cities with his films and plays.  As a national spokesman on
the issues of the contamination resulting from fossil fuel extraction, Josh has
appeared on the Daily Show, Real Time with Bill Maher, The Keith Olbermann
show, PBS Now, CNN and Democracy Now. He has regularly appeared on MSNBC making
frequent appearances on the Chris Hayes shows (Up and All in), The Ed Show,
Countdown with Keith Olbermann, Morning Joe, Melissa Harris-Perry, Alex Wagner,
Tamron Hall, and Dylan Ratigan.  
Help us take this show on the road! Between our
extensive grassroots network and the artistic strength of our work, we know
that if we can take this show on the road, we’ll be able to inspire thousands
of people to begin the transition to 100% renewable energy. 
Many of our
grassroots partners have already requested we bring The Solutions Grassroots Tour
to their towns. 
These are
communities all over the country that are already living with or staring down
extreme energy extraction in their backyards. Between fracking, mountain top
removal, tar sands, off-shore drilling and all the infrastructure that goes
with fossil fuel development, there are more of frontline communities than ever before. 
When you start
adding in all the communities impacted by climate change, we have a large base of
of people ready to start building the alternative.
$75,000 will
allow us to bring The Solutions Grassroots Tour and other cultural events
directly to our grassroots network so we can begin the transition to 100%
renewable energy all over the country.
Join the movement
Sign up for updates at www.SolutionsGrassroots.com
You can also get yourself out of the fossil fuel cycle
through one of our vetted-renewable energy partners. Renewable Energy Menu

story:
Our production of Les Miserables has closed but we are still working on bookkeeping and paying the 78 musicians, technicians, and actors involved with the show, all from right here in Tucson! However, we still need a lot of help help to finish paying the orchestra. Your donations insure that we can continue to produce large uplifting productions such as this one during the summers outside of our small intimate shows at the Temple of Music and Art. 

Arizona Daily Star and Tucson Weekly both gave rave reviews and much of our success was due to the 15 fantastic, professional musicians of the orchestra that gave their time and talents to our production. Thank you so much for your support of the arts and of local talent!

As one of our cast members wrote - "The final dust has settled. The trumpets have returned to their cases and the rifles see the darkness of the armory. The flags have been folded and locked away, and the streets have bled all busyness away. The barricade is a dark shadow cooking its wood in the quiet sun. All is calm. The drums have stopped. But the world is changing. The revolution lives in those who came to see our show. The drums beat in your hearts now, and you'll carry them with you to the corners of the earth. Let your light shine to all you meet, and be good to all you meet. The people will always sing."

story:
Short Summary

Visceral motion, provocative statements and original choreography are trademarks of Dafmark Dance Theater, the Erie-based contemporary dance company founded in 1990 by Dafna and Jean-Marc Baier.  

Dafmark is looking for $5000 to keep its doors open in 2015.  With this money, we will be able to pay the bills while generating other income through performances.

story:
Thank you for visiting our indiegogo page. My name is Jackie Schiffer (www.jackieschiffer.com) and I am a NYC-based actor and first time producer. My co-producer and I are writing to ask for your support in our upcoming theatrical adventure. On September 12th and 13th, we will be producing the NYC premiere of C'est La Vie by Gregg Opelka at the Duplex (http://www.theduplex.com/~thedup/webcalendar/vi...). 

The show is about two cabaret singers in 1950s Paris who decide to take charge of their creative destiny after being dealt years of the same boring set at Chez Leplee (the cabaret). 

I was particularly drawn to the piece because of my Chicago roots (Gregg is Chicago-based and C'est la Vie had a run at Light Opera Works... a place I interned before moving to NYC) and because I am a French speaker. The team was also particularly drawn to the piece because it is about two friends who come together to create their own opportunities-- a challenge we both feel this musical will offer us. 

As young artists, we feel that it is important to capture the message of the two women we will portray--- to seize the moment and create your own rich artistic experiences.

We are committed to making this wonderful work of life be an outstanding piece of immersive theater in NYC. Updates about our production can be found at: www.cestlavienyc.weebly.com . We will host a cabaret fundraiser this June to raise additional funding, but where will your funds go?

-Rental fee of scores: $400

-Royalties: $150 

-Costumes: $300

-Scripts: $50

-CD: $30

-Printed Materials (programs, posters, postcards): $150

-Press Kit: $200

Additional Expenses: Dialect CD, props, CD/Videography of Performance, Promotional ads, rehearsal space rental, stipends for production team and actors. 

The composer/writer Mr. Opelka  is interested in attending our premiere. Please help us give this piece the NYC debut it deserves! 

Any support you can offer would be so greatly appreciated. Thank you for your time and we hope to see you at the performances September 12 and 13th.

Merci,

Jackie, Angela, Nia, Andreas, Jeremy, Patty, David and Anna
